!ID 000000001
!v880!S1679-62252010000300001
!v704!
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="4"><b>Phylogeny of    the family Characidae (Teleostei: Characiformes): from characters to taxonomy</b></font></p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Juan Marcos    Mirande</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">CONICET-Fundaci&oacute;n    Miguel Lillo, Miguel Lillo 251, 4000 San Miguel de Tucum&aacute;n, Argentina.    <a href="mailto:mcmirande@gmail.com">mcmirande@gmail.com</a></font></p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p> <hr size="1" noshade>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>ABSTRACT</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The family Characidae    is the most diverse among Neotropical fishes. Systematics of this family are    mainly based on pre-cladistic papers, and only recently a phylogenetic hypothesis    for Characidae was proposed by the author. That phylogeny was based on 360 morphological    characters studied for 160 species, including representatives of families related    to Characidae. This paper is based on that phylogenetic analysis, with the analyzed    characters described herein and documented, accompanied by comparisons of their    definition and coding in previous papers. Synapomorphies of each node of the    proposed phylogeny are listed, comparisons with previous classifications provided,    and autapomorphies of the analyzed species listed. Taxonomic implications of    the proposed classification and the position of the <i>incertae sedis</i> genera    within Characidae are discussed. A discussion of the phylogenetic 
information    of the characters used in the classical systematics of the Characidae is provided.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Key words:</b>    Ostariophysi, Osteology, Morphology, Classification, Systematics.</font></p> <hr size="1" noshade>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>RESUMEN</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">La familia Characidae    es la m&aacute;s diversa entre los peces neotropicales. La sistem&aacute;tica    de esta familia est&aacute; basada principalmente en trabajos pre-clad&iacute;sticos,    y s&oacute;lo recientemente una hip&oacute;tesis filogen&eacute;tica para Characidae    fue propuesta por el autor. Esa filogenia estaba basada en 360 caracteres estudiados    en 160 especies, incluyendo representantes de familias relacionadas a Characidae.    Este trabajo est&aacute; basado en ese an&aacute;lisis filogen&eacute;tico,    y los caracteres analizados son aqu&iacute; descriptos y documentados, comparando    su definici&oacute;n y codificaci&oacute;n con trabajos previos. Las sinapomorf&iacute;as    de cada nodo de la filogenia propuesta son listadas, y se incluyen comparaciones    con clasificaciones previas; tambi&eacute;n se listan las autapomorf&iacute;as    de las especies analizadas. Las implicancias 
taxon&oacute;micas de la clasificaci&oacute;n    propuesta y la posici&oacute;n de los g&eacute;neros <i>incertae sedis</i> dentro    de Characidae son discutidas. Tambi&eacute;n se presenta una discusi&oacute;n    de la informaci&oacute;n filogen&eacute;tica de los caracteres usados en la    sistem&aacute;tica cl&aacute;sica de Characidae.</font></p> <hr size="1" noshade>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="3"><b>Introduction</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The order Characiformes    includes more than 1,800 species, of which the family Characidae is the most    diverse, with approximately 1,200 species (Reis <i>et al</i>., 2003); indeed,    the Characidae is the fourth most diverse family of fishes, after the Cyprinidae,    Cichlidae and Gobiidae (Eschmeyer &amp; Fricke, 2009). Members of the Characidae    occur from southern portions of the USA to northern Patagonia in Argentina,    being especially diverse in the Amazon, Orinoco, and La Plata River basins.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">According to the    currently accepted phylogenetic hypotheses, based on both morphological and    molecular data, the Cypriniformes constitute the sister group of (Characiformes    (Siluriformes + Gymnotiformes)) (Fink &amp; Fink, 1981, 1996; Dimmick &amp;    Larson, 1996). According to classifications prior to Mirande (2009), the Characiformes    consisted of three African families (Citharinidae, Distichodontidae and Hepsetidae)    (G&eacute;ry, 1977, Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>., 2005), 14 Neotropical families    (Acestrorhynchidae, Anostomidae, Characidae, Chilodontidae, Crenuchidae, Curimatidae,    Ctenoluciidae, Cynodontidae, Erythrinidae, Gasteropelecidae, Hemiodontidae,    Lebiasinidae, Parodontidae, Prochilodontidae, and Serrasalmidae) (Reis <i>et    al</i>., 2003; Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>., 2005), and one trans-Atlantic family    (Alestidae) (Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005). The families Citharinidae and 
Distichodontidae    constitute the suborder Citharinoidei, considered as the sister group of the    Characoidei, which includes all the remaining Characiformes (Vari, 1979; Fink    &amp; Fink, 1981, 1996; Buckup, 1998; Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>., 2005). Among    the Characoidei, the monophyly of a clade composed of the families Anostomidae,    Chilodontidae, Curimatidae, and Prochilodontidae (Anostomoidea; Vari, 1983;    Buckup, 1998), and a clade formed by the Neotropical families Ctenoluciidae,    Erythrinidae and Lebiasinidae and the African family Hepsetidae (Erythrinoidea;    Vari, 1995; Buckup, 1998) had been proposed. Relationships between these suprafamilial    groups and the remaining Characiformes were unclear, and some hypotheses that    conflicted in varying degrees were proposed (Uj, 1990; Ort&iacute; &amp; Meyer,    1997; Buckup, 1998; Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>., 2005, Hubert <i>et al</i>., 2005).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most families of    the Characiformes have evidences of monophyly (Weitzman, 1954; Roberts, 1973,    1974; Vari, 1979, 1983, 1995; Buckup, 1998; Toledo-Piza, 2000; Zanata &amp;    Vari, 2005), whereas there are no consensus on the monophyly and composition    of the Characidae. Most currently recognized subfamilial and generic groups    in the Characidae are based on the pre-cladistic papers of Eigenmann (<i>e</i>.    <i>g</i>. 1912, 1915, 1917, 1918, 1921, 1927) and Eigenmann &amp; Myers (1929).    Eigenmann (1917) was highly influential in terms of our present concepts of    relationships within the Characidae. Eigenmann defined 17 characters with discrete    alternative states, and used them in different combinations to diagnose the    genera in the Characidae, considering the most frequent states as being primitive.    The genus <i>Astyanax</i> Baird &amp; Girard has the combination of the most    frequent states of 
all these characters, and it was consequently considered    by Eigenmann (1917) as primitive within the family. Eigenmann, however, recognized    that the less frequent states could have independent origins in different species    of the same genus, producing "polyphyletic" &#91;sic&#93; genera. Given the    impossibility to classify the Characidae in a branching scheme, Eigenmann (1917)    presented a radial pattern, identifying a "nucleus" of generalized morphology    (represented by the genus <i>Astyanax</i>) and different lines of evolution    diverging from it.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Eigenmann's classification    was followed by Greenwood <i>et al</i>. (1966) and particularly by G&eacute;ry    (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. G&eacute;ry, 1977). G&eacute;ry also recognized the polyphyletic    nature of this classification, and that this systematic scheme failed to reflect    the phylogeny (G&eacute;ry, 1972). In this pre-cladistic systematic classification,    most genera of the Characidae, especially those with "generalized" morphology,    were included in the subfamily Tetragonopterinae. The remaining genera were    distributed across several subfamilies defined by the presence of somewhat arbitrarily    chosen characters. G&eacute;ry (1977), following the general classification    of Eigenmann recognized the subfamilies (number of genera in parentheses) Agoniatinae    (1), Rhaphiodontinae (2), Characinae (14), Bryconinae (6), Clupeacharacinae    (1), Paragoniatinae (6), Aphyocharacinae (1), Glandulocaudinae 
(18), Stethaprioninae    (3), Tetragonopterinae (49), Rhoadsiinae (2) and Cheirodontinae (13 genera <i>sensu    stricto</i> and 36 <i>sensu lato</i>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The first genus    of the Characidae explicitly diagnosed by shared presumably apomorphic features    was <i>Bramocharax</i> Gill (Rosen, 1972). Later, Vari (1977) presented evidence    based on shared presumably derived features, supporting the monophyly of the    subfamily Iguanodectinae. Weitzman &amp; Fink (1983) explicitly explained the    problems related with some generic characters used for the systematic schemes    of Eigenmann and G&eacute;ry, and the needing of a classification reflecting    the phylogeny of the Characidae. A series of contributions proposing or corroborating    the monophyly of some genera and subfamilies of the Characidae were published    subsequently &#91;Serrasalminae (Machado-Allison, 1983), Stethaprioninae (Reis,    1989), Glandulocaudinae (Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1985; Weitzman &amp; Menezes,    1998), Cheirodontinae (Malabarba, 1998a) and <i>Paracheirodon</i> G&eacute;ry    (Weitzman &amp; 
Fink, 1983), <i>Charax</i> Scopoli (Lucena, 1987), <i>Jupiaba</i>    Zanata (Zanata, 1997), <i>Roestes</i> G&uuml;nther and <i>Gilbertolus</i> Eigenmann    (Lucena &amp; Menezes, 1998), <i>Spintherobolus</i> Eigenmann (Weitzman &amp;    Malabarba, 1999), <i>Creagrutus</i> G&uuml;nther and <i>Piabina</i> Reinhardt    (Vari &amp; Harold, 1998, 2001), <i>Deuterodon</i> Eigenmann (Lucena &amp; Lucena,    2002), <i>Cyanocharax</i> Malabarba &amp; Weitzman (Malabarba &amp; Weitzman,    2003), <i>Attonitus</i> Vari &amp; Ortega (Vari &amp; Ortega, 2000), and <i>Bryconadenos</i>    Weitzman, Menezes, Evers &amp; Burns (Weitzman <i>et al</i>., 2005)&#93;. Most    of these papers were focused on particular groups of the Characidae, without    enough exploration of their relationships with the remaining Characidae. Malabarba    (1998a) restricted the subfamily Cheirodontinae to a subset of the genera recognized    in this subfamily by G&eacute;ry (1977), leaving 33 genera as <i>incertae 
sedis</i>.    Later, Reis (2003a) restricted the Tetragonopterinae to its type genus <i>Tetragonopterus</i>    Cuvier, leaving many genera as <i>incertae sedis</i> within the Characidae.    Lima <i>et al</i>. (2003) classified also several genera previously included    in the subfamilies Bryconinae, Characinae, Cheirodontinae, and Paragoniatinae    (G&eacute;ry, 1977) as <i>incertae sedis</i> within the Characidae. The subfamilies    and <i>incertae sedis</i> genera recognized in the last revision of the Characidae    are as follows (number of genera in each group in parentheses): <i>incertae    sedis</i> (88) (Lima <i>et al</i>., 2003), Agoniatinae (1) (Lima &amp; Zanata,    2003), Clupeacharacinae (1) (Lima, 2003a), Iguanodectinae (2) (Moreira, 2003),    Bryconinae (3) (Lima, 2003b), Serrasalminae (15) (J&eacute;gu, 2003), Aphyocharacinae    (1) (Lima, 2003c), Characinae (12) (Lucena &amp; Menezes, 2003), Stethaprioninae    (4) (Reis, 2003a), Tetragonopterinae (1) (Reis, 2003b), 
Rhoadsiinae (3) (Cardoso,    2003a), Cheirodontinae (15) (Malabarba, 2003), and Glandulocaudinae (19) (Weitzman,    2003). The subfamily Rhaphiodontinae (<i>sensu</i> G&eacute;ry, 1977) was included    into the Cynodontidae (Lucena &amp; Menezes, 1998; Toledo-Piza, 2003), and all    the genera assigned to the Paragoniatinae by G&eacute;ry (1977) were included    in the <i>incertae sedis-</i>group (Lima <i>et al</i>., 2003). The Acestrorhynchidae    was considered as a separate family (Lucena &amp; Menezes, 1998, 2003).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Malabarba &amp;    Weitzman (2003) described <i>Cyanocharax</i> and proposed the monophyly of a    group of genera (their clade A) including all members of Glandulocaudinae plus    several <i>incertae sedis</i> genera. Later the glandulocaudin <i>Lophiobrycon</i>    Castro, Ribeiro, Benine &amp; Melo (Castro <i>et al</i>., 2003), and the <i>incertae    sedis</i> genera <i>Myxiops</i> Zanata &amp; Akama (Zanata &amp; Akama, 2004),    <i>Nantis</i> Mirande, Aguilera &amp; Azpelicueta (Mirande <i>et al</i>., 2004,    2006a), <i>Dectobrycon</i> Zarske &amp; G&eacute;ry (Zarske &amp; G&eacute;ry,    2006), and <i>Phallobrycon</i> Menezes, Ferreira &amp; Netto-Ferreira (Menezes    <i>et al</i>., 2009) were described. The phylogeny of Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>.    (2005) implicitly raised the Serrasalminae to the family level. Weitzman <i>et    al</i>. (2005) described the <i>incertae sedis</i> genus <i>Bryconadenos</i>    and 
restricted the Glandulocaudinae to <i>Glandulocauda</i> Eigenmann, <i>Lophiobrycon</i>    and <i>Mimagoniates</i> Regan, shifting the remaining genera previously in the    Glandulocaudinae to the subfamily Stevardiinae. Quevedo (2006) phylogenetically    diagnosed the subfamily Paragoniatinae with a composition very similar to that    proposed by G&eacute;ry (1977) (the results of this and other recently completed    theses are not discussed, pending their eventual publications).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">There is no consensus    about the phylogenetic relationships among subfamilies of the Characidae. Some    phylogenetic analyses of different scope were performed, both from morphological    and molecular data. The phylogenies of Uj (1990), Buckup (1991, 1998) and Lucena    (1993) were based on morphological data. Uj (1990) did not perform a cladistic    analysis; he just mapped character transformations on a "phylogenetic" tree    obtained without specific criteria. This unpublished thesis, however, was an    advance on compared morphological knowledge of the Characidae. The doctoral    theses of Buckup (1991) and Lucena (1993) were the first cladistic analyses    of the Characidae, with the main phylogenetic results of Buckup published later    (Buckup, 1998). These analyses shared a high proportion of characters, but they    had different objectives and, consequently, different taxon sampling. Most of    the characters 
in those theses were analyzed by Mirande (2008, 2009) and discussed    in the present paper. As the aim of Buckup (1991, 1998) was to obtain a hypothesis    of relationships of the members of the Crenuchidae, he included only six genera    of the Characidae. Given that the main objective of Lucena (1993) was to recover    the phylogenetic relationships of the Characidae, the taxon sampling reflected    the morphological diversity of the family, in a scope more similar to that of    Mirande (2008, 2009). Most of the conclusions of Buckup (1991, 1998) and Lucena    (1993) are included on the last classification of the Neotropical members of    the Characiformes (Reis <i>et al</i>., 2003). Subsequently, several unpublished    theses focused on phylogenies of specific groups within the Characidae (Moreira,    2002; Bertaco, 2003; Cardoso, 2003b; Serra, 2003; Benine, 2004; B&uuml;hrnheim,    2006; Lima, 2006; Quevedo, 2006; Bertaco, 2008). Some of the characters used    on these theses 
were also analyzed by Mirande (2008, 2009).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Molecular phylogenies    of the Characiformes were proposed by Ort&iacute; &amp; Meyer (1997), Hubert    <i>et al</i>. (2005), and Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>. (2005). As in the cited    morphological studies, the objectives of these analyses differed, and this affected    the taxon and gene samplings and the methodologies used. Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>.    (2005) published the most comprehensive molecular phylogeny of the Characiformes,    including 27 taxa of the Characidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Mirande (2009)    proposed the monophyly and a classification of the Characidae based on a phylogenetic    analysis. Most <i>incertae sedis</i> genera were assigned to a subfamily or    subfamilial-level clade, at least tentatively. The paper of Mirande (2009) was,    however, mainly concerned with analytical issues, leaving most morphological    descriptions and discussions, and comments on the taxonomic implications or    the phylogeny for the present contribution. In the present study some characters    were redefined or added from Mirande (2009) and the results herein obtained    slightly differ to those of that paper.</font></p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="3"><b>Material and    Methods</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Osteological    preparations</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Osteological preparations    were made following Taylor &amp; van Dyke (1985) on one to five specimens of    each species included in the analysis, according to their availability and observed    intraspecific variability. Some characters involving musculature and soft tissues    were observed with the aid of non-permanent Methylene Blue staining. A total    of 23 species of 14 characiform families and one cypriniform form the outgroup,    while 137 species of the Characidae form the ingroup of this study. <a href="#f1">Figures    1-124</a> illustrate most characters and character-states. Most figures are    stacks of pictures at different focal depth, constructed with CombineZM software    (Hadley, 2006), running under Linux through Wine software.</font></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p align="center"><img src="/img/revistas/ni/v8n3/01f123.jpg"></p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p><a name="f124"></a></p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p align="center"><img src="/img/revistas/ni/v8n3/01f124.jpg"></p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Taxon sampling</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The taxonomic nomenclature    of the Characoidea used in the present paper follows Mirande (2009), while that    of remaining Characiformes follows Buckup (1998). Terminal taxa were included    in the data matrix at species-level. The only exceptions are the root, and the    superfamily Citharinoidei, which actually are compound taxa based primarily    on <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> (Bleeker) and <i>Distichodus maculatus</i> Boulenger    but allowing for documented variations within the Cyprinidae and Citharinoidei,    respectively. Taxon sampling was done considering the inclusion of members of    recognizedly monophyletic groups, representatives of the morphological variation    within the family, members of the <i>incertae sedis</i> genera, species with    special taxonomic interest (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. type species of the most diverse    genera), and an outgroup including members of most families in the Characiformes.    
The taxon sampling focused in the inclusion of as many species as possible,    with studies of intraspecific variations beyond the scope of this paper.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The analyses are    rooted on the compound terminal taxon based on <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> (Cypriniformes,    Cyprinidae). Cases in which the states observed in this species differed from    those considered as plesiomorphic for Cypriniformes (Howes, 1978, 1979, 1980;    Vari, 1979; Fink &amp; Fink, 1981, 1996) were coded as polymorphic. Although    there is enough consensus on the position of the characiform families Citharinidae    and Distichodontidae (Citharinoidei) as the sister group of the remaining Characiformes    (Characoidei) (Vari, 1979; Fink &amp; Fink, 1981, 1996, Buckup, 1991, 1998;    Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>., 2005), a root external to the Characiformes was used    to test also such hypothesis.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">A rather broad    sampling of families related to the Characidae was carried out, to correctly    optimize the characters and to test as rigorously as possible the monophyly    of the Characidae. This test was improved analyzing some members of the families    morphologically closer to Characidae, or included historically in this family,    such as the Alestidae, Gasteropelecidae, and Serrasalmidae (Weitzman, 1954;    G&eacute;ry, 1977; Machado-Allison, 1983).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The ingroup is    composed of members of all the subfamilies recognized in Reis <i>et al</i>.    (2003) excepting the monotypic Clupeacharacinae; however, most of the effort    was oriented towards sampling the <i>incertae sedis</i> genera which represented    approximately two-thirds of the diversity of the Characidae, prior to Mirande    (2009). The taxon termed "undescribed n. gen. and sp." by Mirande (2009) proved    to be an undescribed species of <i>Oligosarcus</i> G&uuml;nther. Thus, in this    paper this species is named as <i>Oligosarcus</i> sp. leaving its description    and discussion of relationships to be published elsewhere. The species named    as <i>Bryconamericus beta</i> Eigenmann by Mirande (2009) is referred to as    <i>B</i>. <i>alpha</i> Eigenmann in this paper, following the synonymy proposed    by Rom&aacute;n-Valencia (2003). The species named as <i>Roeboides bonariensis</i>    (Steindachner) and 
<i>R</i>. <i>paranensis</i> by Mirande (2009) are referred    to as <i>R</i>. <i>microlepis</i> (Reinhardt) and <i>R</i>. <i>descalvadensis</i>    Fowler, following the synonymies proposed by Lucena (2003, 2007). Finally, the    specimens referred to as <i>Hemigrammus</i> cf. <i>rhodostomus</i> Ahl by Mirande    (2009) proved to be <i>H</i>. <i>bleheri</i> G&eacute;ry &amp; Mahnert. The    list of examined material is shown in the <a href="#a1">Appendix 1</a>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">All species (with    the exception of <i>Brycon meeki</i> Eigenmann &amp; Hildebrand that was coded    following Weitzman, 1962) were observed by the author. The coding of each species    was made upon all its available information. If a particular state was observed    in a species, but published data indicate the alternative condition in that    species, such species were coded as polymorphic. Meristic characters (<i>e</i>.    <i>g</i>. anal-fin rays counts) were coded according to the ranges cited in    the literature.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Nomenclature    and Abbreviations</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Abbreviations mentioned    on the list of examined material are as following: AI (Asociaci&oacute;n Ictiol&oacute;gica,    La Plata), ANSP (Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia), CI-FML (Colecci&oacute;n    Ictiol&oacute;gica de la Fundaci&oacute;n Miguel Lillo, Tucum&aacute;n), LACMNH    (Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History), MCNi (Colecci&oacute;n ictiol&oacute;gica    del Museo de Ciencias Naturales, Salta), MCP (Museu de Ci&ecirc;ncias e Tecnologia    da Pontif&iacute;cia Universidade Cat&oacute;lica do Rio Grande do Sul, Porto    Alegre), MHNG (Mus&eacute;um d'histoire naturelle, Gen&egrave;ve), MNHN (Mus&eacute;um    national d'histoire naturelle, Paris), and MZUSP (Museu de Zoologia da Universidade    de S&atilde;o Paulo).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Osteological nomenclature    follows Weitzman (1962) with the modifications adopted by Zanata &amp; Vari    (2005), which are based principally on Nelson (1969), Patterson (1975), and    Fink &amp; Fink (1981, 1996). Abbreviations in character definitions are references    to the following papers: EI (Eigenmann, 1917), FF (Fink &amp; Fink, 1981, 1996),    AM (Machado-Allison, 1983), UJ (Uj, 1990), VA (Vari, 1995), BU (Buckup, 1998),    LU (Lucena, 1993), LC (Lucena, 1998), MA (Malabarba, 1998a), WM (Weitzman &amp;    Menezes, 1998), LM (Lucena &amp; Menezes, 1998), CM (Malabarba, 1998b), TP (Toledo-Piza,    2000), VH (Vari &amp; Harold, 2001), MO (Moreira, 2002), VB (Bertaco, 2003),    CA (Cardoso, 2003b), SE (Serra, 2003), BE (Benine, 2004), ZV (Zanata &amp; Vari,    2005), B&Uuml; (B&uuml;hrnheim, 2006), LI (Lima, 2006), QU (Quevedo, 2006),    PZ (Toledo-Piza, 2007), MW(Menezes &amp; Weitzman, 2009). The number 
following    these abbreviations refers to the character number as used on the cited analysis;    those cases in which the character states were modified from the cited paper    are indicated with a "m", and those instances where the ordering of states were    inverted are indicated with an "i". Some numbers of the list of characters of    Malabarba (1998b) do not correspond with those of the data matrix; instead their    correspondence was deduced from the information given in the text. In these    cases the number in parentheses corresponds to the one deduced to have each    particular character in the data matrix.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The principal objective    of the proposed taxonomic nomenclature is to classify members of the Characidae    in monophyletic units. The proposed nomenclature is as conservative as possible    concerning to the creation of new names for taxonomic groupings, with all the    names used in the recent literature which are compatible with the obtained phylogeny    retained other than in cases when their preservation necessitates the creation    of a number of new taxa. The new suprageneric names are rooted on the first    described genus included within the clade. An evaluation of the monophyly and    phylogeny of all genera is beyond the scope of this paper; therefore, new generic    names are not proposed nor are species reassigned between genera.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Cladistic methodology</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Additive characters    were recoded as binaries and are represented by two or more character numbers;    this improve greatly the efficiency of searches under self-weighting optimization    (Goloboff, 1997) in terms of time and optimality. Binary coding of the additive    characters has no effects on the results obtained under implied weighting and    relatively small influence to the results under self-weighted optimization (see    Mirande, 2009 for details). Conditions that resulted as intermediate between    the defined states were coded as polymorphisms; although both situations are    conceptually different, it was preferred over coding them as inapplicable or    missing entries. Analyses were performed by parsimony, following the methods    described by Hennig (1966) and developed by Farris (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. 1969,    1970, 1983) among others. Analyses under implied weighting (Goloboff, 1993)    and self-weighting 
optimization (Goloboff, 1997) were performed with TNT software    (Goloboff <i>et al</i>., 2003a, 2008). Details of this analysis were described    elsewhere (Mirande, 2008, 2009), and they are not treated here. In this analysis    the number of explored conditions were almost duplicated from Mirande (2009).    In the present study, 21 values of k were used under each of the weighting schemes    (<i>vs</i>. 11 in Mirande, 2009). Measures of stability and support are expressed    in the discussion of each node. Stability measures consider all the range of    explored parameters (see Mirande, 2009), while support measures were calculated    for k = 13, under implied weighting. Those measures are, respectively, GC values    as stability measures, relative frequencies, GC values as support measures (Goloboff    <i>et al</i>., 2003b), and relative Bremer support (Bremer, 1994; Goloboff &amp;    Farris, 2001). Cases in which the support measures are (artificially) negative    are indicated 
with a dash (-), whereas stability measures are indicated as negative.</font></p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="3"><b>Results and    Discussion</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Description    of phylogenetic characters</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most analyzed characters    are osteological (90%), while the remaining ones come from coloration, external    features and reproductive biology. Of these, 135 were not described previously    in the literature (published or not), and represent new definitions. Some characters    about bony hooks on fins of adult males were redefined from Mirande (2009).    The characters proposed by Menezes &amp; Weitzman (2009) to be evidence for    the monophyly of their Glandulocaudinae and Stevardiinae are herein analyzed    together with the characters from Mirande (2009). Also, several missing entries    in the analysis of Mirande (2009) were coded for this study. With that modifications,    the data matrix herein analyzed has 365 characters and is provided as <a href="/img/revistas/ni/v8n3/01a02.gif">Appendix    2</a>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Neurocranium</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Epiphyseal bar:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1. Posterior    laminar expansion of epiphyseal bar: (0) absent; (1) present. (LU13i, LC4).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The frontals articulate    each other via the epiphyseal bar, which transversely crosses the medial cranial    fontanel. In most examined species, the epiphyseal bar is slender and approximately    cylindrical in cross-section (state 0; <a href="#f1">Fig. 1</a>), while a group    of species has a laminar projection on the posterior margin of the epiphyseal    bar, making it proportionally broader in dorsal view (state 1; <a href="#f2">Fig.    2</a>). Lucena (1993, 1998) coded the presence of this expansion in several    characins and <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i> Agassiz. A small laminar expansion    was also observed in examined specimens of <i>Charax stenopterus</i> (Cope)    and <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i> (Valenciennes). Since Lucena (1998) noted the    absence of such an expansion in these species, they are coded as polymorphic.    <i>Serrasalmus maculatus</i> Kner has a broad epiphyseal bar that apparently    lacks the 
laminar expansion. This condition is considered to be different from    the states herein defined for this character, and this character is coded as    inapplicable to <i>S</i>. <i>maculatus</i>. This character is also considered    as inapplicable to the species in which the fontanel is completely covered by    the frontals.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Basioccipital:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2. Ventral longitudinal    lamellae of basioccipital: (0) falling short of posterior border of basioccipital;    (1) reaching posterior border of cranium. (PZ24).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The prootic and    basioccipital have two bilateral lamellae articulating with two longitudinal    dorsal processes of the parasphenoid, forming the limits of the posterior myodome    where part of the extrinsic musculature of the eye attaches, as described by    Weitzman (1962: 24). In most examined members of the Characidae, these lamellae    are restricted to the area of contact between the basioccipital and parasphenoid,    and the surface of the basioccipital lacks any bilateral lamellae or ridges    posterior to that region (state 0; <a href="#f3">Fig. 3</a>). In most members    of the outgroup and some of the Characidae these lamellae extend posteriorly    to the parasphenoid in the region ventral to the lagenar capsules and reach    the posterior margin of the cranium (state 1; <a href="#f4">Fig. 4</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Lagenar capsule:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3. Ventral projection    of lagenar capsule: (0) not extending ventrally to horizontal through articulation    between basioccipital and parasphenoid; (1) extending ventrally to articulation    between basioccipital and parasphenoid. (UJ5m, ZV47m, PZ25m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The extension of    the lagenar capsules lateral to the cranial condyle is a synapomorphy of the    Characiformes according to Fink &amp; Fink (1981) and was observed in all the    characiforms herein examined. The ventral extension of these capsules, in contrast,    is variable among the examined species. In most species of the outgroup, the    lagenar capsules do not extend ventrally to the articulation between the basioccipital    and parasphenoid (state 0; <a href="#f5">Fig. 5</a>), while in most species    of the Characidae and some members of the outgroup these capsules are conspicuously    extended, continuing ventrally beyond the area of articulation of those bones    (state 1; <a href="#f6">Figs. 6</a> and <a href="#f7">7</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>4. Epioccipital    bridge over posttemporal fossa: (0) absent; (1) present. (B&Uuml;7i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The posttemporal    fossa in Characiformes is longitudinally crossed by the epioccipital bridge    (state 1; <a href="#f6">Fig. 6</a>) except in some miniature species of the    Characidae and Crenuchidae (state 0; Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1983: <a href="#f6">figs.    6</a>, <a href="#f8">8</a>, <a href="#f15">15</a>, and <a href="#f17">17</a>).    Although this character was considered to be related with miniaturization, its    phylogenetic value has to be tested. The absence of an epioccipital bridge was    herein observed only in <i>Hasemania nana</i> (L&uuml;tken) and <i>Pyrrhulina    australis</i> Eigenmann &amp; Kennedy. This character, however, is variable    in the two examined specimens of the latter species, which is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>5. Form of epioccipital    bridge: (0) cylindrical or vertically expanded in transverse section; (1) depressed    in its middle region.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The epioccipital    bridge over the posttemporal fossa is usually cylindrical or slightly expanded    dorsally (state 0; <a href="#f6">Fig. 6</a>). In the studied specimens of <i>Bramocharax    bransfordii</i> Gill, <i>Oligosarcus bolivianus</i> (Fowler), <i>O</i>. cf.    <i>jenynsii</i> (G&uuml;nther), and <i>O</i>. sp., the middle region of this    bridge is dorsoventrally depressed (state 1; <a href="#f8">Fig. 8</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>6. Anterior    articulation of epioccipital bridge: (0) with both parietal and pterotic; (1)    only with parietal.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the anterior region of the epioccipital bridge articulates with the    parietal and pterotic (state 0; <a href="#f6">Fig. 6</a>). In <i>Grundulus cochae</i>    (Humboldt) and <i>Paracheirodon axelrodi</i> (Schultz), the epioccipital bridge    is displaced dorsally and its anterior portion articulates only with the parietal    (state 1; Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1983: <a href="#f4">figs. 4</a>, <a href="#f5">5</a>,    and <a href="#f7">7</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>7. Posteriorly-oriented    epioccipital spine: (0) present; (1) absent. (LU21m, LC3i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    lack projections on the posterior surface of the epioccipital (state 1; <a href="#f5">Fig.    5</a>). A posterior projection of the epioccipital aligned with the epioccipital    bridge that serves as a point of attachment of the epaxial musculature was observed    in some species (state 0; <a href="#f7">Fig. 7</a>). In <i>Brycon orbignyanus</i>    (Valenciennes) and <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i> (Cuvier), the posterior tip    of this process is rounded, differing from most species with state 0, in which    it is pointed; these species are coded with state 0 regardless this difference.    Weitzman (1962: <a href="#f3">fig. 3</a>) illustrated a small lobe in <i>Brycon    meeki</i>, similar to that herein observed in <i>B</i>. <i>falcatus</i> M&uuml;ller    &amp; Troschel, <i>B</i>. <i>pesu</i> M&uuml;ller &amp; Troschel, <i>Bryconexodon    juruenae</i> G&eacute;ry, <i>Cynopotamus argenteus</i> 
(Valenciennes), <i>Hemibrycon    dariensis</i> Meek &amp; Hildebrand, <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i> (Perugia) and    <i>Moenkhausia xinguensis</i> (Steindachner). These species are coded as polymorphic.    Contrary to the observations of Lucena (1993), in the examined species of <i>Aphyocharax</i>    G&uuml;nther this process is absent, and they are coded as state 1. <i>Puntius    tetrazona</i>, as in all other Cypriniformes, lacks a posttemporal fossa, and    the form of the epioccipital differs slightly. This character was coded as inapplicable    to the root of this analysis. In <i>Carnegiella strigata</i> (G&uuml;nther)    and <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i> (Kner), the epineurals extend anteriorly    to the cranium, reaching a position occupied by this spine when present. Indeed,    the anteriormost epineurals are fused with the epioccipital. This character    is also coded as inapplicable to these species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>8. Ventromedial    opening of posttemporal fossa: (0) absent; (1) present. (UJ24, BU19, LU20, VH45m,    TP23, BE17, ZV43m, LI35).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have only two openings of the posttemporal fossa situated posterolateral in    the cranium, with these separated by the epioccipital bridge (state 0). A third    opening was described in the Citharinidae and Distichodontidae by Vari (1979).    This opening was later referred as ventromedial opening of the posttemporal    fossa by Buckup (1991, 1998) and Lucena (1993). This opening is situated posteriorly    on the cranium, and is margined by the epioccipital and exoccipital or completely    contained by the epioccipital (state 1; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f10">fig.    10</a>). The ventromedial opening of the posttemporal fossa was observed by    Buckup (1998) and Lucena (1993) in members of the Alestidae, Crenuchidae, Curimatidae,    Cynodontidae, Hemiodontidae, and Parodontidae. Vari &amp; Harold (2001) and    Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) defined the different positions of this opening as    
two separate states, which is treated in the following character. Benine (2004)    cited the presence of this opening in <i>Moenkhausia barbouri</i> Eigenmann,    <i>M</i>. <i>dichroura</i> (Kner), and <i>M</i>. <i>intermedia</i> Eigenmann;    however, this opening is absent in the examined species of <i>Moenkhausia</i>    Eigenmann, and they are herein coded as state 0. According to Lucena (1993)    this opening is present in <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i> Menezes, although    in the examined specimen it is absent, and the species is consequently coded    as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>9. Position    of ventromedial opening of posttemporal fossa: (0) between epioccipital and    exoccipital; (1) bordered entirely by epioccipital. (ZV43m, VH45m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">As previously mentioned,    the ventrolateral opening of the posttemporal fossa is limited by the epioccipital    and exoccipital in some species (state 0; Vari, 1979: <a href="#f15">fig. 15</a>)    while it is completely contained within the epioccipital in others (state 1;    Roberts, 1974: <a href="#f5">figs. 5</a> and <a href="#f59">59</a>; Zanata &amp;    Vari, 2005: <a href="#f10">fig. 10</a>). This opening is completely enclosed    by the epioccipital in some species of <i>Creagrutus</i> (Vari &amp; Harold,    2001) and most members of the Alestidae (except <i>Chalceus</i> Cuvier, among    taxa examined here), Curimatidae, Hemiodontidae, and Parodontidae (Roberts,    1974; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005). A third opening partially margined by the exoccipital    was cited for members of the Citharinidae, Crenuchidae, Cynodontidae, and Distichodontidae    (Vari, 1979; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005). Species in which this opening 
is absent    are coded as inapplicable to this character.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Sphenotic:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>10. Length of    sphenotic spine: (0) not extending ventrally to articulation between sphenotic    and hyomandibula; (1) extending ventrally to articulation between sphenotic    and hyomandibula. (VB28m, VB29m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The sphenotic spine    extends ventrally to the fossa for the <i>dilator operculi</i>, being bordered    posteriorly by that muscle and partially by the <i>levator arcus palatini</i>.    The ventral development of this spine is variable among the examined species.    In some species it falls short of the ventral margin of main body of the sphenotic    (state 0), whereas in other species this spine is longer, anteriorly bordering    the <i>levator arcus palatini</i> and ventrally extending past the region of    articulation of the sphenotic with the hyomandibula (state 1; <a href="#f9">Fig.    9</a>). This character was only coded with states 0 or 1 in the species in which    the sphenotic spine is clearly either not reaching or surpassing the articulation    with the hyomandibula, respectively. In the examined specimens of <i>Distichodus    maculatus</i>, <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i>, <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i>    
(Meek), <i>Mimagoniates rheocharis</i> Menezes &amp; Weitzman, <i>Bryconamericus    alpha</i>, <i>Cyanocharax alburnus</i> (Hensel), <i>Hemibrycon dariensis</i>,    <i>Knodus breviceps</i> Eigenmann, <i>Odontostoechus lethostigmus</i> Gomes,    <i>Aphyocharacidium bolivianum</i> G&eacute;ry, <i>Aulixidens eugeniae</i> B&ouml;hlke,    <i>Axelrodia lindeae</i> G&eacute;ry, <i>Exodon paradoxus</i> M&uuml;ller &amp;    Troschel, <i>Hemigrammus bleheri</i>, <i>Hollandichthys multifasciatus</i> Eigenmann    &amp; Norris, <i>Nematobrycon palmeri</i> Eigenmann, <i>Oligosarcus bolivianus</i>,    <i>Parecbasis cyclolepis</i> Eigenmann, <i>Probolodus heterostomus</i> Eigenmann,    and <i>Thayeria obliqua</i> Eigenmann, the sphenotic spine is hardly reaching    the articulation between this bone with the hyomandibula, and they coded as    polymorphic. In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> this spine reaches the ventral limit    of the sphenotic, but it is variable in the Cypriniformes (Howes, 1978) and    
consequently the root of this analysis is also coded as polymorphic. In <i>Astyanax    lineatus</i> (Perugia) this character is apparently variable during the growth.    Examined juvenile specimens have state 1, while the adults have state 0, and    this species is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>11. Position    of sphenotic spine relative to hyomandibula: (0) rather aligned with anterior    margin of hyomandibula; (1) displaced anteriorly relative to anterior margin    of hyomandibula.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the sphenotic spine is aligned or slightly anterior to the anterior    margin of the hyomandibula (state 0; <a href="#f9">Fig. 9</a>), while in a group    of species, such spine is anterior to the margin of the hyomandibula (state    1; <a href="#f10">Fig. 10</a>). <i>Bryconexodon juruenae</i> and <i>Hollandichthys    multifasciatus</i> have intermediate states that are coded as polymorphisms.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>12. Position    of sphenotic spine relative to the orbit: (0) bordering orbit posteriorly and    aligned with anterior border of fourth and fifth infraorbitals; (1) distinctly    posterior to orbital margin.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">As stated in the    previous character, the sphenotic spine is usually aligned with the anterior    margin of the hyomandibula, thereby forming the posterior margin of the orbit    (state 0). In a group of species the sphenotic spine is situated posterior to    the anterior margin of the fourth and fifth infraorbitals and distant from the    posterior margin of the orbit (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>13. Temporal    fossa: (0) well developed; (1) absent or much reduced. (VH41, LI27).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the entire anterior margin of the pterotic articulates with the sphenotic,    without an intervening space between these bones, or only a small pore (state    1; <a href="#f6">Figs. 6</a> and <a href="#f11">11</a>). The temporal fossa    is an opening limited anteriorly by the sphenotic and posteriorly by the pterotic,    and is present in some examined species (state 0; Weitzman, 1962: <a href="#f3">fig.    3</a>). Vari &amp; Harold (2001) reported the presence of this fossa in <i>Piabina    argentea</i> Reinhardt and several species of <i>Creagrutus</i> not analyzed    herein. Although Lima (2006) mentioned its absence in <i>Brycon falcatus</i>,    among other species of the genus, this fossa is present in the examined specimen    of this species, and is coded as polymorphic. In the examined specimens of <i>Astyanax    troya</i> Azpelicueta, Casciotta &amp; Almir&oacute;n and <i>Piabina 
argentea</i>,    this fossa has a size intermediate to the defined character states, and these    species are coded as polymorphic for this character. In the examined specimens    of <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i> the presence of this fossa is variable and this    species is also coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Lateral ethmoid:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>14. Form of    anterior process of lateral ethmoid: (0) broad in ventral view, contacting proximal    region of vomer in its entire length; (1) slender and separated from vomer.    (CM10m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the lateral ethmoid has an anterior process oriented in the direction    of the vomer. In many species of the outgroup and some examined members of the    Characidae, this process is broad in ventral view and contacts the entire length    of the parasphenoid and vomer in the region anterior to the main body of the    lateral ethmoid (state 0). In most members of the ingroup this process is, in    contrast, comparatively more slender and, as a consequence, leaves a broad space    between the lateral ethmoid process and the lateral margin of the posterior    portion of the vomer (state 1; <a href="#f12">Fig. 12</a>). In <i>Gymnocharacinus    bergii</i> Steindachner the process is much reduced, and this character is coded    as inapplicable. In <i>Aulixidens eugeniae</i> and <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i>    Castro this process is displaced medially, and it contacts the parasphenoid    and vomer in 
its entire length. Although the origin of this condition seems    to be different, resulting in a contact due to a different mechanism (medial    displacement, rather than broadening of the process), these species are tentatively    coded with state 0.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>15. Lateral    opening between ventral diverging lamellae of mesethmoid and anterior process    of lateral ethmoid: (0) broad; (1) small, ovate and partially occluded by diverging    lamellae of mesethmoid and anterior process of lateral ethmoid. (LU2).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anterior process    of the lateral ethmoid is situated approximately in the same plane as the corresponding    diverging lamella of the mesethmoid (Weitzman, 1962) leaving, in most cases,    a broad space between these structures, which is evident in lateral view (state    0; <a href="#f13">Fig. 13</a>). In a few examined species, the diverging lamellae    are much developed ventrally and both the vomer and the anterior process of    the lateral ethmoid are expanded dorsally, with both articulating broadly with    the mesethmoid. As a result the space delimited by these structures has an ovate    shape and is much reduced compared with state 0 (state 1; <a href="#f14">Fig.    14</a>). This character is coded as inapplicable in species lacking ventral    lamellae of the mesethmoid.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>16. Dorsal margin    of lateral ethmoids: (0) aligned; (1) situated obliquely in dorsal view, converging    in an anteriorly directed angle.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dorsal margin    of lateral ethmoids articulate with the frontals and, usually, with the ventral    diverging lamellae of the mesethmoid. The medial region of the lateral ethmoids    articulate with the roof of the mesethmoid through a cartilage. In most examined    species the medial portion of the lateral ethmoids form a rather straight line    from dorsal view, with its margin visible through the frontals and/or mesethmoid    (state 0; <a href="#f15">Figs. 15</a> and <a href="#f16">16</a>). In a relatively    small group of species the medial portions of the lateral ethmoids meet each    other along an anterior angle (state 1; <a href="#f17">Figs. 17</a> and <a href="#f18">18</a>).    Apparently such configuration of the lateral ethmoids allows an anterior displacement    of the extrinsic musculature of the eye, which inserts in the anterior myodome.    <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i> and <i>Prodontocharax 
melanotus</i> Pearson have    intermediate situations that are coded as polymorphic for this character. In    <i>Inpaichthys kerri</i> G&eacute;ry &amp; Junk and <i>Mimagoniates rheocharis</i>    the medial portion of the lateral ethmoid is much reduced and this character    is coded as inapplicable.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>17. Articulation    between medial region of lateral ethmoid and frontal or mesethmoid: (0) absent,    lateral ethmoid articulated principally with ventral diverging lamellae of mesethmoid;    (1) extensive articulation of entire lateral ethmoid dorsal margin.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dorsal margin    of the lateral ethmoid is synchondrally articulated with the ventral surface    of the the lateral portion of the frontal, contacting also the orbital lamella    of the frontal and the ventral diverging lamellae of the mesethmoid, when present.    In most examined species the region of the lateral ethmoid situated just medial    to the orbital lamella of the frontal does not articulates with the mesethmoid    or the frontal (state 0; <a href="#f19">Fig. 19</a>). In these species the variably    broad space between the lateral ethmoid and the ventral surface of the frontal    and mesethmoid is occupied by the ethmoid cartilage (Weitzman, 1962). Instead,    in some species the entire dorsal margin of the lateral ethmoid articulates    synchondrally with the frontal and/or mesethmoid, depending on the posterior    extent of the mesethmoid under the frontal (state 1; <a href="#f18">Fig. 18</a>).    The 
species with state 1 have reduced ventral diverging lamellae of the mesethmoid;    however, there are species in which these lamellae are much reduced, as some    Cheirodontinae, with state 0 of this character.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Exoccipital:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>18. Subtemporal    fossa: (0) medially extended to middle exoccipital; (1) restricted to pterotic    and prootic.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The subtemporal    fossa is formed by an usually shallow depression of the pterotic and is limited    posteromedially by the intercalar. In most examined species the intercalar is    restricted to the region of articulation of the exoccipital and pterotic, and    the subtemporal fossa is consequently excluded from the exoccipital (state 1;    <a href="#f3">Fig. 3</a>). In some species the intercalar is more medially situated    and articulates principally with the exoccipital. In these cases the subtemporal    fossa is partially formed by the exoccipital (state 0; <a href="#f20">Fig. 20</a>).    According to Miquelarena &amp; Ar&aacute;mburu (1983) the intercalar articulates    solely with the exoccipital in <i>Gymnocharacinus bergii</i>, corresponding    with state 0; however, the position of this bone varies among the examined specimens,    and this species is coded as polymorphic. In the examined specimens of 
<i>Hasemania    nana</i> the intercalar is situated entirely on the pterotic; although this    condition is not exactly that described in the state 1, this species is coded    with such state given that the subtemporal fossa is also excluded from the exoccipital.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>19. Ascending    process on posterodorsal angle of exoccipital directed to neural complex of    Weberian apparatus: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The posterior margin    of the exoccipital in almost all the examined species is smoothly rounded in    the area situated just anterior to the neural complex of Weberian apparatus    (state 0). The presence of a process on the exoccipital oriented to the neural    complex (state 1; Uj, 1990: <a href="#f20">fig. 20d</a>) was considered by Uj    (1990) as a synapomorphy of his Aphyocharacidae (<i>Aphyocharax</i> + <i>Prionobrama</i>    Fowler). This state was observed only in <i>Aphyocharax anisitsi</i> Eigenmann    &amp; Kennedy and this character is uninformative, although possibly a synapomorphy    of some group within <i>Aphyocharax.</i></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Frontal:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>20. Anterior    extension of frontal: (0) reaching posterior margin of nasal opening; (1) extending    between nasals and reaching middle length of nasal opening.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The frontal reaches    only to the posterior margin of the nasal opening in most examined species (state    0; <a href="#f21">Fig. 21</a>). In the examined species of the Parodontidae    and <i>Leporinus striatus</i> Kner, the frontals instead extend anteriorly between    the nasals (state 1). In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> the frontals are also anteriorly    extended but this condition is variable within the Cypriniformes (Howes, 1978)    and it is absent in basal Siluriformes, such as <i>Diplomystes</i> Bleeker.    The root of this analysis is thus coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>21. Contact    between frontals anteriorly to frontal fontanel: (0) absent; (1) present. (VH37,    MO35, SE2, BE9, ZV36m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>22. Frontal    fontanel: (0) present; (1) totally occluded by frontals. (BU9, LU7, CM1(2),    SE1i, ZV36m; PZ15).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the frontals do not contact each other anterior to the epiphyseal bar    and the anterior margin of the frontal fontanel is formed by the posterior margin    of the mesethmoid (character 21, state 0; <a href="#f2">Fig. 2</a>). In a number    of species the frontals are rather in contact anterior to the frontal fontanel    (character 21, state 1; character 22, state 0; <a href="#f18">Figs. 18</a> and    <a href="#f22">22</a>). Both <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> and some morphologically    generalized members of the Cypriniformes (<i>Barilius</i> Hamilton, <i>Opsariichthys</i>    Bleeker, and <i>Zacco</i> Jordan &amp; Evermann) completely lack a frontal fontanel    (Howes, 1980: 155), while <i>Diplomystes</i>, which is considered a basal siluriform    has a well developed fontanel (Arratia, 1987; Azpelicueta, 1994). The presence    of a cranial fontanel is broadly distributed in Gymnotiformes except in 
the    clade formed by <i>Electrophorus</i> Gill and <i>Gymnotus</i> Linnaeus, and    it is optimized as present for the root of this order (Albert &amp; Campos da    Paz, 1998). Given the presence of a fully developed frontal fontanel in both    the Gymnotiformes and Siluriformes, these characters are coded as polymorphic    for the root of the present analysis, despite the absence of this fontanel in    the Cypriniformes. The presence of a frontal fontanel is variable within the    Characiformes. It is absent (character 22, state 1; <a href="#f23">Fig. 23</a>)    in the Erythrinidae, Gasteropelecidae, Hepsetidae, Lebiasinidae, and Parodontidae,    and usually present in other families, such as the Alestidae and Characidae.    This fontanel is absent in the examined specimen of <i>Bryconaethiops macrops</i>    Boulenger, although it is present in this species according to Zanata &amp;    Vari (2005). These authors also described the ontogenetic occlusion of the frontal    fontanel in 
<i>Salminus brasiliensis</i> and this character is coded as polymorphic    for both species. The presence of contact between the frontals anterior to the    frontal fontanel is variable or has some intermediate condition in examined    specimens of <i>Acestrocephalus sardina</i> (Fowler), <i>Astyanax mexicanus</i>    (De Filippi), <i>Attonitus ephimeros</i> Vari &amp; Ortega, <i>Bryconamericus    alpha</i>, <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i>, <i>Deuterodon iguape</i> Eigenmann, <i>Distichodus    maculatus</i>, <i>Hoplocharax goethei</i> G&eacute;ry, <i>Odontostoechus lethostigmus</i>,    <i>Phenagoniates macrolepis</i> (Meek &amp; Hildebrand), <i>Pseudochalceus kyburzi</i>    Schultz and <i>Rhoadsia altipinna</i> Fowler, and it is coded as polymorphic    in these species. According to Lima (2006) the frontals do not contact each    other in <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i>; however, in the examined specimen    of this species these bones are in contact and this character is coded as 
polymorphic    for this species. The frontal fontanel is limited anteriorly by the mesethmoid    in the examined specimens of <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i>, <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>    Holmberg, and <i>Piaractus mesopotamicus</i> (Holmberg), contrary to the observations    of Castro (1984), Moreira (2002), and Machado-Allison (1986), respectively;    this character is coded as polymorphic also for these species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>23. Relative    size of frontal and parietal fontanels: (0) length of frontal fontanel up to    2/3 length of parietal fontanel; (1) length of frontal fontanel 3/4 or more    of length of parietal fontanel.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The cranial fontanel    is divided by the epiphyseal bar to a frontal and a parietal fontanels. In most    examined species, the frontal fontanel is conspicuously shorter than the parietal    fontanel, reaching up 2/3 of the length of the latter opening (state 0). In    other species the frontal fontanel is relatively longer, achieving 3/4 or more    the length of the frontal fontanel (state 1). Intermediate or polymorphic conditions    were observed in <i>Metynnis maculatus</i> (Kner), <i>Aphyocharax nattereri</i>    (Steindachner), <i>Acrobrycon tarijae</i> Fowler, <i>Bryconamericus exodon</i>    Eigenmann, <i>B</i>. <i>rubropictus</i> (Berg), <i>B</i>. <i>thomasi</i> Fowler,    <i>Hemigrammus unilineatus</i> (Gill), <i>Oligosarcus bolivianus</i>, <i>O</i>.    cf. <i>jenynsii</i>, <i>Pristella maxillaris</i> (Ulrey) and <i>Thayeria boehlkei</i>    Weitzman, which are coded as polymorphisms. This character is considered 
as    inapplicable to species in which the frontal fontanel is limited anteriorly    by the frontals, because in these cases the shortening of the frontal fontanel    is the consequence of a different arrangement than the one considered in the    state 0.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>24. Dilator    fossa on lateral surface of frontal: (0) absent; (1) present. (BU13m, BU78m,    LU11m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the lateral margins of the frontal and the sphenotic spine form a depression    where the anterior end of the <i>dilator operculi</i> muscle inserts, the dilator    fossa (state 1; <a href="#f24">Fig. 24</a>, Buckup, 1998: <a href="#f2">fig.    2</a>). In some species the frontal projects laterally just dorsal to the <i>dilator    operculi</i>, with that muscle inserting onto the ventral, rather than lateral    surface of the neurocranium (state 0; Buckup, 1998: <a href="#f1">fig. 1</a>).    In <i>Odontostilbe pequira</i> (Steindachner) and the examined species of <i>Aphyocharax</i>    and <i>Moenkhausia</i>, the dilator fossa is relatively small, but it is always    present and these species are coded as state 1. This character is considered    inapplicable to the species of <i>Characidium</i> Reinhardt, where the <i>dilator    operculi</i> inserts posterior to the vertical through the orbit, 
in a situation    not assignable to the states herein defined for this character. Buckup (1998)    coded <i>Characidium</i> with a missing entry for this character for the same    reason.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Mesethmoid:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>25. Anterior    end of mesethmoid: (0) trifurcate, with processes inserted into depressions    on premaxillae; (1) not trifurcate, with a triangular anterior spine and articular    processes reduced or absent. (UJ22m, UJ23, UJ38, BU1, LU1).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In some members    of the outgroup the anterior portion of the mesethmoid has an anterior process    of variable size and a pair of anterolateral processes inserting into small    fossae on the premaxillae. These processes give to the anterior region of the    mesethmoid a trifurcate form, or bifurcate in the cases where the medial process    is reduced (state 0). In all members from the ingroup and some species from    the outgroup, the mesethmoid has an anterior triangular process (the mesethmoid    spine), and lateral wings that support the ascending processes of the premaxillae    (state 1; <a href="#f1">Fig. 1</a>). The situation in the Cypriniformes is not    comparable due to the presence of a kinethmoid bone articulating with the premaxillae.    However, the mesethmoid of the Siluriformes appears to correspond to state 0    and this state probably is ancestral for Characiformes. The root is herein coded    as a 
missing entry pending further studies to resolve this issue. In the examined    specimen of <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i> (B&ouml;hlke), the mesethmoid    has an anterior spine and reduced, but present, lateral wings. This condition    is typically present in the Hemiodontidae with the exception of <i>Argonectes</i>    B&ouml;hlke &amp; Myers (Langeani, 1998) and that species is coded as state    1. In <i>Phenacogaster tegatus</i> (Eigenmann) and <i>Roeboexodon geryi</i>    the mesethmoid spine has small lobes slightly projected to the medial margin    of the premaxillary ascending process. These lobes are simultaneously present    with the lateral wings of the mesethmoid, and they are herein considered to    be non-homologous with the processes described in state 0.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>26. Ventral    projection of mesethmoid spine, forming a keel between premaxillae: (0) absent;    (1) present. (VH35).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">When present, the    mesethmoid spine is rather pointed from lateral view and does not form a keel    between the premaxillae (state 0). In <i>Creagrutus</i> spp., <i>Piabina argentea</i>,    and <i>Roeboexodon geryi</i>, among the studied species, this spine has in addition    a ventral laminar projection expanded between the premaxillae (state 1; <a href="#f25">Fig.    25</a>). This state is diagnostic for a clade formed by <i>Creagrutus</i> and    <i>Piabina</i>, according to Vari &amp; Harold (2001). This character is considered    as inapplicable for species in which the mesethmoid spine is completely absent.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>27. Form of    mesethmoid spine: (0) long, extending between premaxillae; (1) relatively short,    with premaxillae articulating with each other anterior to mesethmoid. (B&Uuml;1m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The mesethmoid    spine extends to varying degrees between the premaxillae. Usually, this spine    is slender and long, almost completely separating the premaxillae, which consequently    articulate with each other only at their anteroventral tips (state 0; <a href="#f21">Figs.    21</a> and <a href="#f22">22</a>). In a reduced number of species, the mesethmoid    spine is much broader and shorter, approximating the form of an equilateral    triangle from dorsal view and leaving a comparatively longer area of articulation    between the premaxillae anteriorly (state 1; <a href="#f26">Fig. 26</a>). This    spine is relatively broad, but separates completely the premaxillae in <i>Charax    stenopterus</i>, <i>Heterocharax macrolepis</i> Eigenmann, <i>Hoplocharax goethei</i>    and <i>Phenacogaster tegatus</i>, which are coded as state 0.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>28. Posterior    portion of mesethmoid spine: (0) relatively slender; (1) as broad as lateral    wings of mesethmoid.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the posterior portion of the mesethmoid spine is rather broad but does    not reach the tip of lateral wings (state 0; <a href="#f21">Figs. 21</a> and    <a href="#f22">22</a>), which are visible as separate structures. Members of    the Rhoadsiinae have the mesethmoid spine greatly expanded posteriorly, being    approximately equal to the total width of the lateral wings of the mesethmoid.    In this state, the lateral wings are not visible as discrete structures (state    1; <a href="#f19">Fig. 19</a>). This character is coded as inapplicable for    species in which the mesethmoid spine is absent.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>29. Lateral    wings of mesethmoid: (0) present; (1) absent. (UJ21, BU2, LU3, B&Uuml;6).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The lateral wings    of mesethmoid ("lateral ethmoid wings" of Weitzman, 1962) are expansions that    support the ascending process of the corresponding premaxilla. As mentioned    above, in some members of the outgroup the mesethmoid is anteriorly trifurcate    and has processes articulating with premaxillary fossae. In these cases, the    lateral wings of mesethmoid are absent (state 1). Most species with a triangular    anterior mesethmoid spine have lateral wings articulated with the premaxillary    ascending processes (state 0; <a href="#f27">Fig. 27</a>). An almost perfect    correspondence exist between the absence of articular processes and the presence    of lateral wings; however, the simultaneous absence of these structures in <i>Hemiodus</i>    cf. <i>thayeria</i>, <i>Leporinus striatus</i>, and <i>Pyrrhulina australis</i>,    among the examined species, justifies their inclusion as separate characters.    This 
character is coded as inapplicable to the root of this analysis in light    of the different configuration of the bones of the snout of the Cypriniformes    and Siluriformes.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>30. Ventral    diverging lamellae of mesethmoid: (0) absent; (1) present. (LU0i, BU3i, TP8i,    ZV22)</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The ventral diverging    lamellae of the mesethmoid were described by Weitzman (1962) for <i>Brycon meeki</i>.    These paired lamellae are situated ventrally in the mesethmoid posterior to    the lateral wings (state 1; <a href="#f14">Fig. 14</a>) and are absent in most    members of the outgroup (state 0). The condition observed in <i>Puntius tetrazona</i>    is herein considered as non-comparable, and the root is coded as inapplicable    for this character. In <i>Aphyocharax</i> spp., <i>Paragoniates alburnus</i>    Steindachner, <i>Phenagoniates macrolepis</i>, <i>Prionobrama paraguayensis</i>    (Eigenmann), and <i>Xenagoniates bondi</i> Myers, the nasal septum of the mesethmoid,    which in other taxa is a single longitudinal medial lamella in the ventral surface    of the mesethmoid, is, at least partially, formed by two parallel lamellae.    In these taxa the ventral diverging lamellae of the mesethmoid, as 
observed    in other species, are absent; however, it is probable that the nasal septum    is formed partially by these lamellae. This character is coded as inapplicable    for the mentioned species pending morphological studies to elucidate this situation.    In the examined species of the Cheirodontinae these lamellae are reduced to    small ridges of variable degree of development in different genera. They are    coded as present in cheirodontin characids. In the examined specimens of <i>Acestrorhynchus    pantaneiro</i> and <i>Agoniates anchovia</i> Eigenmann these lamellae are reduced    in size but present and these species are coded as state 1. These lamellae are    variably present among the examined specimens of <i>Lonchogenys ilisha</i> Myers    and this character is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>31. Anterior    convergence of ventral diverging lamellae with nasal septum of mesethmoid: (0)    absent, or confluent near anterior end of nasal septum; (1) confluent at posterior    end of nasal septum.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">When present, the    diverging lamellae of the mesethmoid usually extend anterior to the articulation    with the vomer and are independent of the medial nasal septum of the mesethmoid    (state 0; <a href="#f1">Fig. 1</a>). In a group of species, principally composed    of members of the clade A of Malabarba &amp; Weitzman (2003), these lamellae    converge near the posterior end of the nasal septum, with the olfactory capsules    separated from each other by this composite septum (state 1; <a href="#f28">Fig.    28</a>). In some examined species including most members of the Cheirodontinae,    <i>Hasemania nana</i>, <i>Hemigrammus erythrozonus</i> Durbin, <i>H</i>. <i>bleheri</i>,    <i>Microschemobrycon casiquiare</i> B&ouml;hlke, <i>Paracheirodon axelrodi</i>,    <i>Parecbasis cyclolepis</i>, and <i>Phenagoniates macrolepis</i>, the ventral    diverging lamellae converge with the nasal septum, but do so anteriorly 
rather    than posteriorly, and the olfactory capsules are separated each other, at least    partially, by the medial longitudinal nasal septum of the mesethmoid. This situation    is coded as state 0. This character is inapplicable for species in which the    ventral diverging lamellae of the mesethmoid are reduced or absent.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>32. Nasal septum    of mesethmoid: (0) single longitudinal lamella; (1) two parallel lamellae apparently    formed, in part, by ventral diverging lamellae.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">As previously mentioned,    in most examined species the ventral diverging lamellae of the mesethmoid are    independent each other, at least posteriorly, and the nasal septum is formed    by a medial single lamella attached dorsally to the ventral surface of the mesethmoid    (state 0; <a href="#f1">Figs. 1</a> and <a href="#f28">28</a>). In some species    the nasal septum is formed by two closely-positioned and parallel lamellae that    articulate posteriorly through cartilages with the medial region of lateral    ethmoids. This condition can be observed dorsally through the somewhat transparent    dorsal lamella of the mesethmoid (state 1; <a href="#f18">Fig. 18</a>). As mentioned    under character 30, in these species the ventral diverging lamellae of the mesethmoid    are absent as separate structures, but probably partially form the composite    nasal septum. Given that the identity of the ventral diverging 
lamellae as part    of this nasal septum was not corroborated herein, this character is considered    different from character 31. This character is coded as inapplicable to <i>Aphyocharax    nattereri</i> in which the whole nasal septum is much reduced and <i>Phenagoniates    macrolepis</i> in which the posterior portion of the lamellae forming the nasal    septum diverge slightly at their posterior tips resulting in a not directly    comparable condition. In <i>Heterocharax macrolepis</i>, <i>Hoplocharax goethei</i>,    and <i>Lonchogenys ilisha</i>, the nasal septum resembles state 1, but the ventral    diverging lamellae are present as separate structures. This character is coded    as inapplicable to these species, pending future studies. The origin and homologies    of the different structures forming the nasal septum and their relationships    with the olfactory capsules remain to be studied in greater detail.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Nasal:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>33. Nasal: (0)    present; (1) absent. (ZV17).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The nasal bone    is present in almost all the Characiformes as a tubular bone lateral to the    mesethmoid (state 0; <a href="#f2">Figs. 2</a> and <a href="#f21">21</a>); its    absence was cited among the examined phylogenies only in the alestid <i>Lepidarchus    adonis</i> Roberts (Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005) (state 1; <a href="#f27">Fig. 27</a>).    This bone is present in all the examined species except for <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>    (Ellis) and <i>Hyphessobrycon elachys</i> Weitzman. Absence of an ossified nasal    is probably associated with miniaturization, although this bone is present in    species of smaller adult sizes than <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>34. Bony lamellae    bordering sensory canal of nasal: (0) absent or more slender than tubular region;    (1) wider at some point than tubular region. (VA17, LU31, MO48m, LI7, PZ10).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the nasal is reduced to a tubular bone, lacking or with distinctly small    associated lamellae (state 0; <a href="#f2">Figs. 2</a> and <a href="#f21">21</a>).    Vari (1995) reported the presence of lamellae bordering the sensory canal of    the nasal dorsally and ventrally (state 1) in members of the families Ctenoluciidae,    Erythrinidae, Hepsetidae, and Lebiasinidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Orbitosphenoid:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>35. Synchondral    articulation between lateral ethmoid and anterodorsal border of orbitosphenoid:    (0) present; (1) absent, with orbitosphenoid distant from lateral ethmoid.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anterodorsal    tip of the orbitosphenoid (the orbitosphenoid wing, <i>sensu</i> Weitzman, 1962:    20) is usually distant from the lateral ethmoid, and the area between these    bones is filled by the posterior projection of the ethmoid cartilage (<i>sensu</i>    Weitzman, 1962: 20), which also limits anterolaterally the anterior myodome    (state 1; <a href="#f6">Fig. 6</a>). In some species, in contrast, the anterior    margin of the orbitosphenoid is much closer to the lateral ethmoid and these    bones articulate synchondrally (state 0; <a href="#f29">Fig. 29</a>). This character    is coded as inapplicable for <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> which, as is usual in    the Cypriniformes, has an extensive contact between the orbitosphenoid and lateral    ethmoid along the entire anterior margin of the orbitosphenoid. In <i>Alestes</i>    cf. <i>macrophthalmus</i> G&uuml;nther, <i>Brycinus carolinae</i> (Paugy &amp;    
Lev&eacute;qu&egrave;), and <i>Bryconaethiops macrops</i> Boulenger, the orbitosphenoid    articulates anteriorly with the lateral ethmoid, but contact in the region lateral    of the olfactory nerve and ventral to the region considered in this character.    These species are correspondingly coded as state 1.
