In the examined specimens    of <i>Bryconamericus</i> cf. <i>rubropictus</i> this character is variable and    is coded here as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>36. Lateral    bony coverage of olfactory nerve: (0) absent; (1) covered by posterior expansion    of lateral ethmoid; (2) covered by an anterior tubular projection of orbitosphenoid;    (3) covered laterally and ventrally by orbitosphenoid and lateral ethmoid, which    do not form canal. (UJ13m, ZV29m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The orbitosphenoid    usually has, from anterior view, an anterior concavity partially containing    the olfactory bulb of the brain, with the olfactory nerve directed anteriorly    from the bulb to the olfactory capsule through a foramen in the lateral ethmoid.    In most examined species, the olfactory bulb and nerve have no lateral bony    coverage and they are visible through the orbit after the eye is removed (state    0; <a href="#f13">Fig. 13</a>). In some species, the olfactory nerve is instead    covered laterally in different modes. In the Parodontidae the lateral ethmoid    has a posterior projection that laterally covers the olfactory nerve (state    1; Roberts, 1974: <a href="#f57">figs. 57</a>, <a href="#f61">61</a>, and <a href="#f63">63</a>).    In most species of the Alestidae, the olfactory nerves are covered by a tubular    anterior projection of the orbitosphenoid that reaches the lateral ethmoid 
(state    2; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f9">fig. 9</a>). In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i>    there is an extensive articulation between the orbitosphenoid and the lateral    ethmoid that completely covers the olfactory bulb and tract. <i>Distichodus</i>    M&uuml;ller &amp; Troschel and <i>Xenocharax</i> G&uuml;nther, as is general    in the Citharinoidei (Vari, 1979; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005), have a similar condition,    but the lateral coverage of the anterior portion of the brain is not complete    (state 3). The lateral coverage of the olfactory nerve by a tubular projection    of the orbitosphenoid was considered as typical of the Alestidae by G&eacute;ry    (1977), and it was proposed as a synapomorphy for this family by Murray &amp;    Stewart (2002), and a synapomorphy for the African alestids by Zanata &amp;    Vari (2005).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>37. Form of    orbitosphenoid: (0) slender, relatively small and separate from parasphenoid;    (1) massive, almost reaching parasphenoid ventrally. (UJ12, UJ36, LC1, TP18,    BE25, B&Uuml;9).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species of the Characidae the orbitosphenoid is slender, and its ventral margin    is distant from the parasphenoid (state 0; <a href="#f25">Fig. 25</a>), while    in most members of the outgroup and some species of the Characidae, the orbitosphenoid    is relatively massive and its ventral margin is close to the parasphenoid (state    1; <a href="#f14">Fig. 14</a>). In the examined specimens of <i>Acestrocephalus    sardina</i>, <i>Chalceus macrolepidotus</i> Cuvier, <i>Hollandichthys multifasciatus</i>,    and <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i> the orbitosphenoid has an intermediate size    and these species are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>38. Distance    between posterodorsal margin of ethmoid cartilage and lateral ethmoids: (0)    contacting, or almost contacting, lateral ethmoids; (1) distant from lateral    ethmoids.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dorsal region    of the orbitosphenoid is margined anteriorly by a cartilage, the ethmoid cartilage    of Weitzman (1962), which is arched in dorsal view and anteriorly limits the    olfactory bulb of the brain and posteriorly the anterior myodome. This myodome    contains part of the extrinsic musculature of the eye which attaches principally    to the posterior wall of the lateral ethmoid. The position of the olfactory    bulb relative to the lateral ethmoid and, consequently, the development and    position of the anterior myodome varies among the examined species. The most    obvious feature reflecting these differences is the position of the ethmoid    cartilage, which is visible dorsally through the frontals. In most examined    species the arch formed by this cartilage contacts, or almost contacts, the    medial region of the lateral ethmoids (state 0; <a href="#f2">Fig. 2</a>). In    other species the ethmoid 
cartilage is distant from the lateral ethmoids and    it is, instead, connected to the medial region of the lateral ethmoids through    a longitudinal cartilage extending dorsally from the rhinosphenoid, when present    (state 1; <a href="#f15">Fig. 15</a>). In the Cypriniformes and Siluriformes    the olfactory bulbs are broadly separated from the telencephalon and situated    just posterior to the olfactory organ (Harder, 1975). Although this condition    is not congruent with any of the states defined herein, it represents an opposite    state to that described on state 1. Thus, the root is herein coded as state    0. State 1 was observed in a juvenile specimen of <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i>;    however, Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) described an anterior displacement of the    olfactory bulb in <i>Salminus</i> Agassiz during the growth, and this character    is coded as polymorphic for this species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>39. Opening    between orbitosphenoid and pterosphenoid: (0) present, rounded or ovate, usually    margined by frontal dorsally; (1) absent. (AM15m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most members    of the outgroup the posterior margin of the orbitosphenoid is broadly articulated    with the anterior margin of the pterosphenoid, leaving no gaps between these    bones (state 1). Almost all the examined characids instead have incomplete articulations    between these bones, resulting in an opening margined anteriorly by the orbitosphenoid,    posteriorly by the pterosphenoid, and dorsally by the orbital lamella of the    frontal (state 0; <a href="#f6">Figs. 6</a> and <a href="#f30">30</a>). Weitzman    (1962) described a small foramen situated between the orbitosphenoid and pterosphenoid    for <i>Brycon meeki</i>, which serves as passage for the trochlear nerve. The    correspondence of the opening discussed herein and that described by Weitzman    (1962) was not corroborated, and <i>Brycon meeki</i> is coded as a missing entry.    A similar opening between the orbitosphenoid and pterosphenoid 
(<i>i</i>. <i>e</i>.    not limited by the frontal), is present in <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i> and the    examined species of <i>Triportheus</i> Cope. These species are coded with the    state 0. The presence of this opening is variable in the examined specimens    of <i>Hoplocharax goethei</i> and this species is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Parasphenoid:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>40. Anterior    paired projections of parasphenoid: (0) absent; (1) present. (BE26).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anterior region    of the parasphenoid articulates with the posterior lamella of the vomer and    the ventral margin of the lateral ethmoids. Usually, the lateral edges of the    parasphenoid are entire and parallel in all their extent across the orbit, lacking    any projections (state 0). The parasphenoid of some examined species instead    has paired acute processes situated near its anterior end, oriented towards    the posteroventral margin of each lateral ethmoid (state 1; <a href="#f12">Fig.    12</a>). Benine (2004) defined three states for this character, considering    an intermediate situation, in which such processes are present but reduced in    size. Only the species in which these processes are present and well developed    in all the examined specimens are herein coded as state 1, leaving as polymorphic    those species in which these process are of variable occurrence or much reduced.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Parietal:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>41. Parietal    fontanel: (0) present in adults; (1) absent in adults. (BU15, LU12, ZV37, PZ16).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The parietal fontanel,    when present, is limited laterally by the frontals and parietals, anteriorly    by the epiphyseal bar, and posteriorly by the supraoccipital (state 0; <a href="#f26">Fig.    26</a>). In some species, the contralateral frontals and parietals meet medially,    occluding the parietal fontanel (state 1; <a href="#f23">Fig. 23</a>). Among    the members of the Characidae, Lucena (1998) mentioned the absence of this fontanel    only in <i>Brycon pesu</i>, while Buckup (1998) coded it as present in <i>B</i>.    <i>guatemalensis</i> Regan. According to Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) this fontanel    is present in specimens of <i>B</i>. <i>pesu</i> of 27.0 mm SL, and absent in    specimens of 49.7 mm SL, indicating that at least in some species this character    is variable during the growth. The parietal fontanel is present in specimens    of 256 mm SL of <i>B</i>. <i>meeki</i> (Weitzman, 1962), and it is coded 
as    present for this species. In the examined specimens of <i>B</i>. <i>falcatus</i>    and <i>B</i>. <i>orbignyanus</i> this fontanel is present; as there is no published    evidence indicating ontogenetic elimination of the parietal fontanel in these    species, this character is also coded with state 0.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Prootic:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>42. Trigemino-facialis    foramen: (0) broad, largely limited by sphenotic dorsally; (1) narrow, as a    cleft with sphenotic almost excluded from its margin.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the trigemino-facialis foramen is situated in an approximately triangular    chamber on the anterior surface of the prootic, with the chamber limited dorsally    by the sphenotic (state 0; <a href="#f11">Figs. 11</a> and <a href="#f31">31</a>).    In the examined species of <i>Aphyocharax</i> the trigemino-facialis foramen    is reduced to a cleft, narrow in anterolateral view and almost completely limited    by the prootic and pterosphenoid (state 1; <a href="#f30">Fig. 30</a>); in this    state the dorsal margin of the trigemino-facialis foramen is much reduced and    the sphenotic, which limits dorsally the foramen, is almost excluded from its    margin.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Pterosphenoid:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>43. Large foramen    on pterosphenoid: (0) absent; (1) present, well developed.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the lateral surface of the pterosphenoid is flat or has a shallow ridge    ventrally limiting the supraorbital nerve, which is directed to the trigemino-facialis    foramen (state 0; <a href="#f11">Figs. 11</a>, <a href="#f30">30</a>, and <a href="#f31">31</a>).    In the examined specimens of <i>Aphyocharacidium bolivianum</i> and <i>Axelrodia    lindeae</i> there is a large foramen situated in the middle of the pterosphenoid    (state 1; <a href="#f32">Fig. 32</a>). The association of this foramen with    blood vessels or nerves was not confirmed. The presence of this foramen is variable    among the examined specimens of <i>Microschemobrycon casiquiare</i> and this    species is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>44. Small foramen    near posterior margin of pterosphenoid: (0) absent, or not pierced by nerves;    (1) present, pierced by a branch of supraorbital nerve.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The supraorbital    nerve runs through the orbit in the region of articulation between the frontal    and orbitosphenoid/pterosphenoid, entering to the braincase through the trigemino-facialis    foramen in most examined species (state 0). In some species, mostly of the Stevardiinae,    a branch of this nerve enters to the braincase through a small foramen near    the posteroventral margin of the pterosphenoid (state 1; <a href="#f31">Fig.    31</a>). The examined alcohol-preserved specimens of <i>Astyanax</i> cf. <i>eigenmanniorum</i>    (Cope), <i>Cynopotamus argenteus</i>, <i>Hemibrycon surinamensis</i> G&eacute;ry,    <i>Hyphessobrycon bifasciatus</i> Ellis, <i>Moenkhausia sanctaefilomenae</i>    (Steindachner), <i>Oligosarcus</i> spp., and <i>Roeboides microlepis</i> have    small pores in a similar position, but these pores are not pierced by nerves    or blood vessels; therefore these species are coded with state 
0.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Pterotic:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>45. Dorsal process    of pterotic where tendon from epaxial musculature attach: (0) absent; (1) present,    projecting dorsally from tube for semicircular canal.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The examined species    usually have a tendon from the epaxial musculature attached to the lateral margin    of the pterotic tube for the horizontal semicircular canal, or to a process    ventral to this tube (state 0). In a group of species, there is a small process    directed dorsally from the tube for the semicircular canal, onto which this    tendon attaches (state 1; <a href="#f33">Fig. 33</a>). The presence of this    process is variable among the examined specimens of <i>Mimagoniates rheocharis</i>,    <i>Nematobrycon palmeri</i>, and <i>Phenagoniates macrolepis</i> which are coded    as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>46. Relative    length of pterotic spine: (0) projected more posteriorly than attachment site    of ligament from hyomandibula; (1) restricted to attachment region of hyomandibular    ligament.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In all the examined    members of the outgroup and some characids, the pterotic spine is projected    posterior to the attachment site of a ligament from the hyomandibula (state    0; <a href="#f5">Figs. 5</a> and <a href="#f7">7</a>). In most examined members    of the Characidae the pterotic spine is relatively reduced and its extension    is limited to the posterior extension of the attachment site for the hyomandibular    ligament (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Rhinosphenoid:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>47. Rhinosphenoid:    (0) absent; (1) present. (UJ35, BU7, LU8i, CM11(13), TP16i, VB15, SE15, BE20i,    ZV31i, LI28, B&Uuml;8, QU21i, PZ13).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The rhinosphenoid    is a medial bone situated anterior to the orbitosphenoid, which is present in    most characiforms (state 1; <a href="#f6">Figs. 6</a>, <a href="#f24">24</a>,    and <a href="#f34">34</a>) albeit is absent in many groups in the Characiformes    and the remaining Ostariophysi (state 0; <a href="#f14">Fig. 14</a>). B&uuml;hrnheim    (2006) mentioned the presence of rhinosphenoid, among others, in <i>Charax stenopterus</i>;    this bone is, however, absent in the specimens of this species herein examined,    and this species is coded as polymorphic. The presence of this bone is intraspecifically    variable among the examined specimens of <i>Astyanax correntinus</i> (Holmberg),    <i>A</i>. <i>latens</i> Mirande, Aguilera &amp; Azpelicueta, <i>Diapoma terofali</i>    (G&eacute;ry), and <i>Hyphessobrycon bifasciatus</i>, in which this character    is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>48. Dorsal expansion    of rhinosphenoid: (0) absent; (1) present and forming a bony wall between olfactory    nerves. (SE17, BE21).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The form of the    rhinosphenoid is variable among the examined species. In some species this bone    has a rectangular form and is situated completely ventral to the olfactory nerves    (state 0; <a href="#f6">Figs. 6</a> and <a href="#f34">34</a>). In <i>Characidium</i>    spp., <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i>, and many species of the Characidae,    the rhinosphenoid is expanded dorsally and so forming a bony wall between the    olfactory nerves (state 1; <a href="#f24">Fig. 24</a>). Benine (2004) coded,    among others, <i>Bario steindachneri</i> (Eigenmann) and <i>Tetragonopterus    argenteus</i> Cuvier as lacking a dorsally expanded rhinosphenoid, however a    well developed process was observed in <i>B</i>. <i>steindachneri</i> and a    relatively smaller process was found in <i>T</i>. <i>argenteus</i> and these    two species are coded as polymorphic. A relatively reduced or intraspecifically    variable dorsal 
projection of the rhinosphenoid was also observed in <i>Aphyodite    grammica</i> Eigenmann, <i>Hemigrammus unilineatus</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon elachys</i>,    <i>H</i>. <i>pulchripinnis</i> Ahl, <i>Microschemobrycon casiquiare</i>, and    <i>Moenkhausia sanctaefilomenae</i> which are coded as polymorphic. This character    is coded as inapplicable to species lacking an ossified rhinosphenoid.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>49. Posterior    extension of rhinosphenoid cartilage: (0) projected only to middle horizontal    length of orbitosphenoid, or less; (1) extended to vertical through region of    articulation between orbitosphenoid and pterosphenoid.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The rhinosphenoid    cartilage is situated between the rhinosphenoid, lateral ethmoid, and parasphenoid.    In almost all of the examined species, this cartilage extends posteriorly along    the dorsal margin of the parasphenoid to a point not surpassing the vertical    through middle horizontal length of the orbitosphenoid (state 0; <a href="#f35">Fig.    35</a>). In <i>Inpaichthys kerri</i> and <i>Xenagoniates bondi</i>, this cartilage    extends more posteriorly and reaches the vertical through the region of articulation    between the orbitosphenoid and pterosphenoid (state 1). The examined specimens    of <i>Hollandichthys multifasciatus</i> have an intermediate situation that    is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>50. Ventral    border of rhinosphenoid: (0) distinctly separate from parasphenoid; (1) almost    contacting parasphenoid.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the rhinosphenoid is variably, but distinctly separated from the parasphenoid    (state 0; <a href="#f25">Fig. 25</a>). In a small group of species, the rhinosphenoid    is situated near the parasphenoid, and its ventral margin is parallel to and    almost contacts the dorsal margin of the parasphenoid (state 1). This character    is coded as inapplicable in species without an ossified rhinosphenoid.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Supraoccipital:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>51. Anterior    margin of supraoccipital: (0) situated completely behind vertical through posterior    orbital margin; (1) situated anterior to vertical through posterior orbital    margin.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anterior margin    of the supraoccipital that forms the the posterior margin of the parietal fontanel,    when that opening is present, is located posterior to the vertical through the    posterior margin of the orbit in most examined species (state 0). In some species,    in contrast, the anterior margin of the supraoccipital is situated anterior    to the vertical through the posterior margin of the orbit (state 1; <a href="#f24">Fig.    24</a>). The examined specimens of <i>Hyphessobrycon socolofi</i> Weitzman have    an intermediate situation that is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>52. Length of    supraoccipital spine: (0) extends dorsal of entire neural complex of Weberian    apparatus; (1) extends dorsal of approximately one half extent of neural complex.    (AM16m, CM8(9), MO34m, VB24m, SE18m, BE19m, QU25m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>53. Length of    supraoccipital spine: (0) extends posteriorly to, at least, middle length of    neural complex of Weberian apparatus; (1) extends only to anterior limit of    neural complex. (LU23m, MO34m, VB24m, SE18m, BE19m, QU25m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">When it is present,    the supraoccipital spine forms the posterior margin of the parietal fontanel    and extends dorsal to the modified vertebrae of the Weberian apparatus to different    degrees among the examined species. The length of the supraoccipital spine is    herein compared to that of the neural complex of the Weberian apparatus. In    some species the supraoccipital spine is greatly developed and extends dorsal    to the entire neural complex (character 52, state 0; <a href="#f24">Fig. 24</a>).    In an intermediate state, it extends onto the middle of the length of the neural    complex (character 52, state 1; character 53, state 0; <a href="#f5">Figs. 5</a>    and <a href="#f8">8</a>), whereas in some species the supraoccipital spine covers    only the anterior vertical portion of the neural complex (character 53, state    1; <a href="#f35">Fig. 35</a>). Intermediate states of the character 52 were    
observed in <i>Astyanax abramis</i> (Jenyns), <i>A</i>. cf. <i>abramis</i>,    <i>A</i>. <i>correntinus</i>, <i>Brycon orbignyanus</i>, <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i>,    <i>Piaractus mesopotamicus</i>, <i>Pseudochalceus kyburzi</i>, and <i>Rhoadsia    altipinna</i>, which are coded as polymorphic. The examined specimens of <i>Hyphessobrycon    socolofi</i> and <i>Roeboexodon geryi</i> have intermediate states of the character    53, and this character is also coded as polymorphic in these species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Vomer:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>54. Dorsolateral    processes of vomer: (0) absent; (1) present. (PZ7).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The vomer, in most    species, has a medial longitudinal ridge in the dorsal surface aligned with    a ridge on the ventral surface of the mesethmoid, together with there forming    the nasal septum (state 0). In addition to this medial lamella, some species    have paired dorsal lamellae on the vomer aligned with the ventral diverging    lamellae of the mesethmoid (state 1; Toledo-Piza, 2007: <a href="#f5">fig. 5</a>).    These ridges were called dorsolateral processes of vomer by Toledo-Piza (2007).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Orbital region</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Antorbital:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>55. Antorbital:    (0) present; (1) absent or fused with first infraorbital. (VA1, BU20, LU25,    ZV1).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The antorbital    is present as an independent ossification in almost all the Characiformes (state    0; <a href="#f37">Fig. 37</a>), whereas it is presumably fused with the first    infraorbital, forming the lachrymal, in the Cypriniformes and Siluriformes (Weitzman,    1962). The absence of antorbital (state 1) is not usual in Characiformes; it    was mentioned for several genera (Lucena, 1993; Buckup, 1998) and proposed by    Vari (1995) as a synapomorphy of a clade composed of the Ctenoluciidae and Erythrinidae.    <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i> (Bloch), <i>Inpaichthys kerri</i>, and    the root of this analysis are coded with state 1, although based on its position    and extension this bone appears to be fused in <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>    and cyprinids and absent in <i>I</i>. <i>kerri</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>56. Position    of antorbital relative to lateral ethmoid in lateral view: (0) antorbital entirely    anterior to lateral ethmoid; (1) antorbital overlapping lateral ethmoid. (TP2).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the antorbital is situated lateral to the olfactory capsules and bordering    the nasal openings posteriorly but is positioned entirely anterior to the lateral    ethmoid (state 0; <a href="#f36">Figs. 35</a> and <a href="#f36">36</a>). In    some species the antorbital is relatively broader, extensively overlapping the    lateral margin of the lateral ethmoid (state 1; <a href="#f37">Fig. 37</a>).    This broadening of the antorbital was mentioned by Castro (1984) as a possible    synapomorphy of a proposed clade formed by <i>Clupeacharax</i> Pearson and <i>Engraulisoma</i>    Castro.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Infraorbitals:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>57. Relative    position of anterior margin of antorbital and first infraorbital: (0) anterior    margin of antorbital either aligned with or anterior to first infraorbital;    (1) anterior margin of antorbital posterior to first infraorbital. (ZV6i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The first infraorbital    is located just ventral to the antorbital and extends to a varying degree along    the longitudinal length of this bone. In most species the anterior margin of    the first infraorbital reaches a point between the middle and anterior margin    of the antorbital, but not projects anterior to this bone (state 0; <a href="#f37">Fig.    37</a>). In several outgroups and <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i> the first infraorbital    conspicuously projects anterior to the antorbital (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>58. Bony lamellae    bordering laterosensory canal of first infraorbital: (0) present; (1) absent.    (ZV9m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the first infraorbital laterosensory canal is margined by a bony lamella    both dorsally and ventrally, (state 0; <a href="#f38">Figs. 38</a> and <a href="#f39">39</a>).    In some species the first infraorbital is reduced to the laterosensory canal,    and these lamellae are lacking (state 1; <a href="#f40">Fig. 40</a>). The lamellae    of all the infraorbitals are much reduced in <i>Gymnocharacinus bergii</i> differing    from other species lacking bony lamellae on the first infraorbital, in which    the lamellae of the remaining infraorbitals are well developed. However, <i>G</i>.    <i>bergii</i> is coded as state 1. The first infraorbital is absent in <i>Carnegiella    strigata</i> and <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>, and this character is coded    as inapplicable to these species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>59. Extent of    expansion of first infraorbital lateral to maxilla: (0) covering less than one    half length of maxilla; (1) covering most of maxilla. (PZ30m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The ventral margin    of the first infraorbital forms a groove that receives the dorsal margin of    the maxilla in most examined species. This grooves usually laterally covers    as much as one half the length of the maxillary lamella when the mouth is closed    (state 0). In <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i> the first infraorbital entirely    covers the maxilla in lateral view (state 1; <i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. Menezes, 1969:    <a href="#f23">fig. 23</a>), and the maxillary lamella is also significantly    covered by the first infraorbital in <i>Agoniates anchovia</i>, <i>Bryconexodon    juruenae</i>, <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i>, <i>Exodon paradoxus</i>, <i>Heterocharax    macrolepis</i>, and <i>Roeboexodon geryi</i>, all of which are coded as state    1. This character is coded as inapplicable to <i>Carnegiella strigata</i> and    <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>, in which the infraorbitals are much reduced.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>60. Lateral    overlap of first infraorbital by anterior margin of second infraorbital: (0)    absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the posterior margin of the first infraorbital and the anterior margin    of the second infraorbital either are not contacting each other or the first    infraorbital is overlapping laterally the second infraorbital (state 0; <a href="#f40">Figs.    40</a> and <a href="#f41">41</a>). The examined species of <i>Bryconops</i>    Kner and <i>Triportheus</i> instead have the anterior margin of the second infraorbital    extensively overlapping the posterior margin of the first infraorbital, especially    in the region of the laterosensory canal, and covering it from lateral view    (state 1; <a href="#f39">Fig. 39</a>). This character is coded as inapplicable    to <i>Carnegiella strigata</i> and <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i> in which the    infraorbitals are reduced. This character differs with that described by Lucena    &amp; Menezes (1998: <a href="#f4">fig. 4</a>) in which only the 
laterosensory    canal of the second infraorbital overlaps laterally the lamella of the first    one, whereas its lamella is situated clearly medial to that of the first infraorbital.    In the state 1 of this character both the laterosensory canal and the lamella    of the second infraorbital overlap laterally the lamella of the first infraorbital.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>61. Overlap    of maxilla by second infraorbital: (0) absent; (1) present. (LM5).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most species    of the ingroup the first infraorbital overlaps the maxilla to some degree, while    the ventral margin of second infraorbital is situated dorsally and does not    cover the maxilla laterally (state 0). In some examined species, both the first    and second infraorbitals form part of a sheath that receives the dorsal margin    of the maxilla when the mouth is closed (state 1; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f3">fig.    3</a>). In <i>Apareiodon affinis</i> (Steindachner), <i>Characidium</i> spp.,    <i>Distichodus maculatus</i>, <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i>, <i>Iguanodectes    geisleri</i> G&eacute;ry, <i>Leporinus striatus</i>, <i>Metynnis maculatus</i>,    <i>Parodon nasus</i> (Kner), <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>, and <i>Puntius tetrazona</i>,    the posterior tip of the maxilla falls short of the second infraorbital and    this character is coded as inapplicable.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>62. Articulation    between second and third infraorbitals: (0) vertical; (1) anteroventrally angled;    (2) posteroventrally angled.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The articulation    between the second and third infraorbitals lacks interdigitations among the    examined species. The main variation in this articulation is the relative angle    of contact between these bones. In the most common situation the posterior margin    of the second infraorbital and the anterior margin of the third infraorbital    describe an approximately vertical line perpendicular to the horizontal arm    of the preopercle (state 0; <a href="#f41">Fig. 41</a>). In a relatively diverse    group of species the second infraorbital has an approximately triangular shape,    with an anteroventrally oblique posterior margin. In this state the third infraorbital    partially borders the ventral edge of the second infraorbital (state 1; <a href="#f40">Fig.    40</a>). The inverse situation is found in some species in which the posterior    margin of the second infraorbital is posteroventrally oblique and the 
second    infraorbital ventrally borders the anterior region of the third infraorbital    (state 2; <a href="#f39">Fig. 39</a>). The latter state is usually found in    species with a long maxilla, although some species with a long maxilla have    state 0 or even state 1, such as <i>Paragoniates alburnus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>63. Anterior    region of third infraorbital: (0) not much expanded relative to posterior region    of second infraorbital; (1) abruptly expanded relative to posterior region of    second infraorbital.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the ventral margins of the second and third infraorbitals form a nearly    continuous line, without conspicuous expansions of these bones (state 0; <a href="#f41">Fig.    41</a>). In <i>Hyphessobrycon eques</i> (Boulenger), <i>H</i>. <i>socolofi</i>,    and <i>Pristella maxillaris</i>, the anterior margin of the third infraorbital    is much expanded ventrally relative to the posterior margin of the second infraorbital.    Thus, the line formed by the ventral margins of these bones is not straight    but rather has a sinusoidal shape in the region of articulation between these    elements (state 1; <a href="#f9">Fig. 9</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>64. Ventral    extent of third infraorbital: (0) reaching horizontal arm of preopercle; (1)    not reaching horizontal arm of preopercle, at least anteriorly. (EI5mi, AM23,    UJ51, UJ53, B&Uuml;19m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The ventral extension    of the third infraorbital was used in traditional characid systematics (Eigenmann,    1917) to discriminate some genera (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. <i>Astyanax</i> from    <i>Bryconamericus</i>). In some species the third infraorbital is comparatively    more developed, covering completely the cheek and reaching the horizontal arm    of the preopercle (state 0; <a href="#f29">Fig. 29</a>). In other species instead    it is less developed and there is a "naked" area between the anterior region    of this infraorbital and the preopercle (state 1; <a href="#f33">Fig. 33</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>65. Posterior    extent of third infraorbital: (0) covering angle of preopercle; (1) relatively    reduced, angle of preopercle covered partially by fourth infraorbital. (MO44).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The posteroventral    angle of the preopercle is bordered dorsally by the third infraorbital in most    examined species (state 0; Weitzman, 1962: <a href="#f8">fig. 8</a>, Zanata    &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f3">fig. 3</a>). In <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i>,    <i>Micralestes stormsi</i>, and <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>, the third infraorbital    is relatively less developed, articulating with the fourth infraorbital just    dorsal to the angle of the preopercle (state 1; Roberts, 1974: <a href="#f6">fig.    6</a>). Moreira (2002) mentioned the presence of state 1 as a synapomorphy for    a clade including all the species of the Iguanodectinae except <i>Iguanodectes    geisleri</i> and cited a parallel occurrence of this state in <i>Micralestes    acutidens</i> (Peters). This character is coded as inapplicable in species with    reduced infraorbital lamellae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>66. Fourth infraorbital:    (0) present, well developed; (1) absent or much reduced and bordered posteriorly    by third and fifth infraorbitals. (VA12, LU28m, LC7m, VB14, ZV12, QU16m, PZ34).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most Characiformes    have six infraorbitals (state 0; <a href="#f40">Figs. 40</a> and <a href="#f41">41</a>),    with several reductions in different groups, being the fourth infraorbital most    frequently the absent or reduced infraorbital (state 1; <a href="#f29">Fig.    29</a>). Uj (1990) proposed the reduction or absence of such infraorbital as    diagnostic for his Aphyocharacidae (including the genera <i>Aphyocharax</i>    and <i>Prionobrama</i>), and Vari (1995) mentioned it as a synapomorphy of the    Ctenoluciidae. The presence of the fourth infraorbital is variable among the    examined specimens of <i>Charax stenopterus</i>, <i>Mimagoniates rheocharis</i>,    <i>Hyphessobrycon eques</i>, and <i>Nantis indefessus</i> (Mirande, Aguilera    &amp; Azpelicueta), which are coded as polymorphic. The absence and the extreme    reduction of the fourth infraorbital are variable within some species of 
<i>Aphyocharax</i>,    and both conditions are very different to the presence of six well developed    infraorbitals that is usually present in the Characidae. Therefore it is preferred    to include both conditions in the same state, instead of coding this character    for presence or absence of the fourth infraorbital. This character is coded    as inapplicable to the species in which all the infraorbitals are reduced.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>67. Form of    fourth infraorbital: (0) approximately square or more developed longitudinally    than dorsoventrally; (1) longer dorsoventrally than longitudinally. (SE25m,    BE2, B&Uuml;20).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The form of the    fourth infraorbital is variable among the examined species. The fourth infraorbital    in some species is more developed longitudinally than dorsoventrally or it is    approximately square (state 0; <a href="#f40">Fig. 40</a>), while in others    it is more elongate dorsoventrally (state 1; <a href="#f39">Figs. 39</a> and    <a href="#f41">41</a>). Contrary to the observations of Benine (2004), the examined    specimens of <i>Bario steindachneri</i> and <i>Bryconops melanurus</i> (Bloch)    have state 0 and these species are coded as polymorphic given possible intraspecific    variability. The examined specimen of <i>Knodus breviceps</i> shows an intermediate    state and this species is coded as polymorphic. The examined specimens of <i>Moenkhausia    sanctaefilomenae</i> are variable in this character, and this species is also    coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>68. Posterior    dorsoventral expansion of fourth infraorbital: (0) absent; (1) present. (PZ33).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the fourth infraorbital is approximately square or rectangular and    bordered dorsally by the fifth infraorbital, whose posterior margin is situated    just anterior to the exposed portion of the vertical arm of the preopercle (state    0). In <i>Acestrocephalus sardina</i>, <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i>, <i>Cynopotamus    argenteus</i>, <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i>, <i>Oligosarcus</i> spp., and <i>Rhaphiodon    vulpinus</i> among the examined species, the posterior region of the fourth    infraorbital is dorsoventrally expanded and the fifth infraorbital is displaced    dorsally and relatively distant from the vertical arm of the preopercle (state    1; <a href="#f10">Figs. 10</a> and <a href="#f34">34</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>69. Lateral    coverage of dilator fossa by sixth infraorbital: (0) almost complete, at least    in its ventral border; (1) leaving a conspicuous naked area in anterior region    of dilator fossa. (UJ49m, SE28m, PZ36m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most outgroups    the sixth infraorbital laterally covers the fossa for the <i>dilator operculi</i>    muscle (state 0). A group of species with well developed infraorbitals instead    have the sixth infraorbital leaving a "naked" area in the anterior region of    the dilator fossa (state 1). Uj (1990) mentioned the reduced size of the dermosphenotic    (=sixth infraorbital) in a clade including his Aphyocharacidae (genera <i>Aphyocharax</i>    and <i>Prionobrama</i>), Piabucidae (=Iguanodectinae), Paragoniatidae (=Paragoniatinae),    and Tetragonopteridae (=Tetragonopterinae). This character is coded as inapplicable    to the species in which the dilator fossa is absent or there is a reduction    of the infraorbitals.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Supraorbital:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>70. Supraorbital:    (0) present; (1) absent. (UJ48, VA9, BU21, LU26, MO39, VB13, SE21, BE5, ZV2,    QU15, PZ37).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The supraorbital,    when present, is situated dorsal or anterodorsal to the orbit (state 0: <a href="#f13">Fig.    13</a>; Zanata &amp; Vari: <a href="#f1">figs. 1</a>, <a href="#f2">2</a>, and    <a href="#f4">4</a>). The absence of a supraorbital (state 1) was considered    by Uj (1990) as a synapomorphy for the clade composed of his Aphyocharacidae    (<i>Aphyocharax</i> and <i>Prionobrama</i>), Piabucidae (=Iguanodectinae), Paragoniatidae    (=Paragoniatinae), and Tetragonopteridae (=Tetragonopterinae); however this    character has an ambiguous optimization for that node according to the tree    proposed by Uj. In addition, Vari (1995) mentioned the absence of the supraorbital    as a parallelism for the Erythrinidae and Lebiasinidae. In the phylogenetic    hypothesis of Buckup (1998), the absence of the supraorbital is a synapomorphy    for a clade composed of <i>Charax</i>, <i>Cynopotamus</i> Valenciennes, 
<i>Oligosarcus</i>,    <i>Phenacogaster</i> Eigenmann, and <i>Tetragonopterus</i>. According to Lucena    (1993), the absence of this bone is a synapomorphy independently supporting    a clade composed of <i>Gnathocharax</i> Fowler, <i>Heterocharax</i> Eigenmann,    and <i>Hoplocharax</i> G&eacute;ry, a clade including most members of the Characidae,    and a node composed of the Erythrinidae and Lebiasinidae. Moreira (2002) mentioned    the presence of the supraorbital in all known species of the Iguanodectinae,    differing in that observation from Lucena (1993) and Malabarba &amp; Weitzman    (2003). Malabarba &amp; Weitzman (2003) proposed a clade of characids lacking    the supraorbital composed of the subfamilies Aphyocharacinae, Characinae, Cheirodontinae,    Iguanodectinae, Rhoadsiinae, Stethaprioninae, Tetragonopterinae, some <i>incertae    sedis</i> genera, and their clade A.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>71. Contact    between supraorbital and sixth infraorbital: (0) absent; (1) present. (AM19,    UJ40, CM6(7)i, LU27i, MO40m, ZV5, LI4).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">When present, the    supraorbital is variably developed across the Characiformes. In some species    it is longitudinally reduced and restricted to the anterior region of the dorsal    margin of the orbit, not contacting the sixth infraorbital. In this state the    orbit is margined dorsally by the frontal (state 0; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005:    <a href="#f1">fig. 1A</a>). In some species the posterior region of the supraorbital    is relatively more developed, reaching to the anterior margin of the sixth infraorbital.    In these cases the dorsal margin of the orbit is bordered by these two bones,    which exclude the frontal from this margin (state 1; <a href="#f13">Fig. 13</a>,    Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f13">figs. 1B</a>, 2, and 4). State 0 is    coded only in the cases in which the supraorbital is present but not contacting    the sixth infraorbital. This character is coded as inapplicable for species    in 
which the supraorbital is absent.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Laterosensory    system</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Infraorbital    canal:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>72. Laterosensory    canal in antorbital: (0) absent; (1) present. (UJ41, CM4(5), MO38, SE22m, BE1m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In the examined    species the infraorbitals usually bear laterosensory canal segments. Such canals    are absent in the antorbital (state 0). The presence of a laterosensory canal    in the antorbital (state 1) was proposed as a synapomorphy of <i>Bryconops</i>    by Lucena (1993), and cited also for some species of <i>Brycon</i> M&uuml;ller    &amp; Troschel and <i>Iguanodectes</i> Cope (Malabarba, 1998b; Moreira, 2002).    This character is coded as inapplicable to the species lacking the antorbital.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>73. Laterosensory    canal of first infraorbital: (0) projects dorsally from main body of first infraorbital;    (1) absent or does not projects dorsally. (LU30, CM2(3)i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the first infraorbital bears a laterosensory canal that extends dorsally    to a point near the dorsal margin of the lamellar region of the bone (state    1). In some species this canal projects dorsal to the lamella of the first infraorbital    (state 0; <a href="#f13">Fig. 13</a>). This character is herein considered as    inapplicable to <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>, in which the first infraorbital    appears to be fused with the antorbital. Malabarba (1998b) coded this character    with state 0, among others, in <i>Brycon pesu</i> and <i>Salminus</i> sp. In    the examined specimens of <i>B</i>. <i>pesu</i> and <i>S</i>. <i>brasiliensis</i>    this canal does not project dorsally. This character is coded as polymorphic    in <i>B</i>. <i>pesu</i>, while <i>S</i>. <i>brasiliensis</i> is coded with    state 0, given that the observations of Malabarba (1998b) are from an 
unidentified    species of the genus, and the only available data about this character for <i>S</i>.    <i>brasiliensis</i> is based on the observations made for the present paper.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>74. Branching    of laterosensory canals of fourth or fifth infraorbitals: (0) absent; (1) present.    (BE3i, LI53m, PZ92).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The infraorbital    laterosensory canal usually has a posterior branch oriented towards the dorsal    end of the laterosensory canal in the preopercle or a pore in the vertical arm    of the preopercle. In most examined species this canal is not ossified, but    rather formed by soft tissue and it is situated superficially on the infraorbitals    (state 0). In some species this canal is partially contained in the fourth or    fifth infraorbitals and is evident as an ossified longitudinal branch of the    laterosensory canal (state 1; <a href="#f38">Figs. 38</a>, <a href="#f39">39</a>,    and <a href="#f41">41</a>). This character is coded as polymorphic in <i>Acestrorhynchus    pantaneiro</i>, <i>Acestrocephalus sardina</i>, <i>Astyanax chico</i> Casciotta    &amp; Almir&oacute;n, <i>Cyphocharax spilotus</i> Vari, <i>Deuterodon iguape</i>,    <i>Hyphessobrycon pulchripinnis</i>, <i>Moenkhausia xinguensis</i>, and 
<i>Probolodus    heterostomus</i>, in which this branch is variably present. This character is    coded as inapplicable for species in which the fourth and/or fifth infraorbitals    are reduced or absent.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>75. Direction    of posterior branch of laterosensory canal of fourth or fifth infraorbital:    (0) to a pore on preopercle near hyomandibular condyle; (1) to a pore conspicuously    ventral to hyomandibular condyle.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the posterior branch of the laterosensory canal of the fourth or fifth    infraorbitals is directed towards the dorsal end of the preopercle near the    region of articulation between the hyomandibula and opercle (state 0). In <i>Chalceus    macrolepidotus</i> and <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i> this branch is oriented    to a point approximating half way down the vertical arm of the preopercle (state    1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>76. Laterosensory    canal of sixth infraorbital: (0) not branched; (1) branched. (MO46m, ZV153,    B&Uuml;23, PZ93i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In the generalized    condition in the Characiformes described for <i>Brycon meeki</i> (Weitzman,    1962), the laterosensory canal of the sixth infraorbital is bifurcate, with    one branch directed towards the neurocranium and other anteriorly (state 1;    <a href="#f2">Figs. 2</a> and <a href="#f38">38</a>). Zanata &amp; Vari (2005)    mentioned that the state 1 is broadly distributed in Characiformes and cited    the absence of this canal (state 0; <a href="#f41">Fig. 41</a>) in several characids,    <i>Crenuchus spilurus</i> G&uuml;nther, <i>Serrasalmus rhombeus</i> (Linnaeus),    and a group of alestids; as observed here this branch of the laterosensory canal    is absent in most Characidae. The presence of this branch is variable among    the examined specimens of <i>Roeboexodon geryi</i>, and this species is coded    as polymorphic. This character is considered as inapplicable to <i>Characidium    rachovii</i> 
Regan, <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>, <i>Grundulus cochae</i>,    <i>Hoplocharax goethei</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon elachys</i>, <i>H</i>. <i>luetkenii</i>    (Boulenger), <i>Inpaichthys kerri</i>, <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i> Perugia,    and <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i> in which the sixth infraorbital is extremely    reduced in size or absent.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>77. Position    of opening on neurocranium communicating with laterosensory canal of sixth infraorbital:    (0) between frontal and pterotic; (1) in frontal. (VH38m, MO46m, ZV154m, PZ95).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In the condition    illustrated by Weitzman (1962) and observed in most examined characiforms, the    laterosensory canal of the sixth infraorbital communicates with an opening situated    between the posterior margin of the frontal and the anterior margin of the pterotic    (state 0; <a href="#f34">Fig. 34</a>). In some species this opening is completely    contained by the frontal and anterior to the articulation between that bone    and the pterotic (state 1; <a href="#f18">Fig. 18</a>). Zanata &amp; Vari (2005)    mentioned that state 1 is also present in <i>Brycon pesu</i> and some members    of the family Alestidae. The analyzed specimens of <i>Brycon pesu</i> have the    state 0, but this species is coded as polymorphic considering the observations    of Zanata &amp; Vari (2005). The examined specimens of <i>Bryconamericus alpha</i>,    <i>B</i>. cf. <i>iheringii</i> (Boulenger), <i>B</i>. <i>mennii</i> 
Miquelarena,    Protogino, Filiberto &amp; L&oacute;pez, <i>B</i>. cf. <i>rubropictus</i>, <i>Nantis    indefessus</i>, and <i>Piabina argentea</i> are variable onto this character    and are coded as polymorphic. In <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i> the opening    that receives the canal from the sixth infraorbital is situated completely in    the pterotic, while in <i>Characidium</i> spp. this opening is situated between    the frontal and sphenotic. This character is coded as inapplicable to both species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>78. Position    of opening on neurocranium communicating with sixth infraorbital laterosensory    canal: (0) lateral to or slightly anterior to sphenotic tube for vertical semicircular    canal; (1) distinctly anterior to sphenotic tube for vertical semicircular canal.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The tube for the    vertical semicircular canal is contained within the anterior region of the sphenotic    and it is evident in diaphanized specimens both in lateral and dorsal views.    In most examined species the laterosensory canal of the sixth infraorbital opens    to the neurocranium in a position just lateral or slightly anterolateral to    the sphenotic tube for the vertical semicircular canal (state 0; <a href="#f32">Fig.    32</a>). In a small group of species this opening is instead displaced anterior    to the sphenotic tube for a distance equal to the width of the tube (state 1;    <a href="#f18">Fig. 18</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Dentary-preopercle    canal:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>79. Length of    laterosensory canal of dentary: (0) piercing almost entire length of dentary;    (1) reduced or absent.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, there occurs a branch of the laterosensory canal running from the anterior    region of the dentary to the posterior margin of the anguloarticular and exiting    just dorsal to the region of articulation between the anguloarticular and the    condyle of the quadrate (state 0; <a href="#f42">Fig. 42</a>). In some species    this canal is reduced, being either absent or restricted to the anterior half    of the dentary (state 1). Although this character is probably related with miniaturization,    some medium-sized species, as <i>Bryconamericus rubropictus</i>, have state    1.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>80. Pores of    laterosensory canal of lower jaw: (0) six or less; (1) seven or more.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have three or four laterosensory canal pores piercing the dentary and one pore    between the dentary and the anguloarticular (state 0; <a href="#f43">Fig. 43</a>).    In a small group of species there are six or more pores in the dentary plus    one between the dentary and anguloarticular (state 1; <a href="#f44">Fig. 44</a>).    In <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i> there are many small tubules. As this condition    is not directly comparable to any of the states described herein, this character    is coded as inapplicable to this species. This character is also coded as inapplicable    to species with laterosensory canals of the dentary reduced or absent.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>81. Lateral    surface of vertical canal of preopercle: (0) canal uncovered and situated posteriorly    to musculature and infraorbitals; (1) covered by musculature and/or infraorbitals    (ZV108i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The vertical arm    of the preopercle bears a canal of the laterosensory system. In most examined    species this canal is situated superficially, posterior to the attachment site    of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> and the posterior margins of the third and    fourth infraorbitals (state 0). Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) described the anterior    displacement of this canal, which is situated in a position close to the anterior    margin of the preopercle (state 1; Roberts, 1974: <a href="#f6">fig. 6</a>);    in this state, the laterosensory canal of the vertical arm of preopercle is    not visible laterally because it is covered by musculature and/or infraorbitals.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>82. Dorsal end    of laterosensory canal of preopercle and suprapreopercle: (0) not overlapping    anterodorsal process of opercle; (1) overlapping anterodorsal process of opercle.    (BU26, ZV107).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The laterosensory    canal of the preopercle in most examined species is situated completely anterior    to the anterodorsal margin of the opercle (state 0; <a href="#f34">Fig. 34</a>),    whereas in some species this canal bends laterally around the anterodorsal corner    of the opercle which is often pointed in the form of an "opercular spine" as    described by Vari (1979) (state 1; <a href="#f45">Fig. 45</a>). This character    is herein considered as inapplicable in the species in which this canal is reduced    dorsally and does not reach the anterodorsal margin of the opercle. In the examined    specimens of <i>Aphyocharax anisitsi</i> and <i>Prodontocharax melanotus</i>    this canal slightly laterally overlaps the opercle. This condition is considered    as intermediate between the states herein defined, and this character is coded    as polymorphic for these species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Frontoparietal    canal:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>83. Anterior    region of laterosensory canal of frontal: (0) contained completely on frontal;    (1) opens into a chamber limited dorsally by frontal and ventrally by lateral    ethmoid.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The laterosensory    canal of the frontal extends longitudinally in the region just medial to the    orbit. In almost all the outgroups this canal reaches the anterior margin of    the frontal and is anteriorly contiguous with the nasal canal (state 0; <a href="#f23">Fig.    23</a>). In most members of the ingroup this canal opens anteriorly into a chamber,    which is broad in dorsal and bordered dorsally by the frontal and posteroventrally    by the lateral ethmoid (state 1; <a href="#f2">Fig. 2</a>); this chamber is    situated between the frontal and nasal canals. Intermediate conditions were    observed in <i>Micralestes stormsi</i> and <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i> in    which this character is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>84. Epiphyseal    branch of supraorbital canal: (0) present; (1) absent.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the epiphyseal branch of the supraorbital laterosensory canal extends    medially dorsal to the epiphyseal bar and opens just lateral to the cranial    fontanel (state 0; <a href="#f1">Figs. 1</a> and <a href="#f46">46</a>). In    most members of the Stevardiinae and some other species this branch of the canal    system is instead completely absent (state 1; <a href="#f17">Fig. 17</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>85. Epiphyseal    branch of corresponding supraorbital canals: (0) both aligned with epiphyseal    bar; (1) oriented obliquely, opening posteriorly to epiphyseal bar.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The epiphyseal    laterosensory canals are both aligned with the epiphyseal bar in most species    included in this analysis (state 0; <a href="#f1">Fig. 1</a>). <i>Heterocharax    macrolepis</i> and <i>Triportheus</i> spp., in contrast, have these canals oriented    posteromedially and opening in a position more posterior than the epiphyseal    bar (state 1; <a href="#f46">Fig. 46</a>). Intermediate states were observed    in <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i> and <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i>, which are coded    as polymorphic. This character is considered as inapplicable to the species    in which the epiphyseal branch of the laterosensory canal is lacking.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>86. Opening    of epiphyseal laterosensory canals: (0) along margin of cranial fontanel; (1)    canals continue dorsomedially in soft tissue, opening over or just lateral to    the cranial fontanel.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The epiphyseal    laterosensory canals in most examined species are included in the frontals and    open dorsal to these bones or along the margin of the cranial fontanel (state    0). In a small group of species, these canals are continued dorsomedially by    soft tissue and open over or just lateral to the cranial fontanel (state 1).    An intermediate state was observed in <i>Acestrocephalus sardina</i> and <i>Roeboides    descalvadensis</i>, in which the posterior projections of these canals are present    but reduced in extension. This character is coded as polymorphic for these species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>87. Laterosensory    canal on sphenotic: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most members    of the Characiformes, the laterosensory canal of frontal continues posteriorly    into the pterotic (state 0). As Buckup (1993) noted, in the Characidiinae this    canal continues into the sphenotic, between the frontal and the pterotic segments    (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Posttemporal    canal:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>88. Posterior    branch of posttemporal laterosensory canal: (0) present; (1) absent. (PZ100).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">A laterosensory    canal passes through the extrascapular, posttemporal, and supracleithrum, posteriorly    to the lateral line on the body. This canal has several branches in the extrascapular    and usually is unbranched in the posttemporal and supracleithrum, although small    tubules are usually present in these bones. Tubules of the supracleithrum are    intraspecifically variable in form and number and are not considered in this    paper. A small posterior branch of the posttemporal canal was observed as relatively    intraspecifically stable in some species (state 0; <a href="#f47">Fig. 47</a>).    This branch is absent in most examined species (state 1; <a href="#f48">Fig.    48</a>). The presence of such branch is variable among the examined specimens    of <i>Astyanax lineatus</i>, <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i>, and <i>Rhoadsia altipinna</i>    which are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Lateral line:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>89. Form of    lateral line: (0) approximately straight; (1) curved ventrally in abdominal    region. (EI12m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    outgroups the lateral line is straight along all of its length (state 0), whereas    in the members of the ingroup it is variably curved ventrally in the abdominal    region (state 1). In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> the lateral line is straight,    but this character is coded as polymorphic for the root of the analysis given    that the lateral line is curved ventrally in the supposedly generalized Cypriniformes    <i>Opsariichthys</i> and <i>Zacco</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>90. Degree of    ventral curvature of lateral line: (0) straight or only slightly curved, with    posterior portion aligned with middle caudal-fin rays; (1) distinctly curved    and ventrally situated, with posterior lying within ventral half of caudal peduncle    and aligned with lower lobe of caudal fin. (EI12m, BE89m, ZV164).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The lateral line    is straight or slightly curved in most examined species, with the number of    transverse scale series above the lateral line comparable to the count ventral    of the lateral line. In these species the lateral line ends posteriorly between    the middle caudal-fin rays (state 0). In a small group of examined species,    the lateral line is distinctly curved ventrally anteriorly and runs ventrally    on the lateral surface of the body flank. In these species there are only two    or three scale series ventral to the lateral line and the lateral line runs    along the ventral half of the caudal peduncle, terminating between the caudal-fin    rays of the ventral lobe (state 1). In <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i> the lateral    line runs obliquely from its beginning to the anterior anal-fin rays. This condition    is considered as non-homologous to the defined states, and this character is    coded as 
inapplicable.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>91. Lateral    line: (0) complete; (1) interrupted. (EI2, VA72, MA60m, WM16, SE88, BE88, ZV162,    B&Uuml;153m, QU96).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    a complete lateral line running from the cranium to the caudal peduncle (state    0) versus an interrupted lateral line (state 1) is one of the generic level    characters used by Eigenmann (1917) and it is still used to discriminate various    genera in the Characiformes. However, the reduction of various regions of the    laterosensory system was mentioned for several groups, usually associated with    miniaturization events (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1983; Buckup,    1993). Although this character is probably highly homoplastic, there are supraspecific    taxa, as the genera <i>Aphyocharax</i> and <i>Hollandichthys</i> Eigenmann,    with medium-sized species, that always have an interrupted lateral line. This    is an evidence that, at least, in some level of analysis this character contains    useful phylogenetic information. Variations of this character were observed    in 
<i>Psellogrammus kennedyi</i> (Eigenmann), which is coded as polymorphic.    This character is coded as inapplicable to <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i>, in    which the lateral line runs obliquely to the anterior anal-fin rays instead    of running along the flank to the caudal peduncle.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>92. Canal of    lateral line on caudal-fin membrane: (0) absent; (1) present. (CM49m, ZV163i,    LI58m, B&Uuml;114m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    outgroups with a complete lateral line, the lateral line ends at the posteriormost    perforated scale on the caudal peduncle (state 0). In many examined members    of the Characidae with a complete lateral line an ossified canal continues the    lateral line onto the membrane between the middle caudal-fin rays (state 1;    <a href="#f49">Fig. 49</a>). Although this canal is usually absent in species    with an interrupted lateral line, in some of these species this canal is present.    Therefore the presence or absence of this canal is coded independently from    the extension of the lateral line. This character is coded as inapplicable to    <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i>, in which the lateral line is aligned towards    the anal fin.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>93. Length of    caudal-fin canal of lateral line: (0) reaching only half of caudal-fin length;    (1) almost reaching posterior margin of caudal fin. (LI58m, B&Uuml;114m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Upper jaw</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Maxilla:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>94. Anterior    end of ascending process of maxilla: (0) with conspicuous notch; (1) pointed    or rounded. (LU43, ZV67i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the tip of the ascending process of the maxilla is rounded or variably    pointed (state 1; <a href="#f50">Fig. 50</a>). Lucena (1993) described an anteriorly    bifurcate ascending process of the maxilla (state 0: Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005:    <a href="#f17">figs. 17-18</a>) in the African alestids he examined. Zanata    &amp; Vari (2005) mentioned that the anterior concavity of the ascending process    serves as attachment site for the ligament that joints the maxilla with the    mesethmoid. These authors mentioned the presence of such concavity in <i>Alestes</i>    M&uuml;ller &amp; Troschel, <i>Brycinus</i> Valenciennes, <i>Bryconaethiops</i>    G&uuml;nther, <i>Bryconalestes</i> Hoedeman, and <i>Triportheus albus</i>. The    anterior bifurcation of this process was herein observed in <i>Micralestes stormsi</i>,    a species not included in the analysis of Zanata &amp; Vari (2005). These 
authors    coded as rounded the ascending process of four species of this genus. Within    the Characidae, an anteriorly bifurcate ascending process of the maxilla was    observed only in <i>Aulixidens eugeniae</i>. In the examined specimens of <i>Triportheus</i>    this process is rounded.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>95. Ventral    margin of toothed region of maxilla: (0) approximately straight; (1) strongly    concave.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The ventral margin    of the toothed region of the maxilla is nearly straight in most examined species    (state 0; <a href="#f51">Fig. 51</a>), while the maxilla is strongly convex    in this region in <i>Phenagoniates macrolepis</i>, and <i>Xenagoniates bondi</i>    (state 1; <a href="#f50">Fig. 50</a>). This character is considered as inapplicable    for species with no or just one maxillary tooth.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>96. Margins    of toothed region of maxilla: (0) roughly parallel; (1) dorsally divergent.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the margins of the maxilla run roughly parallel in the toothed region    (state 0). Lucena &amp; Lucena (2002) proposed the dorsal divergence of the    margins of the maxillary lamellar portion as a synapomorphy of the genus <i>Deuterodon</i>    (state 1; <a href="#f52">Fig. 52</a>). Intermediate conditions were observed    in <i>Bryconamericus agna</i> Azpelicueta &amp; Almir&oacute;n and <i>Piabina    argentea</i> and are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>97. Expansion    of lamellar portion of maxilla just posterior to toothed region: (0) absent    or not pronounced; (1) very pronounced.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The ventral margin    of the lamellar portion of maxilla, in most cases, describes a slightly sinusoidal    line posteriorly to the toothed region, when maxillary teeth are present (state    0; <a href="#f50">Fig. 50</a>). In a relatively small number of species, the    lamellar portion of the maxilla is abruptly expanded posteriorly to the insertion    of the teeth. In such cases, the ventral maxillary margin approximately follows    the straight line anteriorly formed by the cusps of the maxillary teeth (state    1; <a href="#f53">Fig. 53</a>). This character is coded as inapplicable in species    lacking maxillary teeth. In <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i> and <i>Rhoadsia altipinna</i>    this character is variable during the ontogeny; young specimens have state 1    and adults have state 0. These species are then coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>98. Tubules    for passage of blood vessels on lamellar portion of maxilla: (0) a single tubule,    parallel to dorsal margin of maxilla; (1) tubule with anterior branch running    parallel to anterior margin of maxilla and reaching one third of its length;    (2) anastomosed tubules. (ZV75m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the lamellar portion of the maxilla is pierced by one or a series of    small tubules, which would serve as a passage for nerves and blood vessels (Menezes,    1976; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005). In many species, there is a single canal parallel    to the dorsal margin of the maxilla (state 0; <a href="#f52">Figs. 52</a> and    <a href="#f53">53</a>). In some species this canal instead is divided in two    conspicuous branches with one of these tubules similar in form and position    to that of state 0, while the other one is anteriorly-directed and runs parallel    to the convex anterior margin of the maxilla in the edentulous region (state    1; <a href="#f54">Fig. 54</a>). In these species the posterior branch is usually    covered laterally by an expansion of the first infraorbital, while the anterior    branch borders this bone when the mouth is closed. In other species these tubules    are 
rather anastomosed (state 2; <a href="#f55">Fig. 55</a>). Since state 1    refers to the arrangement of tubules in the toothless portion of the maxilla,    this character is coded as inapplicable to the species with a completely toothed    laminar region of the maxilla.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>99. Posterior    extent of maxilla: (0) not reaching second infraorbital; (1) reaching second    infraorbital. (BU33, MA8m, VB5m, ZV72m, B&Uuml;53m, QU4m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    members of the Characidae the maxilla reaches posterior to the second infraorbital    (state 1; <a href="#f33">Figs. 33</a> and <a href="#f56">56</a>), while in some    species the relatively shorter maxilla does not reach the second infraorbital    (state 0; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f2">fig. 2</a>). The maxilla does    not reach the second infraorbital in <i>Puntius tetrazona</i>, but <i>Opsariichthys</i>    and basal Siluriformes have the state 1, and the root of this analysis is coded    as polymorphic. This character is also coded as polymorphic for <i>Distichodus    maculatus</i>; in this species the maxilla does not reach the second infraorbital,    but this bone does reach the maxilla in <i>Xenocharax spilurus</i> G&uuml;nther,    which is considered a basal species of the Distichodontidae (Vari, 1979).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>100. Length    of maxilla relative to dentary: (0) maxilla reaching posterior end of Meckelian    cartilage; (1) maxilla not reaching posterior end of Meckelian cartilage.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The length of the    maxilla is usually correlated with the length of the dentary; however, variations    in this correlation are considered in this character. In most examined species    the lamellar portion of the maxilla extends to a point posterior to the posterior    limit of the Meckelian cartilage (state 0; <a href="#f24">Fig. 24</a>). In some    species the lamellar portion of the maxilla is relatively reduced and does not    reach the posterior end of the Meckelian cartilage when the mouth is closed    (state 1; <a href="#f35">Figs. 35</a> and <a href="#f56">56</a>). This character    is coded as polymorphic in <i>Distichodus maculatus</i>, which has state 1,    whereas <i>Xenocharax spilurus</i>, a basal distichodontid, has state 0. This    character is also coded as polymorphic in <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i> and <i>Rhoadsia    altipinna</i>, which have state 1 when young and state 0 when adults.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>101. Ontogenetic    lengthening of maxilla: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species growths of the maxilla during ontogeny is proportional with that of    the remaining bones of the head, and its length is approximately constant in    relation to the other bones (state 0). In members of the subfamily Rhoadsiinae,    the proportional length of the maxilla increases during the ontogeny such that    it becomes proportionally longer in larger individuals (state 1; Eigenmann,    1927: <a href="#f10">figs. 10</a>, <a href="#f13">13</a>, and <a href="#f14">14</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>102. Dorsal    projection of maxilla: (0) not overlaps second infraorbital; (1) overlaps second    infraorbital.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dorsal margin    of the maxilla usually fits to a sheath formed only by the first infraorbital    and, in some species, first and second infraorbitals when the mouth is closed    (state 0). The inverse situation is present in the examined species of <i>Aphyocharax</i>,    in which the maxilla laterally overlaps the second infraorbital when the mouth    is closed (state 1; <a href="#f29">Fig. 29</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Premaxilla:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>103. Interdigitations    between premaxillae: (0) present; (1) absent. (LU37, ZV55i).</b></font></p>
