<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The mesethmoid    spine usually separates almost completely the premaxillae. The premaxillae,    in turn, are usually joined to each other anterior of the mesethmoid solely    by connective tissue and lack bony interdigitations (state 1). Weitzman (1962)    described the presence of bony interdigitations between the premaxillae of <i>Brycon    meeki</i> (state 0; Weitzman, 1962: <a href="#f2">fig. 2</a>). Vari (1979) later    proposed the presence of bony interdigitations between premaxillae as a synapomorphy    of the Citharinoidei.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>104. Length    of ascending process of premaxilla: (0) reaching at least one-third of length    of nasal; (1) reaching just anterior end of nasal. (LU34mi).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The premaxillary    ascending process usually reaches one third or more the length of the nasal,    as described by Weitzman (1962) for <i>Brycon meeki</i> (state 0; <a href="#f21">Fig.    21</a>). This condition is broadly distributed among the members of the Characidae.    In most outgroups and a diverse group within the Characidae, the ascending process    of the premaxilla is relatively shorter, reaching only the anterior end of the    nasal (state 1; <a href="#f18">Figs. 18</a> and <a href="#f26">26</a>). Intermediate    states were observed in <i>Astyanax latens</i>, <i>Bryconamericus mennii</i>,    <i>Diapoma terofali</i>, <i>Hasemania nana</i>, and <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i>,    which are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>105. Alignment    of ascending process of premaxilla: (0) aligned with medial margin of nasal;    (1) medially shifted and separated from nasal.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anterior process    of the mesethmoid usually has a triangular shape with its posterior region as    wide as the dorsal lamella of the mesethmoid, which is in turn situated posterior    to the lateral wings. Since the anterior process medially borders the premaxilla    and the dorsal lamella borders the nasal, the ascending process of premaxilla    is usually aligned with the nasal, or contacts to it medially (state 0; <a href="#f21">Fig.    21</a>). In <i>Aphyocharax</i> spp., <i>Carnegiella strigata</i>, <i>Prionobrama    paraguayensis</i>, and <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i>, the anterior process    of the mesethmoid is much slender relative to the dorsal lamella of the mesethmoid.    In these cases the nasal is consequently distinctly displaced laterally relative    to the ascending process of the premaxilla (state 1; <a href="#f18">Fig. 18</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>106. Form of    posterolateral portion of premaxilla: (0) with notch; (1) with pedicle expanded    laterally to maxilla. (LU36i, ZV52).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The posterolateral    tip of the premaxillary alveolar arm in the members of the Characidae has a    concave surface that receives the ventral margin of the ascending process of    the maxilla (state 0; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f14">fig. 14</a>).    Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) described a projection of the posterior region of the    premaxillary alveolar arm that borders the lateral surface of the proximal region    of the maxilla (state 1; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f13">fig. 13</a>).    These authors cited the presence of this pedicle-like process in most members    of the Alestidae and in the serrasalmids <i>Colossoma macropomum</i> (Cuvier)    and <i>Piaractus mesopotamicus</i>. In the examined specimen of <i>Piaractus    mesopotamicus</i> the posterolateral end of the premaxilla has a concave surface    where the maxilla articulates; the external lobe of this structure is relatively    more developed 
but it does not laterally borders the maxilla and <i>P</i>. <i>mesopotamicus</i>    is consequently coded as state 0 for this character. This character is not directly    comparable in <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> and the root is coded as inapplicable.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Lower jaw</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Anguloarticular:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>107. Lateral    ridge of anguloarticular: (0) absent; (1) present. (B&Uuml;57m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anguloarticular    has two anterior processes, a horizontal process and an oblique anterodorsal    process. The horizontal process is situated along the longitudinal axis of the    dentary and forms the posterior attachment site for the Meckelian cartilage;    it is attached laterally to that cartilage and the coronomeckelian bone. The    oblique process projects towards the posterodorsal margin of the dentary and    usually is smooth or has longitudinal striae on its lateral surface (state 0;    <a href="#f57">Fig. 57</a>). In addition to these striae, some species have    a bony ridge parallel to the anteroventral margin of the oblique process between    its border and the ventral margin of the primordial ligament (state 1; <a href="#f42">Fig.    42</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>108. Horizontal    process of anguloarticular: (0) laterally covered by dentary only anteriorly;    (1) broadly covered by dentary which reaches posterior border of Meckelian cartilage.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anguloarticular    processes articulate with the dentary such that the oblique dorsal process overlaps    the dentary laterally and the horizontal process overlaps it medially. Both    processes are visible laterally in most species with the oblique process completely    visible, but the horizontal process only partially visible due to the overlap    of the dentary which covers it laterally to different degrees. In most species    the dentary laterally covers a relatively small portion of the horizontal process,    which does not reach the vertical through posterior tip of the Meckelian cartilage    (state 0; <a href="#f42">Figs. 42</a> and <a href="#f58">58</a>). In some species    the dentary overlaps a longer portion of the horizontal process of the anguloarticular    and reaches the posterior end of the Meckelian cartilage. In this state the    Meckelian cartilage appears to be completely contained within the 
dentary from    a lateral view, although it is clear in medial view that its posterior portion    is in contact with the anguloarticular (state 1; <a href="#f59">Figs. 59</a>    and <a href="#f60">60</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>109. Ventral    margin of horizontal process of anguloarticular: (0) posteroventrally angled    relative to laterosensory canal of dentary from medial view; (1) perpendicular    to laterosensory canal of dentary from medial view.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The horizontal    process of the anguloarticular articulates medially within the dentary in the    Meckelian fossa, which in turns serves as the attachment area for the Aw section    of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> (Winterbottom, 1974; Howes, 1976). Fibers    from the Aw section usually inserts posteriorly on a tendon from the A2 and    A3 sections of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i>. The anterior portion of this    tendon usually divides in two smaller tendons that attach to the retroarticular    and the medial face of the dentary, respectively (Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005).    The tendon to the dentary inserts anteriorly or anteroventrally to the anteroventral    margin of the anguloarticular at a point just ventral to the laterosensory canal    of the dentary. In most examined species the anteroventral margin of the anguloarticular    is angled with respect to the laterosensory canal of the dentary. In these cases    the 
tendon from the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> attaches anteroventral to the    anguloarticular (state 0; <a href="#f58">Fig. 58</a> and <a href="#f60">60</a>).    In some species the anteroventral margin of the anguloarticular has a sinusoidal    shape, bordering posteriorly the site of attachment of this tendon and crossing    perpendicularly the laterosensory canal of the dentary (state 1; <a href="#f59">Figs.    59</a> and <a href="#f61">61</a>). This character is variable in <i>Astyanax    latens</i> and <i>A</i>. cf. <i>rutilus</i> (Jenyns) which are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Coronomeckelian:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>110. Position    of coronomeckelian: (0) situated mainly lateral to Meckelian cartilage; (1)    situated mainly dorsal to Meckelian cartilage. (SE44).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The coronomeckelian    serves as the attachment site of one of the anterior tendons of the <i>adductor    mandibulae</i> muscle. The size and longitudinal position of the coronomeckelian    are related with the degree of development of this tendon and the length of    the lower jaw. The position of the coronomeckelian along the vertical is variable    among the examined species. In some species the coronomeckelian bone is situated    almost completely dorsal to the Meckelian cartilage (state 1; <a href="#f61">Fig.    61</a>), while in others the bone is located mainly lateral to that cartilage    (state 0; <a href="#f57">Figs. 57</a> and <a href="#f58">58</a>). Several intermediate    cases were observed among the examined species which are coded as polymorphisms.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Dentary:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>111. Interdigitations    between dentaries: (0) absent; (1) present. (UJ18, BU35, LU46m, MA4, ZV82, LI10).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In the Cypriniformes,    Citharinoidei, and some families of the Characoidei the articulation between    the dentaries lacks interdigitations and these bones are joined together only    by connective tissues (Vari, 1979) (state 0). This condition was considered    as plesiomorphic for the Characiformes by Fink &amp; Fink (1981). According    to the phylogenetic hypothesis of Buckup (1998) the presence of bony interdigitations    between dentaries (state 1; <a href="#f60">Figs. 60</a> and <a href="#f61">61</a>)    is a synapomorphy for a clade composed of the Acestrorhynchidae, Alestidae,    Characidae, Ctenoluciidae, Erythrinidae, Hepsetidae, and Lebiasinidae, with    a reversal in <i>Nannostomus</i> G&uuml;nther. The absence of interdigitations    between dentaries was later proposed as a synapomorphy of a cheirodontin clade    composed of <i>Amazonspinther</i> B&uuml;hrnheim, Carvalho, Malabarba &amp;    Weitzman and 
<i>Spintherobolus</i> by B&uuml;hrnheim <i>et al</i>. (2008).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>112. Form of    interdigitations between dentaries: (0) simple bony lamellae; (1) undulate lamellae.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The number of interdigitations    between dentaries varies ontogenetically (Miquelarena, 1986), but some differences    have been observed in the form of these lamellae. In most of the examined species    the lamellae forming these interdigitations are simple, disposed horizontally,    and parallel each other (state 0). Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) described the undulation    of margins of these lamellae (state 1; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f22">fig.    22</a>) for some African members of the family Alestidae. This character is    coded as inapplicable in species lacking interdigitations between the dentaries.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>113. Form and    dentition of anterior region of dentary: (0) toothed and not depressed anteriorly;    (1) edentulous and much depressed anteriorly.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dentary is    usually toothed and not depressed anteriorly in characiforms (state 0), while    in the Parodontidae, the dentary is edentulous and much depressed anteriorly    (state 1; <i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. Roberts, 1974: <a href="#f61">fig. 61</a>). Some    members of this family, however, have teeth along the lateral margins of the    dentary. In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> and the Cypriniformes in general, the dentary    lacks teeth, but that bone is not anteriorly depressed as in the Parodontidae.    The members of the Curimatidae lack dentary teeth when adults, but teeth are    present in juveniles. <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i> and almost all the    genera of the Hemiodontidae lack dentary teeth, but the anterior margin of the    dentary is not depressed as it is in the members of the Parodontidae (Roberts,    1974). All of these taxa were coded as state 0.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>114. Medial    anteroventral notch of dentary: (0) absent; (1) present. (BU37m, LU48m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    a notch along the anteroventral medial border of the dentary (state 1; <a href="#f62">Fig.    62</a>) was observed in <i>Iguanodectes geisleri</i>, <i>Phenagoniates macrolepis</i>    and <i>Xenagoniates bondi</i>, whereas in most examined species the ventral    margin of the dentary is straight or slightly curved in this area (state 0).    An anteroventral notch in the dentary was illustrated by Weitzman (1964) for    <i>Poecilobrycon harrisoni</i> and this character was considered typical of    the Pyrrhulinini (=Pyrrhulininae, Lebiasinidae) by him. However, as described    by Weitzman (1964) this notch is continuous with the dentary foramen for the    mental ramus of the mandibular branch of trigeminus nerve, while the notch herein    considered is not related with the dentary foramen.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>115. Medial    process of dentary bordering Meckelian cartilage dorsally and medially: (0)    absent; (1) present. (MO9).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">According to Moreira    (2002, 2003) the presence of a medial process in the dentary constitutes a synapomorphy    for the Iguanodectinae (state 1; <a href="#f62">Fig. 62</a>), with this process    absent (state 0; <a href="#f60">Fig. 60</a>) in the remaining species examined    by him. This process was herein observed only in <i>Iguanodectes geisleri</i>    and <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>. In these species such a process medially borders    a portion of the Meckelian cartilage and serves as an area of attachment for    a tendon from the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> which inserts in the dentary, ventral    to the Meckelian cartilage in other species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>116. Bony lamella    covering dentary foramen laterally: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dentary foramen    serves as a passage for nerves and blood vessels and is situated just dorsal    and anterior to the anterior tip of the Meckelian cartilage. This foramen is    usually evident in lateral view (state 0; <a href="#f43">Figs. 43</a> and <a href="#f63">63</a>).    In <i>Acestrocephalus sardina</i>, <i>Cynopotamus argenteus</i>, and <i>Galeocharax    humeralis</i>, among the examined species, this foramen is covered laterally    by a bony lamella and is not evident from a lateral view (state 1; <a href="#f44">Fig.    44</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>117. Longitudinal    ridge covering laterosensory pores of dentary: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The laterosensory    canal of the dentary has a variable number of pores. These pores are evident    in ventrolateral view in most examined species (state 0). In <i>Charax stenopterus</i>    and the examined species of <i>Roeboides</i> G&uuml;nther, there is a longitudinal    bony ridge covering partially these pores which are thus visible only from a    ventral view (state 1; <a href="#f57">Fig. 57</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Dentition</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Generalities:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>118. Morphology    of premaxillary, maxillary, and dentary teeth: (0) all teeth conical, caniniform,    or mamilliform; (1) some teeth multicuspidate or molariform. (FF44m, UJ2, BU72m,    LU47m, LC23m, LU53m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">According to Uj    (1990), the presence of multicuspidate teeth (state 1) is a synapomorphy of    the Characiformes, although his conclusion was not based in a cladistic analysis    but in the optimization of certain features on a tree arrived at without an    explicit phylogenetic method. Lucena (1993) considered this variation under    two different characters, involving the maxillary and dentary teeth respectively.    According to the phylogeny proposed by Lucena (1993) the possession of multicuspidate    teeth constitute independent synapomorphies for the Lebiasinidae and a clade    including most of the Characidae, with a reversal to conical teeth in a clade    composed of the genera <i>Aphyocharax</i> and <i>Phenacogaster.</i></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>119. Premaxillary,    maxillary, and dentary teeth: (0) not pedunculate, or pedunculate only in some    of these bones; (1) pedunculate and uniformly shaped. (MA55m, MA56m, B&Uuml;70m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Multicuspidate    teeth of most species, when present, have a broad base and somewhat variable    form and size on the premaxilla, maxilla, and dentary (state 0). The presence    of pedunculate teeth of similar form in the upper and lower jaws (state 1; <a href="#f42">Figs.    42</a> and <a href="#f53">53</a>) was mentioned as two independent synapomorphies    for the Cheirodontinae by Malabarba (1998a). The presence of pedunculate teeth    on the premaxilla, maxilla, and dentary was observed in this study in most of    the examined members of the Cheirodontinae and in <i>Gymnocharacinus bergii</i>    and <i>Odontostoechus lethostigmus</i>. Although the teeth of the latter two    species are less compressed that those in members of the Cheirodontinae, they    are coded with the state 1 based on overall form. The teeth in both jaws of    <i>Odontostilbe pequira</i> are pedunculate, but having a slightly different    
morphology; this species, however, is also coded as state 1 given the small    degree of that difference.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Premaxillary    teeth:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>120. Mamilliform    teeth outside mouth: (0) absent; (1) present. (LU41mi).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    teeth outside the mouth (state 1; <a href="#f16">Figs. 16</a> and <a href="#f21">21</a>)    associated with lepidophagous habits has been cited for several genera in the    Characiformes. Such dentition is absent in most examined species (state 0).    The presence of three mamilliform teeth on the premaxilla oriented outside the    oral cavity was proposed by Lucena (1993) as a synapomorphy of <i>Roeboides</i>.    <i>Exodon paradoxus</i> and <i>Roeboexodon geryi</i> have only one or two mamilliform    teeth in the premaxilla. Since the morphology of such teeth is very similar    to those of <i>Roeboides</i>, these species are coded with the state 1 of this    character. The teeth of <i>Probolodus heterostomus</i> have a similar overall    shape to those present in <i>Roeboides</i>, but are tricuspidate. In <i>Bryconexodon    juruenae</i> there is variation between unicuspidate and tricuspidate 
mamilliform    teeth which are much similar to those of <i>Exodon</i> M&uuml;ller &amp; Troschel    and <i>Roeboexodon</i> G&eacute;ry and <i>Probolodus</i> Eigenmann, respectively.    Given the extra-oral position of the teeth of <i>Bryconexodon juruenae</i> and    <i>Probolodus heterostomus</i> and the rather similar shape of these teeth with    those of the species of <i>Roeboides</i> both species are coded as state 1.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>121. A pair    of large conical teeth in premaxilla: (0) absent; (1) present. (LU40i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    characids there are one to three rows of teeth in the premaxilla; the teeth    of each row are usually rather homogeneous in morphology (state 0). Lucena (1993)    mentioned the presence of two conical teeth much larger than the remaining ones,    situated near the tips of the premaxillary alveolar ramus (state 1; <a href="#f51">Fig.    51</a>) in several characids. In the examined specimens of <i>Charax stenopterus</i>    these teeth are slightly larger than the remaining ones, and this species is    coded with state 1.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>122. Number    of rows of premaxillary teeth: (0) one; (1) two or three. (AM27m, LU38m, LU39m,    BU32m, MA55m, CM37, MO3, VB75i, BE27, ZV57, LI11m, B&Uuml;35m, QU80m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>123. Number    of rows of premaxillary teeth: (0) one or two; (1) three. (EI4m, AM27m, LU38m,    LU39m, BU32m, MA55m, CM37, MO3, VB75i, BE27, ZV57, LI11m, B&Uuml;35m, QU80m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The homology between    the premaxillary rows of teeth among different species is not always easy to    establish, especially when entire rows are lacking. The main criterion used    herein to recognize, at least tentatively, teeth from different rows is developmental.    The premaxillary teeth from the anterior two rows have intraosseous development    (<i>sensu</i> Trapani, 2001), while those from the inner row have extraosseous    development, growing in the soft connective tissue situated posterior to the    alveolar ramus of the premaxilla. However, in some cases the discrimination    between teeth from different rows could only be done following a topological    criterion. Three states can be recognized among the examined species. In some    species only one row of premaxillary teeth, with extraosseous development, is    present (character 122, state 0). An anterior row of teeth, with intraosseous    development, is 
present in most of the Characidae resulting in two rows of premaxillary    teeth (character 122, state 1; character 123, state 0; <a href="#f64">Fig. 64</a>).    In a relatively small group of species there is an additional row of teeth,    which also has intraosseous development but whose homology is difficult to establish    and remains to be studied in detail. In the latter state there are three rows    of premaxillary teeth (character 123, state 1; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f15">fig.    15</a>). As noted above, according to the hypothesis of Lucena (1993) the presence    of two premaxillary rows of teeth is a synapomorphy for a clade corresponding    to the Characidae, with parallel reversals to a single row in a clade composed    of the genera <i>Roestes</i>, <i>Lonchogenys</i> Myers, <i>Heterocharax</i>,    <i>Gnathocharax</i>, and <i>Hoplocharax</i>, and the clade composed of <i>Hemigrammopetersius</i>    Pellegrin and <i>Hydrocynus</i> Cuvier. According to Lucena 
(1993) the possession    of three rows of premaxillary teeth constitutes two independent synapomorphies    for the clades composed of <i>Creagrutus</i> and <i>Piabina</i> and <i>Brycon</i>    and <i>Chalceus</i>, respectively. In the hypothesis of Buckup (1998) the presence    of two or three premaxillary rows of teeth is a synapomorphy for a group composed    of the Alestidae, Characidae, Ctenoluciidae, Hepsetidae, Lebiasinidae, Erythrinidae,    and Acestrorhynchidae, with a reversion in a subclade formed by the last five    families. This is, however, just one of the possible most parsimonious optimizations    for this character &#91;the optimization produced by ACCTRAN (de Pinna, 1991)&#93;.    It is equally parsimonious to propose parallel acquisitions of two or more premaxillary    rows of teeth in the Alestidae and Characidae without reversals. Malabarba (1998a)    proposed the presence of only one functional row of smoothly aligned and similarly    shaped premaxillary teeth as 
a synapomorphy of the subfamily Cheirodontinae.    According to the phylogenetic hypothesis of Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) the presence    of two rows of premaxillary teeth is plesiomorphic for the Characiformes. The    first of these characters is coded herein as inapplicable to <i>Acestrorhynchus    pantaneiro</i>, <i>Bryconexodon juruenae</i>, <i>Charax stenopterus</i>, <i>Cynopotamus    argenteus</i>, <i>Exodon paradoxus</i>, <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i>, <i>Heterocharax    macrolepis</i>, <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>, <i>Hoplocharax goethei</i>,    <i>Lonchogenys ilisha</i>, <i>Oligosarcus</i> cf. <i>jenynsii</i>, <i>O</i>.    <i>bolivianus</i>, <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>, <i>Roeboexodon geryi</i>, <i>Roeboides</i>    spp., and <i>Serrasalmus maculatus</i>. Although some of these species have    a single premaxillary tooth row, these teeth are variable in size and/or morphology,    probably corresponding to teeth from both the outer and the inner rows of other    species. 
In <i>Apareiodon affinis</i> and <i>Parodon nasus</i> the premaxillary    teeth originate from deep grooves separated by vertical lamellae; this condition    is not comparable to that of the outer row of other species, and the character    122 is coded as inapplicable for these species. The single premaxillary teeth    row of <i>Leporinus striatus</i> has an intraosseous development and it was    thus considered as non-homologous with the outer row of other species. Quevedo    (2006) coded <i>Paragoniates alburnus</i> as having just one premaxillary tooth    row; however, in the specimen examined here, there are two teeth situated distinctly    anterior of the remaining five teeth, as if they were in a separate anterior    row. The first of these characters is coded as polymorphic for <i>P</i>. <i>alburnus</i>,    considering possible intraspecific variations. A variable presence of one or    two premaxillary tooth rows was mentioned in the description of <i>Inpaichthys    kerri</i> 
(G&eacute;ry &amp; Junk, 1977). In the observed specimens all the    premaxillary teeth have extraosseous development and would be homologous to    the teeth from the inner row of other species. <i>Inpaichthys kerri</i> is consequently    coded as state 0 of the character 122. The teeth of the genera <i>Creagrutus</i>    and <i>Piabina</i> were described by Vari &amp; Harold (2001) as composed of    a triangular cluster of medial teeth (or triad), a primary row of teeth, and    a single lateral tooth, which may be either present or absent. Although this    characterization is useful to compare between species of these two genera, it    is not easy to homologize the teeth of these genera with those of other characids    based on these definitions. The primary row, as described by Vari &amp; Harold    (2001) is composed of teeth that have both intraosseous (those situated medially)    and extraosseous development (those situated just lateral to the posterior teeth    of the triad), 
which differs from the criteria used herein to recognize homologies    between tooth rows. These definitions can be seen as homology statements which    are useful at different levels of analysis; however, there is clearly still    much uncertainty relative to the homologies between characid tooth rows. The    analyzed species of <i>Creagrutus</i> are coded with the state 1 of the character    123, while <i>Piabina argentea</i> is coded as polymorphic for this character,    given that its teeth could be interpreted as disposed in three rows or in two    rows, with the anteriormost in a zigzag pattern. These characters are considered    as inapplicable to species lacking premaxillary teeth.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Outer row of    premaxillary teeth:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>124. Alignment    of teeth on anterior premaxillary row: (0) aligned; (1) not aligned, with one    or two teeth situated anterior to remaining teeth.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most species    with two rows of premaxillary teeth, the anterior row is composed of teeth aligned    in a shallow arch (state 0; <a href="#f65">Figs. 65</a>). In <i>Bryconamericus    exodon</i> and <i>B</i>. cf. <i>exodon</i>, there are one or two teeth relatively    displaced anteriorly, giving to the outer row a zigzag-shape (state 1). The    correspondence between these anteriorly displaced teeth with those of the outer    row in species with three rows of premaxillary teeth is unclear; therefore,    this character is considered inapplicable to species coded as having three premaxillary    rows of teeth. The examined specimens of <i>Bryconamericus scleroparius</i>    (Regan), <i>Hemibrycon dariensis</i>, <i>H</i>. <i>surinamensis</i>, and <i>Knodus    breviceps</i> have intermediate conditions that are coded as polymorphisms.    This character is coded as inapplicable to species lacking an outer row of 
premaxillary    teeth with intraosseous development.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>125. Cusps of    teeth on outer premaxillary row: (0) one to three cusps; (1) five or more cusps.    (BE28).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The premaxillary    teeth of the outer tooth row are relatively slender and tricuspidate in most    examined species (state 0; <a href="#f55">Fig. 55</a>). In a relatively small    group of species these teeth are instead expanded distally and have five or    more cusps (state 1; <a href="#f66">Fig. 66</a>). In the examined specimens    of <i>Astyanax</i> cf. <i>rutilus</i>, <i>Bryconamericus alpha</i>, and <i>Hemibrycon    dariensis</i> the teeth of the outer premaxillary row have five cusps, but the    lateral ones are minute and the distal portion of teeth is not expanded. This    condition is thus considered to be intermediate, and these species are coded    as polymorphic. This character is coded as inapplicable to species with only    one row of premaxillary teeth.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Inner row of    premaxillary teeth:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>126. Teeth on    inner premaxillary row: (0) molariform; (1) with aligned in straight series    or anteriorly concave pattern of cusps; (2) with anteriorly concave pattern    plus anterior cusps. (ZV64m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The cusps of teeth    of the inner premaxillary row, when present, are either aligned in a straight    line or form an anteriorly concave arch (state 1; <a href="#f64">Figs. 64</a>,    <a href="#f65">65</a>, and <a href="#f67">67</a>). In <i>Alestes</i> cf. <i>macrophthalmus</i>,    <i>Brycinus carolinae</i>, and <i>Bryconaethiops macrops</i>, among the examined    species, there is, in addition, a series of anterior cusps separated by a concave    surface from the posterior cusps. The anterior series of cusps and the concave    surface jointly give to these teeth a molariform aspect (state 2; Zanata &amp;    Vari, 2005: <a href="#f15">fig. 15</a>). The teeth of the inner premaxillary    row in <i>Metynnis maculatus</i> and <i>Piaractus mesopotamicus</i> have a molariform    form, but their anterior margin is not formed by a series of cusps, but rather    an even margin (state 0). This character is considered as 
inapplicable to species    lacking a defined inner row of premaxillary teeth.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>127. Alignment    of cusps of medial teeth on inner premaxillary row: (0) forming anteriorly concave    semicircle from ventral view; (1) forming shallow arch or aligned in straight    series from ventral view. (ZV63i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">As mentioned above,    the cusps of the inner premaxillary teeth row have an anteriorly concave arrangement    from ventral view. In most examined species this concavity is relatively shallow,    describing approximately one-fourth of a circle, or less, from ventral view    (state 1; <a href="#f64">Figs. 64</a> and <a href="#f67">67</a>). Zanata &amp;    Vari (2005) mentioned that this concavity is much pronounced (state 0; <a href="#f65">Fig.    65</a>) in some alestids and in the characid <i>Triportheus albus</i>. An intermediate    state was herein observed in <i>Bryconops affinis</i> G&uuml;nther, which is    coded as polymorphic. This character is coded as inapplicable to species without    a definite inner row of premaxillary teeth.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>128. Form of    teeth of inner premaxillary tooth row: (0) with cusps forming anteriorly concave    arch; (1) with cusps aligned in straight series and without anterior concavity.    (MO4).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">As mentioned above    the anterior surface of the teeth of the inner premaxillary row has an anteriorly    oriented concavity in ventral view resulting from the arched position of the    cusps on these teeth (state 0; <a href="#f64">Figs. 64</a> and <a href="#f65">65</a>).    In a relatively small group of species these teeth are much compressed anteroposteriorly    and, from a ventral view, their cusps follow an almost straight line (state    1; <a href="#f67">Fig. 67</a>). This character and the preceding one represent    a series of nested homologies and they can be seen as a single additive character    with three states. This character is considered as inapplicable to those species    lacking a defined inner row of premaxillary teeth. Both this character and the    preceding one are coded as inapplicable to <i>Agoniates anchovia</i>, <i>Aphyocharax</i>    spp., <i>Aphyodite grammica</i>, <i>Axelrodia lindeae</i>, 
<i>Grundulus cochae</i>,    <i>Inpaichthys kerri</i>, <i>Microschemobrycon casiquiare</i>, <i>Parecbasis    cyclolepis</i>, <i>Prionobrama paraguayensis</i>, <i>Roeboides microlepis</i>,    and <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i> which have conical teeth or with minute lateral    cusps.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>129. Number    of teeth in inner premaxillary row: (0) four or fewer; (1) five or more. (VB76,    BE29i, ZV61i, B&Uuml;41m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>130. Number    of teeth in inner premaxillary row: (0) seven or fewer; (1) eight or more. (B&Uuml;41m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    four teeth on the inner premaxillary row (character 129, state 0) was used in    the generic key of Eigenmann (1917) to distinguish <i>Argopleura</i> Eigenmann,    <i>Bryconamericus</i>, <i>Ceratobranchia</i>, <i>Creagrutus</i>, <i>Hemibrycon</i>,    <i>Knodus</i>, <i>Microgenys</i>, <i>Nematobrycon</i> Eigenmann, and <i>Piabina</i>    from the remaining characids, which usually have five teeth in that series (character    129, state 1; character 130, state 0; <a href="#f64">Fig. 64</a>). G&eacute;ry    (1977) included most genera with four teeth on the inner premaxillary row in    his tribe Tetragonopterini, within a subgroup therein called "genus <i>Hemibrycon</i>    and allied genera" which included <i>Boehlkea</i>, <i>Bryconacidnus</i>, <i>Bryconamericus</i>,    <i>Carlastyanax</i> G&eacute;ry, <i>Ceratobranchia</i>, <i>Coptobrycon</i> G&eacute;ry,    <i>Creagrudite</i> Myers, <i>Hemibrycon</i>, 
<i>Knodus</i>, <i>Microgenys</i>,    <i>Nematobrycon</i>, <i>Piabarchus</i>, <i>Rhinobrycon</i>, and <i>Rhinopetitia</i>.    Although the phylogenetic importance of the possession of four premaxillary    teeth on the inner row was not adequately tested, this character was later proposed    by Malabarba &amp; Weitzman (2003) to be a putative synapomorphy of their clade    A. The presence of eight or more teeth on the inner premaxillary row (character    130, state 1; <a href="#f68">Fig. 68</a>) was mentioned by B&uuml;hrnheim (2006)    for several small species of the Characidae. The first of these characters is    coded as polymorphic in <i>Bryconamericus</i> cf. <i>rubropictus</i>, <i>Cyanocharax    alburnus</i>, <i>Diapoma terofali</i>, and <i>Hemibrycon surinamensis</i>, and    the second one in <i>Aphyocharax dentatus</i> Eigenmann &amp; Kennedy, <i>Inpaichthys    kerri</i>, and <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>131. Polymorphism    of teeth on inner premaxillary row: (0) absent; (1) present, with two medial    teeth somewhat larger and usually separated from remaining ones by a gap.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the two medial teeth of the inner premaxillary tooth row are slightly    larger than the remaining teeth, although the homology of these teeth in different    species is unclear. These medial teeth are probably homologous to the posterior    teeth of the triad described by Vari &amp; Harold (2001) for <i>Creagrutus</i>    and <i>Piabina</i>. Apparently this identification was followed by Zanata &amp;    Vari (2005: 34), who considered <i>Brycon</i> and <i>Triportheus</i> to have    two teeth on the posteriormost premaxillary row of teeth, corresponding to the    medial teeth of the inner row. Although the homology of the premaxillary teeth    of different species remains to be studied, the teeth from the posteriormost    premaxillary row of the examined species are usually concave anteriorly and    have extraosseous development. In <i>Brycon</i> spp., <i>Metynnis maculatus</i>,    <i>Piaractus 
mesopotamicus</i>, and <i>Triportheus</i>, among the examined species,    these medial teeth are slightly larger and separated from the lateral ones by    a gap (state 1). In other species the two medial teeth are not distinctly larger    than the third tooth and the second and third tooth are separated each other    in the same extent than the remaining pairs of teeth of the inner premaxillary    tooth row (state 0).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>132. Number    of replacement tooth rows on premaxilla: (0) one; (1) two or more.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have a single series of inner premaxillary row replacement teeth that demonstrate    extraosseous development and which usually become functional simultaneously    (state 0). <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i> and the examined species of the    Parodontidae have two or more rows of replacement teeth which apparently become    functional sequentially (state 1; <i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. Roberts, 1974: <a href="#f7">fig.    7</a>). Although the homology of particular teeth among Characiformes is uncertain,    the simultaneous presence of two or more rows of replacement premaxillary teeth    with, at least partially, extraosseous development is tentatively coded as present    in the members of the Hemiodontidae and Parodontidae and as absent in the remaining    species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>133. Fossa for    inner row of replacement premaxillary teeth: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The teeth of the    inner premaxillary row in most examined species undergo a completely extraosseous    development being formed in the soft connective tissue just posterior to the    premaxilla (state 0). In a small group of species these teeth rather form within    shallow cavities or fossae situated on the posterior surface of the premaxilla    (state 1; <a href="#f68">Fig. 68</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Maxillary teeth:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>134. Maxillary    teeth: (0) absent; (1) present. (LU44m, MO6m, SE46m, BE34m, ZV78, LI12, B&Uuml;54m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence (state    1) or absence (state 0) of maxillary teeth was longly considered as significant    in the classification of the Characidae. This character is coded as polymorphic    in <i>Hasemania nana</i>, <i>Hemigrammus bleheri</i>, <i>Moenkhausia dichroura</i>,    and <i>Thayeria obliqua</i>, in which there occurs either cited or herein observed    variation in this character.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>135. Number    of maxillary teeth: (0) only one, or absent; (1) two or more. (LU45m, WM42m,    CM38m, BE34m, VH7m, B&Uuml;54m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>136. Number    of maxillary teeth: (0) up to three; (1) four or more. (LU45m, WM42m, CM38m,    BE34m, VH7m, B&Uuml;54m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The number of maxillary    teeth has been considered in almost all published phylogenies of genera and    subfamilies of the Characidae. The variation in number of maxillary teeth, however,    is almost continuous among the examined species, and any definition of discrete    states within this character would have some degree of subjectivity. The number    of maxillary teeth is not distributed normally among the examined species, and    many species have none (<a href="#f54">Fig. 54</a>) to four teeth, while relatively    few have more than ten teeth. In species with low number of maxillary teeth,    this number is relatively more stable intraspecifically, and differences between    one or two teeth could be phylogenetically informative, while species with high    numbers of maxillary teeth also have relatively higher intraspecific variations    in this feature, and the gaining or loss of one teeth has comparatively 
less    correlation with phylogeny and species discrimination. The option of analyzing    this character as a lineal continuous character, implemented in TNT (Goloboff    <i>et al</i>., 2003, 2006), tends to overestimate the phylogenetic information    of the transformations in groups with higher and variable number of maxillary    teeth, in relation to groups with lower number of teeth (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>.    a transformation between one to three teeth will have lower weight than a transformation    between 20 to 25 teeth). The coding of this character takes into account both    personal observations and published information about the number of maxillary    teeth in order to consider intraspecific variations, which in several species    results in polymorphisms.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>137. Extent    of implantation of teeth along maxilla: (0) not reaching middle of maxillary    lamella; (1) extending across almost entire maxillary lamella. (EI3, LU44m,    MO6, VB79, SE46m, QU82).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The posterior extent    of the area of implantation of the maxillary teeth is one of the "generic" level    characters proposed by Eigenmann (1917). Eigenmann noted the presence of teeth    along the entire anterior margin of the maxilla (state 1; <a href="#f51">Figs.    51</a> and <a href="#f69">69</a>) in <i>Hollandichthys</i>, <i>Nematobrycon</i>,    <i>Phenacogaster</i>, and <i>Pseudochalceus</i> Kner. Lucena (1993) divided    this character to three states, considering the absence of maxillary teeth,    the presence of teeth only in the anterior half of the maxillary margin (state    0; <a href="#f68">Fig. 68</a>), and the presence of teeth along the entire anterior    margin of the maxilla. The examined specimens of <i>Odontostoechus lethostigmus</i>    and <i>Probolodus heterostomus</i> have teeth only in the anterior half of the    maxillary lamella, and these species are coded with state 0. In <i>Carlana</i>    
Strand and <i>Rhoadsia</i> Fowler, the maxilla is progressively longer and bears    an increasingly number of teeth during ontogeny, with the dentition extending    along the entire maxillary margin in adult specimens. Given that young specimens    of <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i> and <i>Rhoadsia altipinna</i> have state 0 and    adults exhibit state 1, these species are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>138. Number    of cusps of anterior maxillary teeth: (0) conical, a single cusp; (1) three    or more cusps. (LU43m, MO7m, VB81m, SE48m, BE35, B&Uuml;55i, QU81m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>139. Number    of cusps of anterior maxillary teeth: (0) up to three; (1) five or more cusps.    (LU43m, MO7m, VB81m, SE48m, BE35, B&Uuml;55i, QU81m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Maxillary teeth    usually have a similar morphology to that from the other jaw bones; however,    some species with five or more cusps in the premaxillary and dentary teeth,    have only conical (character 138, state 0; <a href="#f69">Fig. 69</a>) or tricuspidate    (character 138, state 1; character 139, state 0; <a href="#f50">Fig. 50</a>)    teeth on the maxilla. Although the number of cusps on the maxillary teeth is    somewhat correlated with the number of cusps of other teeth, it is coded as    a separate character as a function of the lack of correlation in some species.    Five cusps were herein observed <i>Bryconops melanurus</i> instead of three,    as reported by Benine (2004), and this species is coded as polymorphic. Benine    (2004) mentioned the presence of five or more cusps in the maxillary teeth (character    139, state 1; <a href="#f52">Fig. 52</a>), among others, in <i>Bario steindachneri</i>,    
<i>Hemigrammus unilineatus</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon eques</i>, and <i>Poptella    paraguayensis</i> (Eigenmann). This character is variable among the examined    specimens of <i>Bario steindachneri</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon eques</i>, and <i>Poptella    paraguayensis</i>, which are coded as polymorphic for character 139. The examined    specimen of <i>Hemigrammus unilineatus</i> has only three cusps on the maxillary    teeth. This character is also coded as polymorphic for this species following    the observations of Benine (2004). The maxillary teeth of <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i>    are essentially conical but have lateral projections that appear to be rudimentary    cusps. This condition is herein considered to be intermediate between the states    defined for the character 138, and <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i> is coded as    polymorphic for this character. Variation in the character 139 was observed    in <i>Astyanax chico</i>, <i>A</i>. cf. <i>eigenmanniorum</i>, <i>A</i>. 
<i>endy</i>    Mirande, Aguilera &amp; Azpelicueta, <i>A</i>. <i>lineatus</i>, <i>Bryconops    affinis</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon anisitsi</i> (Eigenmann), <i>H</i>. <i>eques</i>,    <i>Prodontocharax melanotus</i>, and <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i> and this    character is coded as polymorphic for these species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>140. Ontogenetic    acquisition of conical teeth on maxilla: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The proportional    lengthening of the maxilla and the acquisition of conical maxillary teeth during    the ontogeny (state 1; <a href="#f70">Fig. 70</a>), were mentioned above as    characteristic for members of the subfamily Rhoadsiinae by Fink &amp; Weitzman    (1974). Notwithstanding those observations, Fink &amp; Weitzman classified the    genus <i>Carlana</i> within the "so-called Cheirodontin fishes" due to the presence    of only one row of premaxillary teeth. <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i> and <i>Rhoadsia    altipinna</i>, the only analyzed members of Rhoadsiinae, are herein coded as    state 1. This character is coded as unknown for <i>Nematocharax venustus</i>    Weitzman, Menezes &amp; Britski; although the maxillary dentition of adults    of this species bear certain similarities with that of the Rhoadsiinae, an ontogenetic    series of this species was unavailable for study and this character could not    be 
analyzed.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Dentary teeth:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>141. Orientation    of anterior dentary teeth: (0) oriented dorsally or anterodorsally; (1) oriented    anteriorly, almost parallel to main axis of dentary.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the anterior teeth of dentary are situated perpendicular to or slightly    oblique to the longitudinal axis of the bone, (state 0; <a href="#f60">Fig.    60</a>). Some species instead have the anteriormost dentary teeth oriented anteriorly,    in a plane almost parallel to the longitudinal axis of the dentary (state 1;    <a href="#f45">Fig. 45</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>142. Size and    number of anterior dentary teeth: (0) four or five relatively broad teeth at    front of dentary; (1) eight or more small and slender teeth at front of dentary.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have four or five relatively broad teeth situated in the anterior region of    the dentary (state 0; <a href="#f59">Fig. 59</a>). In a relatively small group    of species, the anterior dentary teeth are more slender, and eight or more teeth    are situated at the anterior portion of the dentary (state 1). This character    is coded as polymorphic in <i>Grundulus cochae</i> which has six or seven teeth    in the anterior region of the dentary.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>143. Inner row    of dentary teeth: (0) present; (1) absent. (UJ50, BU36i, LU49i, CM41m, MO10,    SE63m, LI13m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The inner row of    dentary teeth, when present, is situated just posterior to the replacement fossa    for the anterior dentary teeth (Buckup, 1998) (state 0; <a href="#f90">Figs.    60</a> and <a href="#f71">71</a>). This inner row of dentary teeth is absent    in most members of the Characidae (state 1). <i>Distichodus</i> and <i>Triportheus</i>    were coded as state 1 by Buckup (1998) and Lucena (1993) respectively; however,    an inner row of dentary teeth was observed in the examined species of both genera    and they are herein coded as state 0. The members of the Crenuchidae analyzed    by Buckup (1998) have two rows of teeth in the dentary; however the examined    species of <i>Characidium</i> have only one row of dentary teeth and they are    herein coded as state 1. The examined specimen of <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i>    lack dentary teeth. Juvenile specimens of this genus have teeth which are lost    
ontogenetically; although no juveniles of <i>H</i>. cf. <i>thayeria</i> were    examined for this paper, the inner tooth row of dentary is absent in juveniles    according to Langeani (1998), and this character is coded as state 1 for this    species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>144. Symphyseal    dentary teeth: (0) absent; (1) present. (UJ46, LU50i, CM41m, SE63m, ZV88, LI14).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most species    with two rows of dentary teeth, the posterior row is composed of numerous and    minute conical teeth situated along the ridge posterior to the replacement fossa    of the dentary (state 0; <a href="#f71">Fig. 71</a>). In a group of species,    the inner row of dentary teeth has a symphyseal tooth much larger than the remaining    teeth, a broad diastema, and a posterior series of teeth similar to those present    in state 0 (state 1; <a href="#f60">Fig. 60</a>). This character is coded as    inapplicable in species lacking the entire inner row of dentary teeth.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>145. Articulation    between dentary teeth: (0) absent; (1) present with associated processes and    fossae. (AM6).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the dentary teeth are contiguously situated, without articulations    among them (state 0). In some members of the Serrasalmidae, the posterior margin    of each dentary tooth has a depression into which the anterior of the immediately    posterior tooth inserts (Machado-Allison, 1983) (state 1; <a href="#f63">Fig.    63</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>146. Position    of anterior teeth of dentary: (0) along margin of dentary; (1) internally situated    with dentary forming anterior ridge.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Dentary teeth are    usually situated along the anterodorsal margin of the dentary (state 0). In    <i>Axelrodia lindeae</i> the dentary teeth are displaced internally and their    bases are bordered anteroventrally by a small continuous ridge of the dentary    (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>147. Separation    between posterior dentary teeth: (0) less than width of these teeth; (1) more    than width of these teeth.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The posterior teeth    of the outer dentary row are usually conical and much reduced in size. In most    species these teeth are closely situated each other, with only small spaces    between them (state 0; <a href="#f59">Fig. 59</a>). In the examined members    of the Stethaprioninae (<i>sensu</i> Reis, 1989), and some other species, these    teeth are comparatively more distant from each other, being separated by spaces    broader than the width of each tooth (state 1; <a href="#f43">Fig. 43</a>).    This character is coded as polymorphic in <i>Astyanax</i> cf. <i>eigenmanniorum1</i>    and <i>A</i>. <i>paris</i> Azpelicueta, Almir&oacute;n &amp; Casciotta in which    these spaces are of intermediate length.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>148. Abrupt    decrease in size of dentary teeth: (0) absent; (1) present. (EI8i, SE66m, SE67m,    ZV85m, B&Uuml;73m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The outer row of    dentary teeth is usually composed of four or five comparatively larger teeth    with five or more cusps followed by a variable number of smaller teeth with    fewer cusps. Eigenmann (1917) considered the size of the lateral dentary teeth    as a generic character, distinguishing between abruptly smaller (state 1; <a href="#f43">Fig.    43</a>) versus gradually smaller teeth (state 0; <a href="#f62">Fig. 62</a>;    Mirande <i>et al</i>., 2007: <a href="#f2">fig. 2</a>). The presence of gradually    decreasing dentary teeth was traditionally used to diagnose <i>Deuterodon</i>.    This genus was later rediagnosed phylogenetically by Lucena &amp; Lucena (2002)    who did not utilize this character as a putative synapomorphy. Most of the herein    examined species have a rather gradual decrease in the size of the dentary teeth,    with a comparatively smaller group of species having four or five much 
larger    anterior teeth and a posterior series of small, usually unicuspidate, teeth.    According to the adopted definition of states, <i>Charax stenopterus</i> and    <i>Triportheus</i> spp. are coded as state 0. This character is coded as polymorphic    in <i>Astyanax abramis</i>, <i>A</i>. cf. <i>asuncionensis</i> G&eacute;ry,    <i>A</i>. <i>lineatus</i>, <i>Brycon falcatus</i>, <i>B</i>. <i>pesu</i>, <i>Hemigrammus    unilineatus</i>, <i>Jupiaba scologaster</i> (Weitzman &amp; Vari), and <i>Pseudochalceus    kyburzi</i>, which have intermediate conditions.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Suspensorium</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Quadrate:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>149. Foramen    on articular condyle of quadrate: (0) absent; (1) present. (LU59i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The quadrate has    an anterior condyle for articulation with the anguloarticular. The ventral surface    of this condyle has, in medial view, a conspicuous vault that is not laterally    visible in most species (state 0; <a href="#f72">Fig. 72</a>). In some species    this vault opens dorsally by way of a foramen situated on the dorsal surface    of the condyle of the quadrate, with the foramen evident from a lateral view    (state 1; <a href="#f73">Figs. 73</a> and <a href="#f74">74</a>). The root of    this analysis is coded with state 0 because this foramen was not observed in    <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> and is absent in <i>Barilius</i> and <i>Opsariichthys</i>    according to Howes (1978: <a href="#f38">fig. 38</a>). This character is variable    among the examined specimens of <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i>, <i>Hollandichthys    multifasciatus</i>, <i>Odontostilbe paraguayensis</i> Eigenmann &amp; Kennedy,    and 
<i>Rhoadsia altipinna</i> in which it is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>150. Form of    quadrate: (0) with ventral portion longer than anterodorsal region; (1) with    anterodorsal portion equal or longer than ventral region. (LU60m, LM26, MO28m,    VB9, SE41m, BE45, ZV102m, QU8).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The quadrate in    most examined species has rather well differentiated anterodorsal and ventral    portions. The anterodorsal portion, which is situated anteriorly on the bone,    contacts the ectopterygoid, mesopterygoid, and metapterygoid, while the ventral    portion articulates with the symplectic and the horizontal arm of the preopercle.    The quadrate borders the quadrate-metapterygoid fenestra anteriorly and ventrally.    The ventral portion of the quadrate in most species is longer than the anterodorsal    portion, and the fenestra is consequently longitudinally elongate (state 0;    <a href="#f72">Fig. 72</a>). In some species the anterodorsal portion is relatively    more developed, equaling or surpassing the length of the ventral portion and    the fenestra is rounded or dorsoventrally ovoid (state 1; <a href="#f73">Fig.    73</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>151. Posterior    extent of ventral process of quadrate: (0) reaching vertical through posterior    margin of symplectic; (1) falling short of posterior margin of symplectic.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The ventral region    of the quadrate articulates laterally with the horizontal arm of the preopercle    via a variably elongate process, among the examined species. In many species    this articulation reaches posteriorly to a vertical line through the posterior    end of symplectic (state 0; <a href="#f75">Fig. 75</a>), while in others it    does not reach the posterior tip of the symplectic (state 1; <a href="#f76">Figs.    76</a> and <a href="#f77">77</a>). The degree of extension of the process may    be related, at least in some groups, to the relative length of the horizontal    arm of the preopercle or perhaps the size of the individuals. Such a correlation,    if present, is not absolute because some relatively small species have this    region much developed posteriorly, with the inverse also true. In the species    with a dorsoventrally expanded metapterygoid-quadrate fenestra, the symplectic    has an oblique 
orientation, and this character is not directly comparable. These    cases are thus coded as inapplicable.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>152. Longitudinal    ridge in quadrate bordering <i>adductor mandibulae</i> muscle ventrally and,    to some degree laterally: (0) absent; (1) present. (MO30).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The lateral surface    of the quadrate medially borders to some degree the medial sections of the <i>adductor    mandibulae</i>. In a group of taxa, the quadrate has a lateral bony longitudinal    ridge that borders the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> both ventrally and ventrolaterally    (state 1; <a href="#f78">Fig. 78</a>). This ridge is, however, absent in most    examined species (state 0). Moreira (2002) mentioned the presence of this bony    ridge as a synapomorphy of the Iguanodectinae. A similar bony ridge was observed    in <i>Distichodus maculatus</i>, but given its absence in <i>Xenocharax spilurus</i>,    this character is coded as polymorphic for this terminal taxon.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>153. Articulation    between quadrate and anguloarticular: (0) anterior to or at vertical through    lateral ethmoid; (1) posterior to lateral ethmoid. (LU62m, MO68, VB7m, SE42m,    ZV93i, QU7m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>154. Articulation    between quadrate and anguloarticular: (0) anterior to or at vertical through    middle eye; (1) posterior to middle eye. (LU62m, VB7m, SE42m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The posterior displacement    of the articulation between the quadrate and the anguloarticular is related    to the elongation of the lower jaw. The definition of states in this character    follows Lucena (1993), who recognized three states. In most examined species    of the Characidae this articulation is situated between the verticals through    the lateral ethmoid and the middle of the eye (character 153, state 1; character    154, state 0), in some species it is located anterior to the vertical through    the lateral ethmoid (character 153, state 0), whereas in other species it is    posterior to the middle of the eye (character 154, state 1). The examined specimen    of <i>Distichodus maculatus</i> has the state 0 in the character 153, but this    compound outgroup taxon is coded as polymorphic for this character given that    in <i>Xenocharax</i> the lower jaw is longer, corresponding to state 1. In <i>Carlana    
eigenmanni</i> and <i>Rhoadsia altipinna</i>, this articulation is situated    posteriorly to the middle of the eye only in adult specimens, while in young    individuals it is situated anterior to the middle of the eye; these species    are coded as polymorphic for the character 154. Intermediate states between    the states defined for the character 154 were observed in <i>Brycon pesu</i>    and <i>Nematocharax venustus</i>, which are also coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>155. Articulation    between ventral margin of metapterygoid and posterodorsal margin of quadrate:    (0) absent; (1) present. (LU58mi, MO24, VB8m, SE34i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">A metapterygoid-quadrate    fenestra is broadly distributed across the Characiformes. This fenestra is bordered    dorsally and posteriorly by the metapterygoid and anteriorly and ventrally by    the quadrate. The posteroventral margin of the fenestra is variably bordered    by these bones or by a cartilage situated just dorsal to the symplectic. This    portion of the quadrate has a process dorsally bordering the symplectic and    posteriorly oriented towards the metapterygoid which also has a small anterior    process directed anteriorly towards the quadrate in some species. In most examined    species the processes from the quadrate and metapterygoid are separated by a    cartilage, and consequently lack a common articular surface (state 0; <a href="#f72">Fig.    72</a>); in other species, these processes are synchondrally articulated to    each other (state 1; <a href="#f73">Fig. 73</a>). The examined specimens of    
<i>Brycon orbignyanus</i>, <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i>, <i>Nematocharax venustus</i>,    and <i>Rhoadsia altipinna</i> have intermediate states that are coded as polymorphisms.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ectopterygoid:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>156. Shape of    ectopterygoid: (0) elongate; (1) triangular and much broadened anteriorly; (2)    approximately square.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The ectopterygoid    is usually elongate and situated just lateral and parallel to the mesopterygoid,    in the area between the posterior margin of the palatine and the anterodorsal    region of the quadrate (state 0). Among the examined species, this bone has    a triangular shape in <i>Aulixidens eugeniae</i>, with its medial margin articulating    with the mesopterygoid and the anterior margin with the palatine (state 1).    In <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i> the ectopterygoid is relatively shorter and    broader than in the state 0, having an approximately square shape (state 2).    This character is not informative in the present analysis, other than involving    autapomorphies of <i>Aulixidens</i> B&ouml;hlke and <i>Engraulisoma</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>157. Form of    anterior portion of ectopterygoid: (0) broad and broadly articulating with palatine    and connected to neurocranium by ligaments; (1) slender and articulating only    to lateral margin of palatine, and lacking ligaments to neurocranium. (ZV97,    ZV99).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    members in the Characiformes, the ectopterygoid is broad anteriorly and broadly    articulated with the palatine. In most species the ligaments joining the suspensorium    to the neurocranium attach to the anterior portion of the ectopterygoid and    to the palatine and are directed towards the vomer (state 0). Zanata &amp; Vari    (2005) analyzed the anterior reduction of the ectopterygoid and the presence    or absence of ligaments to the neurocranium as separate characters; as these    two features are correlated in the species examined, they are herein considered    within the same character. It is important to note, however, that Zanata &amp;    Vari (2005) reported that the alestids <i>Clupeocharax schoutedeni</i> Pellegrin    and <i>Tricuspidalestes caeruleus</i> (Matthes), which were not analyzed here,    are exceptions to this correlation. Both the reduction of the anterior portion    of the 
ectopterygoid and the absence of ligaments attached to this bone (state    1) were proposed by Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) as synapomorphies for the family    Alestidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>158. Dorsal    process of ectopterygoid oriented towards lateral ethmoid: (0) absent. (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The ventral margin    of the lateral ethmoid articulates with the dorsal surfaces of the ectopterygoid    and mesopterygoid through a cartilage. Most examined species lack dorsally oriented    ectopterygoid processes towards the lateral ethmoid, with the exception of a    rather shallow lateral bony ridge in some species (state 0). In <i>Iguanodectes    geisleri</i> and <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i> there is instead a conspicuous    dorsal expansion near the posterior end of this bony ridge with the expansion    oriented in the direction of the lateral ethmoid (state 1; <a href="#f78">Fig.    78</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>159. Ectopterygoid    teeth row: (0) absent; (1) present. (VA53m, BU22mi, LU56m, MO16m, BE41, LI19,    B&Uuml;28, QU28, PZ50m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the ectopterygoid lacks teeth (state 0). Two patterns of teeth distribution    were observed among species with ectopterygoid teeth. Some species have teeth    forming a row along the lateral margin of the ectopterygoid, with these teeth    rather similar in form to those of the jaws (state 1; <i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. Menezes,    1969: <a href="#f71">fig. 71</a>). Some species have also a patch of minute    teeth (see character 160). As both types of teeth are topologically and morphologically    different from other and are simultaneously present in some species, they are    coded as separate characters.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>160. Patch of    ectopterygoid teeth: (0) absent; (1) present. (LM25, TP30, PZ50m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Ectopterygoid teeth    are absent or restricted to a distinct row parallel to the lateral margin of    the bone in most examined species (state 0). Some species have a patch of minute,    conical, more medially positioned teeth relative to the ectopterygoid row of    teeth, when the latter is present (state 1). This character is considered as    independent from the preceding character because both types of teeth are simultaneously    present in <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>161. Position    of longitudinal cartilage dorsal to ectopterygoid: (0) bordered medially by    mesopterygoid; (1) displaced laterally and separated from medial margin of mesopterygoid.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have a cartilage dorsal to the ectopterygoid that medially borders the mesopterygoid    (state 0). This cartilage is situated along all of the ectopterygoid, from its    anterior articulation with the lateral ethmoid to a position near the anterodorsal    region of the quadrate. In some species this cartilage is displaced laterally    and does not border the medial margin of the mesopterygoid (state 1). <i>Brycon    pesu</i>, <i>Deuterodon langei</i> Travassos, <i>Jupiaba mucronata</i> Eigenmann,    <i>J</i>. <i>scologaster</i>, <i>Triportheus nematurus</i> (Kner), and <i>T</i>.    <i>pantanensis</i> Malabarba have intermediate situations which are coded as    polymorphisms.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>162. Contact    between ectopterygoid and anterodorsal region of quadrate: (0) present; (1)    absent. (VH21, MO15, SE37, BE42m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The ectopterygoid    is situated just ventrolateral to the mesopterygoid, and usually articulates    posteriorly with the anterodorsal region of the quadrate (state 0; <a href="#f72">Figs.    72</a> and <a href="#f73">73</a>). Vari &amp; Harold (2001) mentioned the absence    of contact between the ectopterygoid and quadrate in most species of <i>Creagrutus</i>    (state 1; <a href="#f45">Fig. 45</a>). Intraspecific variation was observed    in <i>Acrobrycon tarijae</i>, <i>Astyanax troya</i>, <i>Bryconamericus</i> cf.    <i>iheringii</i>, <i>B</i>. <i>rubropictus</i>, <i>B</i>. cf. <i>rubropictus</i>,    <i>B</i>. <i>thomasi</i>, <i>Cheirodon interruptus</i> (Jenyns), <i>Coptobrycon    bilineatus</i>, <i>Deuterodon iguape</i>, <i>Jupiaba scologaster</i>, <i>Mimagoniates    rheocharis</i>, <i>Nantis indefessus</i>, <i>N</i>. cf. <i>indefessus</i>, <i>Odontostilbe    pequira</i>, <i>Phenacogaster tegatus</i>, <i>Stichonodon 
insignis</i> (Steindachner),    and <i>Thayeria boehlkei</i>, which are coded as polymorphisms.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Interopercle:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>163. Anterior    extension of interopercle: (0) extending anteriorly beyond terminus of horizontal    arm of preopercle; (1) not extending anteriorly beyond terminus of horizontal    arm of preopercle.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The interopercle    in most examined species extends anteriorly beyond the anterior end of the preopercle    and ventrally borders, at least partially, the region of articulation between    the quadrate and anguloarticular (state 0; <a href="#f75">Fig. 75</a>). In some    species the interopercle is reduced anteriorly and does not reach the anterior    margin of the horizontal arm of the preopercle (state 1; <a href="#f74">Fig.    74</a>). In the examined specimens of <i>Axelrodia lindeae</i> and <i>Carnegiella    strigata</i> the anterior margins of the interopercle and preopercle reach approximately    the same vertical line, and this character is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>164. Abrupt    posterior expansion of interopercle: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the interopercle gradually deepens to its posterior margin, which not    overlaps the opercle in all its depth (state 0). In other species the posterior    region of the interopercle is abruptly vertically expanded and its posterodorsal    angle is conspicuously acute; the posterior margin of the interopercle, in these    species, broadly overlaps the anteroventral margin of the opercle (state 1;    <a href="#f45">Fig. 45</a>). Intermediate situations were observed in <i>Leporinus    striatus</i> and <i>Odontostilbe pequira</i>, which are coded with polymorphisms.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Mesopterygoid:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>165. Mesopterygoid    teeth: (0) absent; (1) present. (UJ68, VA54, BU23, LU55i, LC31, LM24, TP29,    MO17, B&Uuml;29m, PZ51).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The mesopterygoid    lacks teeth in most species in the Characiformes (state 0). The presence of    mesopterygoid teeth (state 1; Vari, 1995: <a href="#f8">fig. 8</a>; Toledo-Piza,    2007: <a href="#f18">fig. 18</a>) was proposed as a synapomorphy of a clade    composed of <i>Acestrorhynchus</i> Eigenmann &amp; Kennedy, <i>Cynodon</i> Cuvier,    and <i>Rhaphiodon</i> Agassiz (Lucena, 1993), and was reported also in some    other non-characid genera (Vari, 1995; Buckup, 1998). Lucena &amp; Menezes (1998)    also mentioned the presence of mesopterygoid teeth in these three genera, but    under their phylogeny this character could be interpreted both as a synapomorphy    of their Acestrorhynchidae plus Cynodontidae, with a reversion in the Roestinae,    or as parallel autapomorphies of the Acestrorhynchidae and Cynodontidae. The    examined specimen of <i>Distichodus maculatus</i> lacks mesopterygoid teeth;    as these teeth 
were coded as present in this species by Buckup (1998), this    character is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Metapterygoid:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>166. Anterodorsal    lobe of metapterygoid oriented towards mesopterygoid: (0) absent or small and    dorsally oriented; (1) present, conspicuous and anteriorly oriented. (CM9(11)).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the anterior portion of the metapterygoid has a variably developed    lobe, oriented dorsally towards the mesopterygoid (state 0; <a href="#f44">Fig.    44</a>). Malabarba (1998b) proposed the presence of a rounded anterior process    as a synapomorphy of <i>Triportheus</i> (state 1; <a href="#f76">Fig. 76</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>167. Shape of    metapterygoid-quadrate fenestra: (0) rounded or ovate, anteriorly limited by    anterodorsal region of quadrate; (1) anteriorly collapsed by convergence of    metapterygoid and ventral region of quadrate. (MO28m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">When present, the    metapterygoid-quadrate fenestra is anteriorly bordered by the anterodorsal portion    of the quadrate, and has a rather ovate form (state 0; <a href="#f44">Fig. 44</a>).    In <i>Iguanodectes geisleri</i> and <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>, among the    examined species, the metapterygoid is expanded ventrally, articulating in some    point of the ventral region of quadrate, limiting anteriorly such fenestra in    instances when it is not completely occluded by the metapterygoid (state 1;    <a href="#f78">Fig. 78</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>168.
