Foramen    in posterior region of metapterygoid: (0) absent; (1) present, encircled by    metapterygoid or bordered partially by cartilage; (2) in form of incomplete    arch, bordered posteriorly by hyomandibula (LU57m, VH23m, MO23m, SE35m, BE43m,    LI22m, QU9m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    characids there is a foramen situated near the posterior margin of the metapterygoid    which serves as passage for the ramus mandibularis trigeminus nerve. This foramen    is usually situated entirely within the metapterygoid, although in some species,    especially in young specimens, its posterior margin is formed by a cartilage    (state 1; <a href="#f44">Figs. 44</a> and <a href="#f73">73</a>). In some species    this foramen is not completely contained within the metapterygoid, and is posteriorly    bordered by the hyomandibula (state 2; <a href="#f72">Figs. 72</a>, <a href="#f76">76</a>,    and <a href="#f78">78</a>), while in others it is completely absent (state 0).    According to the phylogenetic hypothesis of Lucena (1993) the presence of this    foramen is a synapomorphy of a clade including the Alestidae, Serrasalmidae,    and Characidae (excepting <i>Agoniates</i> M&uuml;ller &amp; 
Troschel), with    a reversion in a clade composed of <i>Brycon</i>, <i>Bryconops</i>, <i>Triportheus</i>,    and the Alestidae and Serrasalmidae. Intermediate situations between the states    1 and 2 were observed in specimens of <i>Heterocharax macrolepis</i> and <i>Hoplocharax    goethei</i> which are coded as polymorphisms between such states.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Opercle:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>169. Posterior    directed radial striae from articular region of opercle: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">A medial longitudinal    bony ridge in the opercle serves the as site of attachment of the <i>adductor    operculi</i> muscle, while the remaining medial surface of the opercle is smooth    in most species (state 0). A series of striae situated in the medial surface    of the opercle, oriented radially from the articular region of the opercle were    observed in the Serrasalmidae and <i>Prochilodus lineatus</i> (Valenciennes)    (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>170. Length    of medial bony ridge of opercle: (0) 60% or greater than opercular length; (1)    less than 50% of opercular length.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">As noted in the    preceding character, the opercle has a medial bony ridge that receives fibers    from the <i>adductor operculi</i> muscle. The length of this ridge is variable    among the examined species. In most species it is less than one half the length    of the opercle (state 1; <a href="#f75">Fig. 75</a>), while in some species    it achieves more than 60% of that length (state 0). Intermediate states were    observed in specimens of <i>Astyanax</i> cf. <i>abramis</i> and <i>A</i>. <i>asuncionensis</i>,    and these species are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Palatine:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>171. Ethmopalatine    cartilage: (0) absent or reduced in size; (1) present and conspicuous.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The palatine articulates    synchondrally with the vomer anteriorly and medially. Some species have a separate    block of cartilage, the ethmopalatine cartilage of Fink &amp; Fink (1981), just    anterior to the palatine. When present, this receives the ascending process    of the maxilla (state 1; <a href="#f22">Fig. 22</a>). In most species this cartilage    is absent or much reduced in size (state 0; <a href="#f27">Fig. 27</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>172. Relative    length of palatine: (0) approximately one-half length of ectopterygoid, or less;    (1) distinctly longer than one-half length of ectopterygoid. (M020m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The palatine is    the most anterior bone of the suspensorium and partially forms the floor of    the olfactory capsules. The size of the palatine is associated with the snout    length, and the relative positions of the mouth and olfactory capsules. In some    species the palatine is equal or shorter than half length of the ectopterygoid    (state 0), whereas in other species the palatine is longer than half length    of the ectopterygoid (state 1). Intermediate cases as coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>173. Palatine    foramen: (0) absent or reduced in size; (1) present and very conspicuous.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have a palatine that is approximately rectangular in dorsal view and lacks a    conspicuous foramen (state 0). A small group of species have a large foramen    in the palatine, which is easily visible in both dorsal and ventral views (state    1; <a href="#f79">Fig. 79</a>; Serra &amp; Langeani, 2006: <a href="#f8">fig.    8</a>). This foramen was described by Serra &amp; Langeani (2006) for <i>Bryconamericus    exodon</i>; however, in the examined specimens of <i>B</i>. <i>exodon</i> such    foramen is variably present and this species is coded as polymorphic. Polymorphisms    were also observed in <i>Astyanax</i> cf. <i>abramis</i>, <i>A</i>. <i>asuncionensis</i>,    <i>Bryconamericus</i> cf. <i>exodon</i>, <i>Diapoma terofali</i>, and <i>Mimagoniates    rheocharis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Preopercle:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>174. Shape of    posteroventral corner of preopercle: (0) acute; (1) rounded. (LU65).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The posteroventral    corner of the preopercle is rounded in most examined species (state 1; <a href="#f76">Fig.    76</a>). Lucena (1993) described an acute angle in the preopercle, present in    <i>Gnathocharax steindachneri</i> Fowler, <i>Heterocharax macrolepis</i>, <i>Hoplocharax    goethei</i>, <i>Iguanodectes adujai</i> G&eacute;ry, <i>Lonchogenys ilisha</i>,    and <i>Roestes</i> spp. (state 0).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Suprapreopercle:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>175. Suprapreopercle:    (0) fused to preopercle; (1) autogenous, separated from preopercle. (UJ20, BU27m,    LU64i, BE49i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The suprapreopercle    is situated in contiguity or continuity with the laterosensory canal segment    in the vertical arm of the preopercle and bears a canal of the laterosensory    system. Usually this bone is absent or fused with the preopercle (state 0),    whereas in some species the suprapreopercle is evident as an autogenous structure,    completely separate from the preopercle (state 1; <a href="#f34">Fig. 34</a>).    In several species, although the suprapreopercle appears to be separate from    the preopercle, it is situated very close to it. Since in these species is difficult    to recognize the complete separation of the preopercle, state 1 is restricted    only to cases in which the suprapreopercle is clearly separate, with an obvious    gap with the preopercle. The suprapreopercle is present in <i>Chanos</i> Lac&eacute;p&egrave;de    (Gonorynchiformes) and <i>Diplomystes</i> (Siluriformes) and was 
considered    as primitive for Characiformes (Fink &amp; Fink, 1981). The root of this analysis    is thus coded as state 1. In the examined specimens of <i>Charax stenopterus</i>    the suprapreopercle is not ossified and this species is coded with the state    0, although the presence of this bone is probably intragenerically variable    according to the observations of Lucena (1993) for <i>C</i>. <i>gibbosus</i>.    In the examined specimen of <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i> the laterosensory canal    of the suprapreopercle is apparently autogenous but it is aligned with the preopercle.    Given the coding of Lucena (1993) this character is coded herein as polymorphic.    Intraspecific variation was observed in <i>Astyanax troya, Creagrutus anary</i>    Fowler, <i>Microschemobrycon casiquiare</i>, and <i>Oligosarcus</i> sp. in which    this character is similarly coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>176. Bony lamellae    bordering laterosensory canal of suprapreopercle: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The suprapreopercle    is usually limited to a tubular laterosensory canal without associated lamellae    (state 0). Variably developed bony lamellae associated with the laterosensory    canal of the suprapreopercle were observed in <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i> and    <i>Oligosarcus</i> spp., (state 1; <a href="#f34">Fig. 34</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Branchial and    hyoid arches</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Anterior ceratohyal:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>177. Anterior    projection of anterior ceratohyal articulating laterally with hypohyals: (0)    absent or much reduced; (1) present and achieving half length of hypohyals.    (UJ69).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the proximal portion of the anterior ceratohyal articulates synchondrally    with the hypohyals without bony contact between these bones (state 0). Uj (1990)    mentioned the presence of a process laterally bordering the hypohyals in the    African alestid <i>Hydrocynus</i> and the South American genera <i>Acestrorhynchus</i>,    <i>Agoniates</i>, and <i>Rhaphiodon</i> (state 1). An intermediate state was    observed in <i>Heterocharax macrolepis</i> among the examined species, which    is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>178. Hyoid artery:    (0) completely contained within anterior ceratohyal in passage from posterior    ceratohyal to hypohyals; (1) emerging from anterior ceratohyal near its articulation    with posterior ceratohyal. (BU25, BE50, ZV111).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">A segment of the    hyoid artery enters in the posterior ceratohyal and is oriented towards the    dorsal hypohyal through the anterior ceratohyal. Castro (1984) and Buckup (1998)    noted that in some taxa this artery is contained completely within the anterior    ceratohyal as it passes to the dorsal hypohyal (state 0; <a href="#f80">Figs.    80</a> and <a href="#f81">81</a>), whereas in other species it exits by a pore    near the posterodorsal margin of the anterior ceratohyal and then passes into    an opening between the anterior ceratohyal and the dorsal hypohyal (state 1;    <a href="#f82">Fig. 82</a>). This state is present in most examined species    of the Characidae, while state 0 is present in all members from the outgroup    and some genera of the Characidae. A morphologically intermediate state was    observed in <i>Hoplocharax goethei</i> and <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i> which    are coded as polymorphic. 
In these species, the hyoid artery emerges at middle    length of the anterior ceratohyal, but is contained in a deep open canal along    the dorsal margin of the bone.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>179. Ventral    margin of anterior ceratohyal: (0) smooth and without notches; (1) with notches    for articulation of branchiostegal rays. (LU68, B&Uuml;79m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The branchiostegal    rays articulate with the ventral margin of the ceratohyals. Lucena (1993) mentioned    the presence of notches along the margin of the anterior ceratohyal in most    species of the Characidae (state 1; <a href="#f81">Figs. 81</a> and <a href="#f82">82</a>).    These notches are absent (state 0; <a href="#f80">Fig. 80</a>) in several characids    and in most members of the outgroup. A series of small cartilages coincident    in shape and position with the margins of the notches of other species were    observed in the members of the Serrasalmidae. These cartilages are probably    homologous with portions of the anterior ceratohyal forming these notches. <i>Metynnis    maculatus</i>, <i>Piaractus mesopotamicus</i>, and <i>Serrasalmus maculatus</i>    are thus coded as polymorphic for this character. Much reduced notches are present    in the examined specimens of <i>Hoplocharax goethei</i> which is also 
coded    as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>180. Number    of notches along ventral border of anterior ceratohyal: (0) zero to two; (1)    three.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Species in the    Characiformes usually have three branchiostegal rays articulating with the ventral    margin of the anterior ceratohyal. In these species, the anterior two branchiostegal    rays have a rather pedunculate anterior portion, which articulates with the    notches of the ventral margin of the anterior ceratohyal. The third branchiostegal    ray lacks a basal pedicle and articulates with the posteroventral surface of    the anterior ceratohyal (state 0). In some members of the Cheirodontinae there    is a third notch in the ventral margin of the anterior ceratohyal where the    third branchiostegal ray articulates. This ray, however, lacks a developed anterior    pedicle (state 1). The presence and development of this third notch is variable    among the examined specimens of <i>Aphyocharax dentatus</i> and this species    is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>181. Articulation    between anterior and posterior ceratohyals: (0) synchondral, without bony interdigitations;    (1) with bony interdigitations. (VA57, LI37).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the anterior ceratohyal articulates synchondrally with the posterior    ceratohyal without any bony interdigitations between the bones (state 0; <a href="#f80">Figs.    80</a> and <a href="#f82">82</a>). Uj (1990) mentioned the presence of interdigitations    between these bones (state 1; <a href="#f83">Fig. 83</a>) as a synapomorphy    of his Cynopotaminae (=Characinae, in part). Vari (1995) mentioned the presence    of such interdigitations as a synapomorphy of a clade including the families    Ctenoluciidae and Erythrinidae, and independently occurring in the lebiasinid    genera <i>Lebiasina</i> Valenciennes and <i>Piabucina</i> Valenciennes.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Basibranchials:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>182. First basibranchial:    (0) absent or much reduced, not articulating anteriorly with basihyal; (1) well    developed and articulating anteriorly with basihyal.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Members in the    Characiformes have three or four ossified basibranchials situated medial to    the hypobranchials. The anterior margin of the first basibranchial articulates    with the posterior margin of the basihyal in almost all the examined taxa (state    1; <a href="#f84">Fig. 84</a>). In some members of the outgroup, the first basibranchial    is absent or much reduced, and it does not contact the posterior margin of the    basihyal (state 0).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>183. Contact    between lamella on anterior portion of first basibranchial with lamella on posterior    portion of second basibranchial: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Basibranchials    usually bear, anteriorly and/or posteriorly, thin bony lamellae which project    dorsal to the cartilages situated between their main portions. These lamellae    apparently develop as autogenous ossifications and usually fuses to the main    portion of the basibranchials during ontogeny, as suggested by the presence    of autogenous lamellae in some examined specimens. The bony lamellae are usually    situated between the first and second and the second and third basibranchials.    Some species have also a bony lamella situated dorsal to the fourth basibranchial,    which is usually completely cartilaginous. The bony lamellae situated between    the first and second basibranchials are usually absent or not contacting each    other (state 0; <a href="#f86">Fig. 86</a>), whereas in some species these lamellae    form a bony bridge between the main portions of the first and second basibranchials    (state 1; 
<a href="#f85">Fig. 85</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>184. Bony lamellae    between second and third basibranchials: (0) absent; (1) present. (PZ66m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    bony lamellae between the basibranchials is variable among the examined species    and often independent in terms of occurrence between pairs of basibranchials;    this character is therefore considered as not correlated with the preceding    one. The bony lamellae between the second and third basibranchials are present    in most examined species (state 1; <a href="#f84">Fig. 84</a>). In some species    these lamellae are completely absent, and the space between the main portion    of the second and third basibranchials is filled only by cartilage (state 0;    <a href="#f86">Fig. 86</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>185. Bony lamella    dorsal to fourth basibranchial: (0) present; (1) absent. (LU74, VH32, MO56,    BE53i, LI43i, B&Uuml;82i, PZ67i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The fourth basibranchial    is completely cartilaginous in most examined species. Lucena (1993) mentioned    the presence of an ossified fourth basibranchial in many species of the Characidae;    however, based on his coding, it is likely that Lucena was instead referring    to the bony lamellae situated just dorsal to the fourth basibranchial (state    0; <a href="#f84">Figs. 84</a> and <a href="#f87">87</a>). In the phylogenetic    hypothesis of Lucena (1993), the presence of this lamella is a synapomorphy    of a clade including most characids, with a reversal in a clade composed of    <i>Creagrutus</i>, <i>Ctenobrycon</i> Eigenmann, <i>Iguanodectes</i>, and <i>Piabina</i>.    Contrary to the observations of Lucena (1993) and Benine (2004), this ossification    is present in the examined specimens of <i>Bryconamericus exodon</i>, <i>Deuterodon    iguape</i>, <i>Hemigrammus unilineatus</i>, and <i>Poptella 
paraguayensis</i>;    these species are coded as polymorphic, in light of probable intraspecific variations.    The presence of this bone is variable among the examined specimens of <i>Astyanax</i>    cf. <i>eigenmanniorum1</i> and <i>Probolodus heterostomus</i> and this character    is also coded as polymorphic in these taxa. The bony lamella dorsal to the fourth    basibranchial is absent (state 1; <a href="#f88">Fig. 88</a>) in the examined    specimens of <i>Exodon paradoxus</i> and <i>Hyphessobrycon herbertaxelrodi</i>    G&eacute;ry. Since Lucena (1993) and Benine (2004), respectively, noted the    presence of this lamella in these species this character is coded as polymorphic    for these taxa. In the examined specimen of <i>Prionobrama paraguayensis</i>    the fourth basibranchial is ossified and bordered dorsally by the bony lamella,    and this species is therefore coded as state 1.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>186. Main portion    of fourth basibranchial: (0) completely cartilaginous; (1) ossified.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">As noted above,    the fourth basibranchial is usually completely cartilaginous or has only a dorsal    bony lamella (state 0; <a href="#f87">Figs. 87</a> and <a href="#f88">88</a>).    In <i>Phenagoniates macrolepis</i>, <i>Prionobrama paraguayensis</i>, and <i>Xenagoniates    bondi</i> among the examined species, the main portion of the fourth basibranchial    is ossified (state 1). This character could not be examined in <i>Paragoniates    alburnus</i> which is coded as a missing entry.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>187. Teeth on    lamella dorsal to fourth basibranchial: (0) absent; (1) present. (LM36, PZ68).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Lucena (1993) proposed    the presence of teeth on the fourth basibranchial (state 1) as independent autapomorphies    of <i>Acestrorhynchus</i> and <i>Agoniates</i>. Such teeth are usually absent    (state 0) in the Characiformes. In the phylogenetic hypothesis of Lucena &amp;    Menezes (1998) the presence of teeth on the lamella dorsal to the fourth basibranchial    is also optimized as a parallelism between <i>Acestrorhynchus</i> and <i>Agoniates</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Basihyal:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>188. Cartilages    anterior to basihyal: (0) one or two blocks of cartilage, but anterior block    much smaller; (1) two well developed blocks of cartilage. (VA56).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anterior margin    of the basihyal has a cartilaginous margin bordered anteriorly by an autogenous    block of cartilage which supports the anterior portion of the primary tongue    (state 0; <a href="#f84">Figs. 84</a> and <a href="#f88">88</a>). Some species    have two independent autogenous blocks of cartilage anterior to the basihyal;    these blocks are approximately of the same width and as wide as the basihyal    (state 1; <a href="#f87">Fig. 87</a>). In some species the anterior block of    cartilage is much smaller and these cases were coded state 0. Both the homology    between these cartilages and possible ontogenetic variations should be assessed    in more focused studies. Intraspecific variation in this character were observed    in <i>Astyanax</i> cf. <i>eigenmanniorum2</i>, <i>A</i>. <i>endy</i>, <i>A</i>.    <i>latens</i>, <i>A</i>. <i>troya</i>, <i>Cheirodon interruptus</i>, <i>Hollandichthys    
multifasciatus</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon socolofi</i>, and <i>Psellogrammus kennedyi</i>,    which are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>189. Edentulous    basihyal lamella: (0) absent; (1) present. (ZV109i, LI42).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Vari (1983: 24)    described an "edentulous basihyal tooth plate" (state 1; <a href="#f85">Fig.    85</a>; Vari, 1983: <a href="#f22">fig. 22</a>) as a lamella situated just anterior    and dorsal to the basihyal. This lamella is probably a serial homologous to    the lamellae situated between the basibranchials. As this lamella, when present,    lacks teeth in the Characiformes, is here referred as edentulous basihyal lamella.    Such a lamella is absent in most examined species (state 0; <a href="#f88">Fig.    88</a>). Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) mentioned the presence of this lamella in    <i>Hepsetus odoe</i> (Bloch), <i>Hoplias microlepis</i>, <i>Triportheus albus</i>,    <i>Xenocharax spilurus</i>, and all of the alestids examined by them.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>190. Anterior    development of basihyal: (0) broadly extending beyond anterior margin of hypohyals;    (1) slightly surpassing anterior margin of hypohyals.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anterior margin    of the basihyal usually extends distinctly anterior of the hypohyals, being    the anteriormost element of the hyoid arch (state 0; <a href="#f84">Fig. 84</a>).    In the examined specimens of <i>Carnegiella strigata</i>, <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i>,    and <i>Triportheus</i> spp., the basihyal is relatively reduced, not extending    anteriorly beyond the hypohyals, or at most slightly surpassing that elements    (state 1; <a href="#f85">Fig. 85</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>191. Form of    anterior expansion of basihyal: (0) slender, with anterior margin less than    two-thirds of its length; (1) expanded, with anterior margin with two-thirds    or more of its length. (SE76m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anterior margin    of the basihyal supports the anterior portion of the primary tongue. The basihyal    expands laterally as it progresses anteriorly from its relatively slender articulation    with the first basibranchial. In most species this expansion is limited, and    the anterior margin of the basihyal have less than two-thirds of its length    (state 0; <a href="#f88">Fig. 88</a>). In some species the anterior region of    the basihyal is much expanded laterally and the anterior margin have two-thirds    or more of the length of this bone (state 1; <a href="#f89">Fig. 89</a>). The    basihyal in <i>Bryconamericus</i> cf. <i>exodon</i>, <i>Cheirodon interruptus</i>,    <i>Diapoma speculiferum</i>, and <i>Probolodus heterostomus</i> has an intermediate    state which is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Gill rakers:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>192. Rows of    gill rakers on first ceratobranchial: (0) one; (1) two. (LU73i, LC34, SE83m,    B&Uuml;85, PZ61i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>193. Rows of    gill rakers on second ceratobranchial: (0) one; (1) two. (LC35, SE83m, PZ62mi).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>194. Rows of    gill rakers on third and fourth ceratobranchials: (0) one; (1) two. (PZ63mi,    PZ64i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most members of    the outgroup have two rows of gill rakers on the first ceratobranchial (character    192, state 1), while most characids have only one row of gill rakers in this    bone (character 192, state 0). The first row of gill rakers is situated along    the leading margin of the ceratobranchial and the second row is located along    the trailing margin. In almost all the examined species, there are two rows    of gill rakers on the third and fourth ceratobranchials (character 194, state    1). The number of rows of gill rakers on the different ceratobranchials is not    independent, according to the observations done for this paper. All species    having two rows on the first ceratobranchial, have also two rows on the remaining    ceratobranchials; correspondingly, all the species with two rows on the second    ceratobranchial (character 193, state 1) have two rows on the third and fourth    ceratobranchial, 
although not necessarily on the first ceratobranchial. In this    way, this character can be seen as an ordered character with four states. The    examined specimen of <i>Cyanocharax alburnus</i> has only one minute gill raker    on the second row of the first ceratobranchial and this character is coded as    polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>195. Number    of gill rakers on first hypobranchial and ceratobranchial: (0) 16 or more; (1)    15 or fewer. (CM16(18)m, SE82m, B&Uuml;90m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>196. Number    of gill rakers on first hypobranchial and ceratobranchial: (0) 11 or more; (1)    ten or fewer. (CM16(18)m, SE82m, B&Uuml;90m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The number of gill    rakers is continuously variable among the examined taxa. Therefore, the limits    of the states used in characters 195 and 196 are rather subjective and they    were defined, in part, considering their congruence with the remaining characters    under preliminary analyses. Malabarba (1998b) defined the states of this character    with different ranges. According to her phylogeny, a high number of gill rakers    (more than 20) (character 195, state 0) is a synapomorphy of <i>Triportheus</i>.    Intraspecific variations in the character 196 was observed in <i>Astyanax abramis</i>,    <i>A</i>. cf. <i>abramis</i>, and <i>Prodontocharax melanotus</i>, and in the    character 195 in <i>Astyanax troya</i>, <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>, <i>Cynopotamus    argenteus</i>, <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i>, <i>Grundulus cochae</i>, <i>Hasemania    nana</i>, <i>Hemibrycon surinamensis</i>, <i>Hollandichthys 
multifasciatus</i>,    <i>Hoplocharax goethei</i>, <i>Jupiaba mucronata</i>, <i>Micralestes stormsi</i>,    <i>Mimagoniates rheocharis</i>, <i>Nematobrycon palmeri</i>, <i>Odontostoechus    lethostigmus</i>, <i>Roeboides descalvadensis</i>, and <i>Thayeria boehlkei</i>.    These species are coded as polymorphic for the variable character.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>197. Shape of    first ceratobranchial gill rakers: (0) pointed and not anteroposteriorly compressed;    (1) laminar and much compressed perpendicular to ceratobranchial; (2) short,    broad and strongly denticulate. (UJ70m, LU71m, LM35m, TP38, PZ65m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The gill rakers    are morphologically rather homogeneous within the Characiformes, with a broad    proximal region which articulates with the corresponding ceratobranchial and    a progressively slender distal region (state 0; <a href="#f83">Fig. 83</a>).    Among the examined species of the Parodontidae the gill rakers are laminar,    much reduced anteroposteriorly, and situated perpendicularly to the main axis    of the ceratobranchial (state 1). Lucena (1993) mentioned the presence of short    broad gill rakers bearing strong denticles in their dorsal surface (state 2;    Toledo-Piza, 2000: <a href="#f12">fig. 12</a>) in <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i>,    <i>Cynodon gibbus</i> (Agassiz), and <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>. This state    is a synapomorphy of a clade composed on these genera in his phylogeny. According    to Lucena &amp; Menezes (1998), the optimization of this character is ambiguous,    and this state 
could be a synapomorphy for their Acestrorhynchidae plus Cynodontidae,    with a reversal in their Roestinae, or a parallelism between the Acestrorhynchidae    and Cynodontidae. According to the phylogeny of Toledo-Piza (2007), the presence    of the state 2 is a synapomorphy for a clade consisting of <i>Acestrorhynchus</i>,    <i>Cynodon</i>, <i>Hydrolycus</i> M&uuml;ller &amp; Troschel, and <i>Rhaphiodon.</i></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>198. Form of    anterior gill rakers on first ceratobranchial: (0) not fused; (1) with fused    bases forming plates extensively articulated with ceratobranchial.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The gill rakers    are lanceolate and similar in form each other in most examined species (state    0). In <i>Cynopotamus argenteus</i> and <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i> the posterior    gill rakers of the first ceratobranchial are similar to those of other examined    species, while the anterior ones are progressively shorter and broader in these    species. The gill rakers situated along the anterior one-third of the first    ceratobranchial and on the first hypobranchial are fused to each other, thereby    forming strongly denticulate plates (state 1; <a href="#f86">Fig. 86</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>199. Lateral    base of gill rakers on first ceratobranchial: (0) slender; (1) broad and laminar    at least on anteriormost gill rakers.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The gill rakers    are usually articulated with the first ceratobranchial by two slender anterolaterally    and posteromedially oriented bases and aligned along an approximately transverse    line relative to the main axis of the ceratobranchial (state 0; <a href="#f83">Fig.    83</a>). In some species the anterolateral base of the gill rakers is expanded,    forming a lamella extensively articulated with the first ceratobranchial (state    1; <a href="#f81">Fig. 81</a>). This lamella is usually notched basally and    appears to be composed of two parallel bony platelets. As mentioned under the    preceding character, the anterior gill rakers of <i>Cynopotamus argenteus</i>    and <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i> are expanded basally. This state, however,    is not comparable to the states defined in this character, which is coded as    inapplicable for those species. In <i>Characidium</i> spp., <i>Carnegiella strigata</i>,    
<i>Puntius tetrazona</i>, and <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i> the anterolateral    base of the gill rakers is reduced and this character is coded as inapplicable.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>200. Form and    degree of ossification of first ceratobranchial gill rakers: (0) laminar and    not ossified distally; (1) rather thick and completely ossified distal region.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the gill rakers are slender and are not ossified distally (state 0;    Mirande <i>et al</i>., 2007: <a href="#f3">fig. 3</a>). In some species the    gill rakers are relatively stronger and completely ossified (state 1; <a href="#f83">Fig.    83</a>). This character has an intermediate state in <i>Hollandichthys multifasciatus</i>    which is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>201. Denticles    on gill rakers: (0) present; (1) absent. (CM17(19)m, SE80m, B&Uuml;93m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Denticles on the    gill rakers (state 0; Mirande <i>et al</i>., 2007: <a href="#f3">fig. 3</a>)    are broadly distributed in the Characiformes, especially among the members of    the Characidae. The presence and distribution of these denticles were considered    by B&uuml;hrnheim &amp; Malabarba (2006) in the systematics of the genus <i>Odontostilbe</i>.    The absence of these denticles was observed in most members of the outgroup    and some characids (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>202. Distribution    of denticles on gill rakers: (0) restricted to margins, or absent; (1) along    entire surface of gill rakers.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The denticles of    the gill rakers, when present, are usually more densely distributed along the    anterior and posterior margins of the rakers, where they are approximately aligned    into a row along each margin (state 0). In some species these denticles are    more densely distributed and situated also on the lateral surfaces of the gill    rakers, (state 1), as mentioned by Mirande <i>et al</i>. (2007) for <i>Astyanax    chico</i>, <i>A</i>. <i>puka</i> Mirande, Aguilera &amp; Azpelicueta, and <i>A</i>.    <i>troya</i>. This character, along with the preceding one can be considered    as an additive character with three states; therefore the absence of gill rakers    is coded in both characters. In <i>Jupiaba mucronata</i> and <i>Moenkhausia    xinguensis</i> the denticles are largely restricted to margins of the gill-rakers,    but some isolated denticles occur on their lateral surface and these species    are coded 
as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>203. Rows of    gill rakers on first epibranchial: (0) one; (1) two. (LC38i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species each of the four epibranchials has two rows of gill rakers (state 1).    A single row of gill rakers on the first epibranchial (state 0) was observed    in this study only in <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i>, <i>Agoniates anchovia</i>,    and <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ceratobranchials:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>204. Shape of    dentigerous plate of fifth ceratobranchial: (0) rounded, with posterior notch;    (1) elongated, without posterior notch. (VH33i, MO58i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The fifth ceratobranchial    bears a dentigerous plate in its posterior margin. This plate in most examined    species is rather elongate, with obtuse angles with the main body of the fifth    ceratobranchial both in their anterior and posterior regions (state 1; Vari    &amp; Harold, 2001: <a href="#f13">fig. 13A</a>). In a small number of species    the dentigerous plate has a rounded shape and its posterior region forms a straight    or acute angle with the main body of the fifth ceratobranchial (state 0; Vari    &amp; Harold, 2001: <a href="#f13">fig. 13B</a>). Uj (1990) mentioned the rounded    shape of the dentigerous plate of the fifth ceratobranchial as a synapomorphy    of his Piabucidae (= Iguanodectinae). Uj cited also this character state for    the genus <i>Creagrutus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>205. Teeth on    fifth ceratobranchial: (0) present; (1) absent.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most species in    the Characiformes have teeth on the fifth ceratobranchial (state 0; Vari &amp;    Harold, 2001: <a href="#f13">fig. 13</a>). The absence of such teeth (state    1) was proposed as a synapomorphy of the Curimatidae plus Prochilodontidae by    Vari (1983) and it was observed in this study only in <i>Cyphocharax spilotus</i>    and <i>Prochilodus lineatus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Pharyngobranchials:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>206. Teeth on    third pharyngobranchial: (0) present; (1) absent. (LC37, VH34, MO57, SE87m,    B&Uuml;84).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The third pharyngobranchial    bears teeth in most members of the Characidae (state 0) and these teeth are    absent in a relatively small group of examined species (state 1). Contrary to    the reported by Moreira (2002), teeth on the third pharyngobranchial are present    in the examined specimens of <i>Brycon pesu</i> and <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i>,    which are coded as polymorphic. <i>Iguanodectes geisleri</i> is also coded as    polymorphic following the observations of Moreira (2002) for this species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>207. Teeth on    fourth pharyngobranchial: (0) present; (1) absent. (BU41).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The fourth pharyngobranchial    bears teeth in most species of the Characiformes (state 0). The absence of teeth    in this bone (state 1) was proposed as a synapomorphy of the Anostomoidea (Anostomidae,    Chilodontidae, Curimatidae, and Prochilodontidae) by Vari (1983). The ancestral    condition for the Characiformes is unclear. The Cypriniformes lack dentigerous    plates on the fourth and fifth pharyngobranchials (Fink &amp; Fink, 1981, 1996)    while <i>Diplomystes</i>, considered a basal siluriform, bears teeth on the    third and fourth pharyngobranchials (Azpelicueta, 1994). This character is coded    as missing for the root of this analysis.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>208. Teeth on    fifth pharyngobranchial: (0) present; (1) absent.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The fifth pharyngobranchial    bears teeth in most taxa in the Characiformes (state 0). The absence or reduction    of such teeth (state 1) is a synapomorphy of a clade composed of the Curimatidae    and Prochilodontidae according to Vari (1983). For the same reasons as in character    207, the root is coded as missing.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>209. Contact    between fourth and fifth pharyngobranchial dentigerous plates: (0) absent; (1)    present. (UJ81, BU42i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most characiforms    the dentigerous plates of the fourth and fifth pharyngobranchials contact each    other and form a continuous surface (state 0; Vari, 1983: <a href="#f13">fig.    13</a>). The absence of contact between these pharyngobranchials (state 1; Vari,    1983: <a href="#f16">figs. 16-19</a>) was considered by Vari (1983) as a synapomorphy    of the Anostomoidea.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Interhyal:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>210. Interhyal:    (0) present; (1) absent.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The interhyal joins    the suspensorium with the hyoid arch in almost all the examined species. This    bone contacts dorsally with the symplectic and hyomandibula by means of cartilages;    the interhyal contacts ventrally with the posterior ceratohyal (state 0). The    interhyal is absent (state 1) in <i>Aulixidens eugeniae</i> and <i>Engraulisoma    taeniatum</i> among the examined species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>211. Length    of interhyal: (0) shorter than one-third of symplectic length; (1) equal to    or longer than one-half of symplectic length.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The interhyal is    a cylindrical bone much shorter than the symplectic in most examined species    (state 0; <a href="#f72">Fig. 72</a>). A configuration of the jaws and suspensorium    including a shortening of the horizontal arm of the preopercle, the lengthening    of the dentary, and a dorsal displacement of the posterior end of the symplectic    was observed in some species. The dorsal displacement of the symplectic in this    arrangement is correlated with an elongation of the interhyal to a relatively    longer form (state 1). Although this character could be associated with predation,    some apparently predatory genera such as <i>Bramocharax</i> and <i>Oligosarcus</i>    have state 0.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Branchiostegal    rays:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>212. Number    of branchiostegal rays: (0) three; (1) four or five. (VA61m, LU70, LM33m, TP33m,    ZV112i, LI39).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>213. Number    of branchiostegal rays: (0) three or four; (1) five. (VA61m, LU70, LM33m, TP33m,    ZV112i, LI39, PZ57).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most characiforms    have four branchiostegal rays (character 212, state 1; Character 213, state    0). Vari (1995) mentioned the presence of five branchiostegal rays (character    213, state 1) in <i>Erythrinus</i> Scopoli, <i>Hoplerythrinus</i> Gill and <i>Hoplias</i>    and considered this state as a synapomorphy of the Erythrinidae. Lucena &amp;    Menezes (1998) considered the possession of five branchiostegal rays as a synapomorphy    of the Cynodontinae. Variation between four and five branchiostegal rays was    observed in <i>Astyanax</i> cf. <i>asuncionensis</i>, <i>Cyanocharax alburnus</i>,    <i>Knodus breviceps</i>, and <i>Nantis</i> cf. <i>indefessus</i> with these    species coded as polymorphic for character 213. The Cypriniformes has three    branchiostegal rays, but both the Gymnotiformes and Siluriformes have more than    five and the ancestral state for the Characiformes is unknown. Therefore, the    
root of this analysis is coded as missing.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>214. Anterior    portions of branchiostegal rays: (0) broad near their articulation with ceratohyals;    (1) slender near their articulation with ceratohyals. (BE56).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the branchiostegal rays are anteriorly expanded near their articulation    with the ceratohyals (state 0; <a href="#f80">Fig. 80</a>). In some characids,    especially in members of the Characinae, the branchiostegal rays are slender    along their entire length and lack the cited expansion (state 1; <a href="#f82">Fig.    82</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>215. Attachment    of first branchiostegal ray: (0) on proximal one-half length of anterior ceratohyal    or anterior to that; (1) posterior to one-half length of anterior ceratohyal.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><i>Brycon meeki</i>    has three branchiostegal rays attached to the ventral margin of the anterior    ceratohyal (Weitzman, 1962). The first branchiostegal ray articulates to some    point on the proximal one-half of the anterior ceratohyal, usually along its    proximal one-third (state 0; <a href="#f80">Fig. 80</a>). In the examined specimens    of <i>Triportheus</i> spp. the attachment site of the branchiostegal rays is    displaced posteriorly to the posterior half of the ceratohyal (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>216. Distance    between attachment site of first and second branchiostegal rays: (0) equal or    shorter than distance between second and third rays; (1) longer than distance    between second and third rays.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The first and second    branchiostegal rays are usually closer to each other than are the second and    third rays (state 0; <a href="#f82">Fig. 82</a>). In some species, however,    the first and second branchiostegal rays are relatively more distant from each    other, being separated by a distance equal to or greater than the distance between    the second and third rays (state 1; <a href="#f83">Fig. 83</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>217. Number    of branchiostegal rays attached to posterior ceratohyal: (0) one; (1) two. (VA60,    LU69i, LM34, TP34, PZ58).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    share the possession of three branchiostegal rays articulated with the anterior    ceratohyal, plus one attached to the posterior ceratohyal as described by Weitzman    (1962) (state 0; <a href="#f82">Fig. 82</a>). Vari (1995) mentioned the presence    of two branchiostegal rays articulating with the posterior ceratohyal (state    1) in <i>Ctenolucius</i> spp, while Lucena (1993) also coded this state in <i>Acestrorhynchus    pantaneiro</i> and <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i> and considered the presence of    two branchiostegal rays articulating with the posterior ceratohyal as a synapomorphy    of a monophyletic clade composed of <i>Acestrorhynchus</i>, <i>Cynodon</i>,    and <i>Rhaphiodon</i>, with a parallel occurrence in <i>Ctenolucius</i>. Lucena    &amp; Menezes (1998) proposed the inclusion of <i>Gilbertolus</i> and <i>Roestes</i>    (subfamily Roestinae) in their family Cynodontidae, as sister 
group of <i>Cynodon</i>    and <i>Rhaphiodon</i>. Since <i>Gilbertolus</i> and <i>Roestes</i> have state    0, the optimization of this character is ambiguous in the analysis of Lucena    &amp; Menezes (1998) for the clade containing the Acestrorhynchidae and Cynodontidae.    This character could be optimized both as a synapomorphy of the Acestrorhynchidae    and Cynodontidae, with a reversion in the Roestinae, or as parallelisms in the    Acestrorhynchidae and Cynodontinae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Vertebrae, ribs    and Weberian apparatus</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Weberian apparatus:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>218. Form and    articulation of neural pedicle of third vertebra: (0) pedicle well developed    and articulating synchondrally with neural complex; (1) pedicle much smaller    and without an articular surface with neural complex.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most ingroup    species the neural pedicle of the third vertebra is smaller relative to the    condition described by Weitzman (1962) for <i>Brycon meeki</i>. In that species    the posterior margin of the neural pedicle articulates with the neural arch    of the fourth vertebra, and its dorsal margin articulates with the neural complex    (state 0; <a href="#f7">Fig. 7</a>; Weitzman, 1962: <a href="#f12">fig. 12</a>).    This situation was observed herein in most members of the outgroup and some    representatives of the Characidae. In the remaining species the neural pedicle    of the third vertebra is reduced to a furca extending dorsally to the neural    complex but not articulated synchondrally with that bone. Consequently the ventral    margin of the neural complex is articulated solely with the neural arch of the    fourth vertebra (state 1; <a href="#f8">Fig. 8</a>; Fink &amp; Fink, 1981: <a href="#f16">fig.    
16</a>). In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> and <i>Opsariichthys</i> (Fink &amp; Fink,    1981), the neural arch of the third vertebra is well developed and broadly articulates    with the anterior supraneurals. This situation is coded herein as state 0. In    the gymnotiform <i>Sternopygus</i> M&uuml;ller &amp; Troschel, the situation    is similar to that of <i>Xenocharax</i> and <i>Brycon meeki</i> (Fink &amp;    Fink, 1981; Weitzman, 1962), which constitutes additional evidence to consider    state 0 as ancestral for the Characiformes. This character is coded as polymorphic    in <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i> which demonstrates an intermediate state. Apparently,    the neural arches of the third and fourth vertebrae of <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i>    are fused each other, and this character is coded as inapplicable.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>219. Development    of transverse process of neural arch of third vertebra: (0) not reaching anterior    margin of tripus; (1) well developed and extending beyond anterior margin of    tripus. (VA71m, ZV114m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The transverse    process of third neural arch projects anteriorly or anterodorsally from the    main body of the bone and receives the posterior tip of the intercalarium. Uj    (1990) considered the great development of this process as diagnostic of his    Agoniatidae (=Agoniatinae). Vari (1995) mentioned that this process is relatively    reduced in the Ctenoluciidae and not reaching the posterior end of the intercalarium.    In most species this process does not reach the anterior end of the tripus (state    0; <a href="#f6">Fig. 6</a>) while in others it extends beyond the tripus anteriorly    (state 1; <a href="#f7">Fig. 7</a>). Intermediate states or intraspecific variability    were observed in <i>Bryconexodon juruenae</i>, <i>Diapoma speculiferum</i>,    <i>Hoplocharax goethei</i>, <i>Lonchogenys ilisha</i>, <i>Moenkhausia xinguensis</i>,    and <i>Odontostoechus lethostigmus</i> which are coded as 
polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>220. Ascending    process of neural pedicle of third vertebra: (0) absent; (1) present. (UJ9m,    LU76m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the neural pedicle of the third vertebra has a variably developed ascending    process directed towards the neural complex (state 1; <a href="#f8">Fig. 8</a>).    In several outgroups this process is completely absent (state 0). A reduced    dorsal expansion of the neural pedicle was observed in <i>Characidium rachovii</i>    and <i>Distichodus maculatus</i>, and these species are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>221. Dorsal    development of dorsal process of neural pedicle of third vertebra: (0) not broadly    overlapping neural complex; (1) broadly overlapping neural complex. (UJ37m,    BU45m, LU76m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dorsal process    of the neural pedicle of the third vertebra, when present, is directed dorsally    towards the neural complex. In most species this process falls short of the    ventral margin of the neural complex, or only overlaps the margin slightly (state    0; <a href="#f8">Fig. 8</a>), whereas in some species this process extensively    overlaps the neural complex (state 1). Intermediate states were observed in    <i>Astyanax</i> cf. <i>rutilus</i>, <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i>, <i>Creagrutus    anary</i>, <i>Hollandichthys multifasciatus</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon luetkenii</i>,    <i>Moenkhausia dichroura</i>, and <i>Oligosarcus</i> sp. These species are coded    as polymorphic. The cases in which this process is completely absent are coded    as inapplicable.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>222. Neural    arch and vertebral centrum of fourth vertebra: (0) not fused and with autogenous    fourth neural arch; (1) fused. (BU49).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Fink &amp; Fink    (1981) mentioned that the neural arch of the fourth vertebra is autogenous (state    0; Fink &amp; Fink, 1981: <a href="#f14">figs. 14-15</a>) in the Citharinidae    and Distichodontidae and considered this state as plesiomorphic for the Characiformes,    due to its presence in the Cypriniformes and Gymnotiformes. Among the examined    species, the neural arch of the fourth vertebra is only autogenous in <i>Puntius    tetrazona</i> and <i>Distichodus maculatus</i>, corroborating the observations    of those authors. This neural arch is fused to the corresponding vertebral centrum    in the remaining examined species (state 1; Weitzman, 1962: <a href="#f12">fig.    12</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ribs:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>223. Anteriorly    directed spine at base of first rib: (0) absent; (1) present. (LU81m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the base of the first rib posterior to the Weberian apparatus bears    an expansion onto which a ligament directed towards the following rib and parapophysis    attaches. This medially directed expansion is approximately triangular (state    0). In some species there is, additionally, a well-developed spine projected    anteriorly from that expansion (state 1; <a href="#f90">Fig. 90</a>). Zanata    &amp; Vari (2005) described a process in <i>Acestrorhynchus microlepis</i> (Jardine),    <i>Brycon</i> spp., and <i>Chalceus</i> spp., which is medially directed and    projects from the main body of the rib. That feature is non-homologous with    the process described in the state 1 of this character.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>224. Laminar    bony ridge on dorsal margin of abdominal ribs: (0) absent; (1) present. (BE59).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dorsal margin    of the abdominal ribs lacks conspicuous projections in most examined species    (state 0). Lucena (1993) mentioned the presence of dorsal bony ridges in the    third to sixth abdominal ribs (state 1; <a href="#f91">Fig. 91</a>) as parallel    autapomorphies of <i>Moenkhausia lepidura</i> (Kner) and <i>Parecbasis cyclolepis</i>.    Benine (2004) proposed the presence of bony ridges on abdominal ribs as a synapomorphy    of a clade within <i>Moenkhausia</i> including <i>M</i>. <i>lepidura</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>225. Abdominal    ribs on anterior caudal vertebrae: (0) absent; (1) present, associated to first    and occasionally second caudal vertebrae.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most species,    the ribs are articulated to the abdominal and transitional vertebrae both of    which lack haemal spines (state 0). In the examined species of the Serrasalmidae,    the posterior ribs are associated with the first, or first and second, caudal    vertebrae (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Vertebrae:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>226. Relative    number of precaudal vertebrae: (0) exceeding caudal vertebrae in two or more    elements; (1) equal or less numerous than caudal vertebrae. (LU80m, MO87m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The precaudal vertebrae    include the abdominal and transitional vertebrae. In most examined species of    the Characidae the caudal vertebrae are as numerous or less numerous than the    precaudal vertebrae (state 1). In some members of the outgroup, in contrast,    the precaudal vertebrae are more numerous than the caudal vertebrae (state 0).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>227. Total number    of vertebrae: (0) 40 or fewer; (1) 41 or more.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The number of vertebrae    is almost continuously variable across the examined species. The limits of the    states used herein are, therefore, rather subjective. Most examined species    have a vertebral number comprised of between 35 and 38 vertebrae (state 0),    while in some species a higher number was observed, exceeding 40 vertebrae (state    1). This character is coded as polymorphic for <i>Distichodus maculatus</i>,    <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i>, and <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i> which    have ranges of vertebral counts overlapping the defined states. The examined    specimen of <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> has 29 vertebrae, but the root of this    analysis is coded as polymorphic because <i>Opsariichthys</i>, considered to    be a generalized cypriniform by Fink &amp; Fink (1981) has more than 40 vertebrae    (Howes, 1978).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>228. Total number    of transitional vertebrae: (0) four or more; (1) three or fewer. (UJ47m, ZV121m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Haemal processes    are ventral projections of the vertebrae that form part of the haemal arch and    the haemal spine of the caudal vertebrae. Transitional vertebrae have bilateral    haemal processes but lack a haemal spine (Weitzman, 1962: <a href="#f14">fig.    14b</a>). Most examined species have fewer than four transitional vertebrae,    most often two (state 1), while some species have four or more (state 0). Variation    between these states was observed in <i>Acrobrycon tarijae</i> and <i>Iguanodectes    geisleri</i>, which are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>229. Transitional    vertebrae with haemal canal: (0) present; (1) absent.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Additionally to    the haemal processes, the posteriormost transitional vertebrae usually bear    a haemal canal which is also present in the caudal vertebrae. This canal is    formed by a transverse bony bridge between the contralateral haemal processes    (state 0; Weitzman, 1962: <a href="#f14">figs. 14b</a> and <a href="#f14">14c</a>).    In some species this type of transitional vertebrae is absent, and the first    vertebra that bears a haemal canal also has a haemal spine, being therefore    the first caudal vertebra (state 1). This character is coded as polymorphic    in <i>Aphyocharacidium bolivianum</i>, <i>Astyanax latens</i>, <i>Bryconamericus</i>    cf. <i>rubropictus</i>, <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i>, <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>,    <i>Hyphessobrycon pulchripinnis</i>, and <i>Psellogrammus kennedyi</i>, which    show variation between the defined states.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Pectoral girdle</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Pectoral fins:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>230. Margin    of first pectoral ray in adult specimens: (0) not serrated; (1) conspicuously    serrated. (VB41).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The external margin    of the first pectoral and pelvic fins is formed by a cartilage situated between    the hemiradii that constitute such ray. This margin is usually not serrated    (state 0). Bertaco (2003) reported the presence of a serrated margin of this    cartilage in <i>Hollandichthys</i> and <i>Pseudochalceus</i> as a synapomorphy    for a clade composed of those genera (state 1). This condition was also observed    in this study in <i>Apareiodon affinis</i>, <i>Parodon nasus</i>, and <i>Characidium</i>    spp.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>231. Base of    second pectoral ray: (0) large and partially overlapping base of first pectoral    ray from medial view; (1) similar in form and size to base of posterior rays.    (ZV137i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The base of each    pectoral-fin ray has an expansion where several branches of the <i>adductor    radialis</i> muscle attach (Winterbottom, 1974). In most examined species the    base of the first pectoral-fin ray, usually the single unbranched ray, is much    expanded in comparison to the bases of the posterior rays, all of which are    of similar size (state 1). In a relatively small group of species, the base    of the second pectoral-fin ray is much expanded and conspicuously laterally    overlaps the base of the first fin ray (state 0; <a href="#f92">Fig. 92</a>).    Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) mentioned that state 0 is broadly distributed in the    Alestidae, being also present in several other characiforms. Zanata &amp; Vari    (2005) considered the state present in <i>Hoplias microlepis</i> as inapplicable,    because the second pectoral-fin base is not conspicuously larger that those    of the posterior rays, and it 
is oriented anteromedially rather than dorsally.    A similar condition was observed in this study in <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>    and <i>Pyrrhulina australis</i> in which this character is coded as inapplicable.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Cleithrum:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>232. Anterior    margin of cleithrum: (0) slightly sinuous; (1) with anterior pointed projection.    (UJ64m, LU88, LC42m, PZ77m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Lucena (1987) described    a pointed projection of the anterior margin of the cleithrum lateral lamella    (state 1; <a href="#f93">Fig. 93</a>) of <i>Charax</i>. This projection extends    laterally and posteriorly the surface where the <i>sternohyoideus</i> muscle    attaches to the cleithrum. Uj (1990) mentioned the presence of such projection    in his Cynopotamidae (genera <i>Cynopotamus</i> and <i>Galeocharax</i> Fowler)    and Characidae (most of the Characinae). According to Lucena (1998), such a    process is absent (state 0; <a href="#f94">Fig. 94</a>) in, among others, <i>Cynopotamus    argenteus.</i> The anterior process of the cleithrum was, however, observed    in this species in this study and <i>C</i>. <i>argenteus</i> is coded as polymorphic    for this character.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>233. Form of    posterior margin of cleithrum: (0) convex or slightly sinuous just dorsal to    pectoral-fin insertion; (1) with notch just anterior to pectoral-fin insertion.    (UJ64m, BU57, LU88, LC43, MO65, PZ78).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The lateral lamella    of the cleithrum is situated just dorsal to the pectoral-fin insertion and usually    has a slightly sinusoidal form that partially follows the anterior margin of    this fin (state 0; <a href="#f94">Fig. 94</a>). Lucena (1987) described the    presence of a conspicuous notch broadly surrounding the anterior margin of the    pectoral-fin insertion (state 1; <a href="#f93">Fig. 93</a>) in <i>Charax</i>.    Buckup (1998) coded this notch as present in <i>Charax</i> sp., <i>Cynopotamus    argenteus,</i> and <i>Phenacogaster microstictus</i> Eigenmann, proposing it    as a synapomorphy for a clade composed of these three species. A much reduced    notch was observed in this study in <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i> and <i>Hoplocharax    goethei</i>, which are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>234. Posterior    margin of cleithrum: (0) without concavity ventral to first postcleithrum; (1)    with concavity ventral to first postcleithrum. (BE68).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>235. Posterior    margin of cleithrum: (0) with concavity poorly pronounced or lacking; (1) with    markedly concave margin, almost forming straight angle. (BE68).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the posterior margin of cleithrum, is slightly concave in the region    immediately ventral to the first postcleithrum. The position and degree of concavity    of this region of the cleithrum is almost continuously variable among the examined    species; however the cases in which the concavity is absent and those in which    this concavity is much pronounced are clearly recognizable. The states herein    defined follow in general those of Benine (2004), who differentiated a state    in which the cleithrum lacks a concavity (character 234, state 0; <a href="#f94">Fig.    94</a>), a state in which there is a slight concavity (character 234, state    1; character 235, state 0; <a href="#f95">Fig. 95</a>) and a state in which    this concavity is much marked, almost forming a straight angle (character 235,    state 1; <a href="#f96">Fig. 96</a>). The examined specimen of <i>Hemigrammus    
unilineatus</i> has the state 0 of the character 234, but this species is here    coded as polymorphic given the observations of Benine (2004), who coded it with    state 1.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>236. Medial    laminar expansion at dorsal tip of cleithrum: (0) absent; (1) present. (CM19(1?)).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Malabarba (1998b)    proposed the presence of a medially oriented laminar blade-like projection at    the dorsal tip of the cleithrum (state 1; <a href="#f97">Fig. 97</a>) as a synapomorphy    of <i>Triportheus</i>. This lamella is absent (state 0) in the remaining examined    species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>237. Dorsal    development of cleithrum: (0) much extended dorsally to mesocoracoid; (1) ending    in a position just dorsal of tip of mesocoracoid. (LM20, CM18(10), PZ81).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The cleithrum,    in most examined species, obviously projects dorsal of the tip of the mesocoracoid.    The dorsal portion of the cleithrum in this condition is longer than one-half    the length of the mesocoracoid (state 0). Malabarba (1998b) proposed a reduction    of the dorsal extent of the cleithrum, which projects just slightly dorsal to    mesocoracoid (state 1; <a href="#f97">Fig. 97</a>) as a synapomorphy of <i>Triportheus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Coracoid:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>238. Development    of medial lamella of coracoid: (0) not expanded; (1) expanded as a keel. (CM21,    MO63).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the medial lamellae of the coracoids do not articulate with each other    but rather diverge posteriorly from a ventral view. Furthermore, in this condition    the coracoids are not conspicuously expanded ventrally (state 0). In some species    the coracoids lamellae are much expanded ventrally and medially contacting each    other and forming a keel (state 1). Weitzman (1960) mentioned the presence of    a pectoral keel in some phylogenetically distant groups as in the genera <i>Ilisha</i>    Richardson, <i>Odontognathus</i> Lac&eacute;p&egrave;de, <i>Opisthopterus</i>    Gill, and <i>Raconda</i> Gray (Clupeiformes: Clupeidae) and in <i>Chela</i>    Hamilton (Cypriniformes: Cyprinidae). Within the Characiformes this author mentioned    the presence of a pectoral keel in the genera <i>Piabucus</i> Oken, <i>Pseudocorynopoma</i>    Perugia, <i>Rhaphiodon</i>, <i>Triportheus</i>, and the members 
of the Gasteropelecidae.    A coracoid keel was also reported for <i>Cynodon</i> (Toledo-Piza, 2000) and    <i>Lignobrycon</i> (Malabarba, 1998b). In <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i> the    coracoid lamellae are enlarged relative to other characids, but they do not    articulate medially to form a keel and this species is coded as state 0.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>239. Bony ridge    of coracoid between base of mesocoracoid and ventral margin of interosseous    space: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The interosseous    space (Starks, 1930) is a fenestra situated anterior to the region of articulation    between the mesocoracoid and coracoid and is limited dorsally by the cleithrum    and ventrally by the coracoid; this fenestra is present in most species in the    Characiformes. In most examined species the lateral surface of the ventral lamella    of the coracoid is relatively smooth and lacks obvious ridges in the region    just anterior to its articulation with the mesocoracoid (state 0; <a href="#f98">Fig.    98</a>). A bony ridge situated on the lateral surface of the coracoid between    its articulation with the mesocoracoid and the interosseous space was observed    in several species (state 1; <a href="#f97">Fig. 97</a>). In <i>Carnegiella    strigata</i>, <i>Characidium</i> spp., <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>,    and <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i>, the coracoid has a different set of modifications    
and this character is coded as inapplicable to these species. A broadening of    the coracoid in a position similar to that of the ridge coded in this character    was observed in <i>Leporinus striatus</i>. Given that the correspondence between    these structures is doubtful, this character is also considered as inapplicable    to <i>L</i>. <i>striatus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>240. Anterior    extension of coracoid ventral lamella: (0) reaching cleithrum; (1) not reaching    cleithrum. (UJ34, BU55, LU84).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the ventral lamella of the coracoid extends anteriorly to the cleithrum    (state 0). According to Buckup (1998), the coracoid is reduced anteriorly in    <i>Crenuchus spilurus</i> and <i>Hoplias malabaricus</i> and does not reach    the cleithrum (state 1). Lucena (1993) mentioned that such a reduction in the    anterior extension of the coracoid is present in <i>Erythrinus erythrinus</i>    (Bloch), <i>Hoplerythrinus unitaeniatus</i> (Spix &amp; Agassiz), and <i>Hoplias    malabaricus</i>, among the taxa examined by him, and that it constitutes a synapomorphy    of the Erythrinidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>241. Ventral    extension of coracoid lamella: (0) reaching ventral margin of cleithrum; (1)    falling short of ventral margin of cleithrum.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The medial lamella    of the coracoid projects ventrally to different degrees among the examined taxa.    Usually its ventral margin reaches the body wall and it is visible through the    skin and scales in some alcohol-preserved individuals. In such cases, the ventral    margin of the coracoid reaches the ventral end of the cleithrum (state 0; <a href="#f99">Fig.    99</a>). In <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>, <i>Grundulus cochae</i>, <i>Gymnocharacinus    bergii</i>, and <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i> among the examined species,    the medial lamella of the coracoid is much smaller ventrally and does not reach    the ventral margin of the cleithrum (state 1; <a href="#f100">Fig. 100</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>242. Anterior    limit of interosseous space: (0) formed by dorsal margin of coracoid medial    lamella and dorsal margin of cleithrum; (1) formed by dorsal margin of coracoid    medial lamella and an oblique bony ridge located just ventral to dorsal margin    of cleithrum.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the interosseous space is limited anteriorly by the junction of the    dorsal margin of the coracoid medial lamella and the dorsal margin of the cleithrum.    The anterior end of the coracoid in such cases articulates through interdigitations    with the medial margin of the cleithrum (state 0; <a href="#f98">Fig. 98</a>).    In some species the coracoid articulates anteriorly with an oblique bony ridge    of the posterior surface of the anterior region of the cleithrum, and the interosseous    space is limited anteriorly by these two elements. In these cases there are    no interdigitations of the coracoid with the medial region of the cleithrum    (state 1; <a href="#f101">Fig. 101</a>). Although the interosseous space is    absent in <i>Characidium</i> spp., the coracoid articulates anteriorly with    a bony lamella in a mode comparable to that described in the state 1, and these    species 
are coded as that state. The coracoid of <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>    is much reduced and it does not articulate anteriorly with the cleithrum, and    this character is coded as inapplicable for this species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>243. Coracoid    foramen: (0) absent or reduced to small pore; (1) well developed. (LU85, CM20i,    VB46i, PZ79m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The coracoid foramen    is a large rounded opening situated just anteroventral to the region of articulation    of the mesocoracoid and coracoid (state 1; <a href="#f99">Fig. 99</a>) as described    for <i>Brycon meeki</i> by Weitzman (1962). This opening is absent or reduced    to a small pore in most of the species examined here (state 0; <a href="#f98">Fig.    98</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Scapula:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>244. Process    of scapula forming anterior border of scapular foramen: (0) present; (1) absent.    (LU87, VH48, ZV136).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The scapula borders    posteriorly the scapular foramen in the Characiformes; this foramen in most    examined species is also limited anteriorly by a ring-like projection of the    anterolateral margin of the scapula (state 0; <a href="#f97">Fig. 97</a>). In    several characiforms such anterior process is reduced or absent and does not    form the anterior margin of the scapular foramen (state 1). Intraspecific variability    in this character was observed in this study in <i>Aulixidens eugeniae</i>,    <i>Bryconamericus agna</i>, <i>Bryconexodon juruenae</i>, <i>Diapoma terofali</i>,    <i>Hyphessobrycon pulchripinnis</i>, <i>Nematobrycon palmeri</i>, and <i>Roeboides    descalvadensis</i>, which are coded as polymorphisms.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Mesocoracoid:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>245. Articulation    between ventral process of mesocoracoid and dorsal margin of scapula: (0) absent    or small; (1) present and broad. (VH47).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most species    the mesocoracoid is columnar except in its dorsal region, which is variably    expanded to articulate only with the cleithrum in most of the Characiformes    (state 0; <a href="#f98">Fig. 98</a>).
