As described by Vari &amp; Harold (2001)    in the species of <i>Creagrutus</i> this dorsal expansion of the mesocoracoid    is projected ventrally to articulate synchondrally with the dorsal margin of    the scapula (state 1; <a href="#f102">Fig. 102</a>). Vari &amp; Harold (2001)    mentioned that such contact is also present in <i>Triportheus</i>, although    they considered that condition as not homologous with that present in <i>Creagrutus</i>.    A similar situation to that described for <i>Creagrutus</i> was observed here    in <i>Characidium</i> spp., <i>Gymnocharacinus bergii</i>, and <i>Hoplias</i>    cf. <i>malabaricus</i>. In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> a projection of the middle    region of the 
mesocoracoid to the scapula, ventral to its articulation with    the cleithrum, was observed. Given that this state is different from those coded    in this paper, the root of this analysis is coded as inapplicable. A cartilage    of similar shape to the mesocoracoid process was observed in <i>Pyrrhulina australis</i>;    however, since the correspondence of this cartilage to the ossified process    is uncertain, this character is also coded as inapplicable for this species.    In the lebiasinid <i>Poecilobrycon</i> (=<i>Nannostomus</i>) <i>harrisoni</i>    (Eigenmann), illustrated by Weitzman (1964) this process is absent, at least    as an ossification.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>246. Ventral    articulation of mesocoracoid: (0) anteriorly with coracoid and posteriorly with    scapula; (1) only with coracoid.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The mesocoracoid    in most examined species articulates ventrally with the coracoid and scapula    (state 0; <a href="#f98">Fig. 98</a>), whereas in the examined specimen of <i>Prionobrama    paraguayensis</i> the mesocoracoid only articulates ventrally with the coracoid    (state 1). This character constitutes an autapomorphy of this species in this    analysis; however it is maintained in the data matrix considering its potential    phylogenetic utility in future studies.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Postcleithra:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>247. First postcleithrum:    (0) present. (1) absent. (VH50, ZV132, QU43).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Three postcleithra    are present in most members of the Characiformes (state 0). Among the examined    species the first postcleithrum is absent (state 1) in <i>Diapoma</i> spp.,    <i>Mimagoniates rheocharis</i>, <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i>, <i>Puntius tetrazona</i>,    and <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i>. In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i>, as is general    in the Cypriniformes (Fink &amp; Fink, 1981; Howes, 1978, 1979, 1980), there    is a single postcleithrum, which corresponds in form and position to the second    and third postcleithra which are apparently fused into one element. Fink &amp;    Fink (1981, 1996) proposed that the loss of the first postcleithrum occurred    independently in the Gonorynchiformes, Cypriniformes, and Siluriformes. However,    the most parsimonious optimizations of this character, according to the state    distribution presented by those authors, is clearly ambiguous. It could be 
interpreted    as a gain of the first postcleithrum in the (Characiformes (Siluriformes + Gymnotiformes)),    with a secondary loss in the Siluriformes, or alternatively as a parallel acquisition    of the first postcleithrum in the Characiformes and Gonorynchiformes. In both    cases, the absence of the first postcleithrum is the most parsimonious optimization    for the clade including the Cypriniformes and the remaining Otophysi. As mentioned,    the ancestral state in the Characiformes is ambiguous, and this character is    coded as polymorphic in the root of this analysis.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>248. Second    postcleithrum: (0) present; (1) absent. (VA65, BU58, LU89, LM30, CM25m, TP55,    MO60, ZV133, QU45).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence (state    0) or absence (state 1) of the second postcleithrum was considered in several    phylogenetic analyses concerning different groups of the Characiformes. Vari    (1995) mentioned the absence of this postcleithrum in <i>Boulengerella lateristriga</i>    (Boulenger), <i>B</i>. <i>maculata</i> (Valenciennes), <i>Ctenolucius</i> spp.,    and <i>Hepsetus odoe</i>. The absence of the second postcleithrum was also mentioned    for the Gasteropelecidae (Weitzman, 1954), <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i> (Castro,    1984), <i>Lignobrycon myersi</i> (Miranda-Ribeiro) (Malabarba, 1998b), <i>Gilbertolus    atratoensis</i> Schultz (Toledo-Piza, 2000), and the species of <i>Rhabdalestes</i>    Hoedeman (Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005). In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i>, as is general    for the Cypriniformes (Fink &amp; Fink, 1981, 1996), there is a single postcleithrum    that would correspond to the fused second and third 
postcleithra based on its    position and shape. The same condition is present in the Citharinidae and Distichodontidae    (Vari, 1979). Given that the second postcleithrum is usually present in the    remaining characiforms, the ancestral state of this character for the Characiformes    is not clear and the root of this analysis is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>249. Third postcleithrum:    (0) present; (1) absent. (VA64, BU59, LU90, LM31, CM25m, TP56, ZV134, QU46,    PZ75).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence (state    0) or absence (state 1) of the third postcleithrum is usually associated to    that of the second one. Vari (1995) mentioned the absence of the third postcleithrum    in the genera <i>Boulengerella</i>, <i>Ctenolucius</i>, and <i>Hepsetus</i>    Swainson. The absence of such postcleithrum was similarly cited for the members    of the Gasteropelecidae (Weitzman, 1954), <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i> (Castro,    1984), <i>Cynodon gibbus</i>, <i>Gnathocharax steindachneri</i>, <i>Hemigrammopetersius</i>    (=<i>Rhabdalestes</i>) <i>rhodesiensis</i> (Ricardo-Bertram), <i>Paragoniates    alburnus</i>, <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>, <i>Triportheus elongatus</i> G&uuml;nther    &#91;=<i>T</i>. <i>auritus</i> (Valenciennes)&#93; (Lucena, 1993), the species    of <i>Chilodus</i> M&uuml;ller &amp; Troschel (Vari <i>et al</i>., 1995), <i>Pyrrhulina    australis</i> (Buckup, 1998), the species of <i>Lignobrycon</i> 
Eigenmann &amp;    Myers (Malabarba, 1998b), <i>Gilbertolus atratoensis</i> (Toledo-Piza, 2000),    <i>Clupeocharax schoutedeni</i>, and <i>Hemigrammopetersius barnardi</i> (Herre)    (Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>250. Form of    third postcleithrum: (0) slender, without associated lamella; (1) with a posterior    lamella. (VB42, CA22m, SE70, BE69, ZV135i, QU47, PZ76).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The third postcleithrum    is usually slender and rather sinuous as described by Weitzman (1962) for <i>Brycon    meeki</i>. The degree of curvature of this bone is almost continuously variable    among the examined species, and this variation is consequently not considered    in this paper. In some species the third postcleithrum has an associated bony    lamella dorsally (state 1; <a href="#f93">Fig. 93</a>), while this lamella is    absent in other species (state 0; <a href="#f102">Fig. 102</a>). This character    is coded as inapplicable to the species in which the third postcleithrum is    absent or fused with the second postcleithrum. The presence of a lamella associated    with the third postcleithrum is variable among the examined specimens of <i>Grundulus    cochae</i>, and this species is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>251. Dorsal    development of third postcleithrum: (0) projects dorsally to posterior region    of scapula; (1) not projects dorsally to posterior region of scapula.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The third postcleithrum    of most examined species reaches a position dorsal of the posterior projection    of the scapula (state 0). In <i>Agoniates anchovia</i>, <i>Aphyocharax</i> spp.,    and <i>Gymnocharacinus bergii</i> this postcleithrum is smaller dorsally and    reaches only the ventral margin of the posterior projection of the scapula (state    1). This character is coded as inapplicable in the species having the third    postcleithrum absent or fused with the second. It is also coded as inapplicable    to <i>Prionobrama paraguayensis</i> in which this postcleithrum is present only    as a cartilaginous structure.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Posttemporal:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>252. Position    of ventral margin of posttemporal: (0) anterior to lateral margin of epioccipital;    (1) lateral or posterior to lateral margin of epioccipital. (BE67m, B&Uuml;94m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>253. Position    of ventral end of posttemporal: (0) anterior or lateral to lateral margin of    epioccipital; (1) posterior to lateral margin of epioccipital. (BE67m, B&Uuml;94m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dorsal region    of the posttemporal bone is situated laterally to the posttemporal fossa immediately    anterior to the anterior margin of the epioccipital. From that location the    posttemporal runs obliquely posteroventrally to its articulation with the cleithrum.    The position of the ventral region of the posttemporal varies among the examined    species. Benine (2004) mentioned that the posttemporal is usually situated just    lateral to the epioccipital (character 252, state 1; character 253, state 0),    while in some species it is situated anteriorly (character 252, state 0), or    posteriorly (character 253, state 1). Benine (2004) however, did not refer to    the position of some specific region of the posttemporal, and his observations    are not directly comparable with those made here. Intermediate situations in    the second of these characters were observed in <i>Astyanax mexicanus</i>, <i>A</i>.    
<i>troya</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon bifasciatus</i>, <i>H</i>. <i>eques</i>, <i>Nantis    indefessus</i>, <i>N</i>. cf. <i>indefessus</i>, and <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>,    which are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Supracleithrum:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>254. Ventral    exit of laterosensory canal of supracleithrum: (0) covered by posterior lamella    of supracleithrum and exiting medially; (1) ventral to lamella of supracleithrum    and exiting on posterior margin of this bone. (SE71m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The posterior margin    of the supracleithrum overlaps to some degree the anterior scales of the body.    This bone is pierced by a laterosensory canal that exits towards the first scale    of the lateral line; however, with the region where the canal exits the supracleithrum    variable. In most examined species the supracleithrum bears a lamellar posterior    region dorsally margining, at least partially, the first scale of the lateral    line. In these species the laterosensory canal exits near the posterior margin    of the supracleithrum within a notch formed by the lamella and the main body    of the supracleithrum (state 1; <a href="#f48">Fig. 48</a>). In some species    this notch is absent and the posterior lamella of the supracleithrum extensively    laterally covers the first scale of the lateral line. In these species the laterosensory    canal of the supracleithrum exits medial to the supracleithrum (state 0; 
<a href="#f47">Fig.    47</a>). A different situation was observed in <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i>,    in which the laterosensory canal of the supracleithrum exits laterally to the    bone. This character is coded as inapplicable for this species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>255. Fusion    between posttemporal and supracleithrum: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The posttemporal    and supracleithrum are independent ossifications (state 0) in most examined    species. Weitzman (1954) mentioned that in his Gasteropelecinae (=Gasteropelecidae)    the posttemporal and supracleithrum are fused into a single ossification (state    1; Weitzman, 1954: <a href="#f7">fig. 7</a>). This state was also mentioned    by Castro (1984) for <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i>; this author considered this    fusion as an autapomorphy of this species that is absent in <i>Clupeacharax    anchoveoides</i> Pearson, the hypothesized sister taxon of <i>E</i>. <i>taeniatum</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Pelvic girdle</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Pelvic fin:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>256. First pelvic-fin    ray: (0) not branched; (1) branched. (VB55).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The first pelvic-fin    ray is not branched in most examined species (state 0). Bertaco (2003) mentioned    that this ray is branched in the species of <i>Hollandichthys</i> (state 1)    and a synapomorphy of the genus. Quevedo (2006) reported the branching of this    ray in <i>Mimagoniates rheocharis</i>, although the specimens of the species    herein examined have state 0. This species is coded as polymorphic in light    of possible intraspecific variability.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>257. Relative    length of first pelvic-fin ray of adult males: (0) not extending beyond margin    of other rays; (1) extending beyond margin of other rays. (MA15, B&Uuml;103).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The first, usually    unbranched, pelvic-fin ray is slightly longer than the remaining rays in most    examined species (state 0). Malabarba (1998a) mentioned that this ray extends    distinctly beyond the remaining pelvic-fin rays in <i>Odontostilbe fugitiva</i>    Cope, <i>O</i>. <i>mitoptera</i> (Fink &amp; Weitzman), and <i>O</i>. <i>pequira</i>    (state 1; B&uuml;hrnheim &amp; Malabarba, 2007: <a href="#f23">fig. 23</a>).    According to the phylogeny proposed by Malabarba (1998a), this state is a synapomorphy    of <i>Odontostilbe</i> Cope.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>258. Number    of branched pelvic-fin rays: (0) six or less; (1) seven or more. (BU63m, LU95m,    MA14i, MO68m, VB57m, BE70, ZV138m, QU59m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>259. Number    of branched pelvic-fin rays: (0) seven or less; (1) eight or more. (BU63m, LU95m,    MO68m, VB57m, ZV138m, QU59m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    of the Characidae have seven branched pelvic-fin rays (character 258, state    1; character 259, state 0). The presence of only six branched pelvic-fin rays    (character 258, state 0) was cited as diagnostic for <i>Cyanocharax</i> (Malabarba    &amp; Weitzman, 2003). Intraspecific variability between six and seven branched    pelvic-fin rays was observed in <i>Aphyocharax nattereri</i> and <i>Hemigrammus    erythrozonus</i>, which are coded as polymorphic for the character 258. The    presence of eight or more branched pelvic-fin rays (character 259, state 1)    was reported by some members of the Citharinidae, Crenuchidae, Distichodontidae,    Hemiodontidae (Buckup, 1998), and Alestidae (Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005). Variations    between seven and eight branched pelvic-fin rays were observed in <i>Astyanax    paris</i>, <i>Hemigrammus bleheri</i>, and <i>Leporinus striatus</i>, which    are coded as 
polymorphic for the second of these characters.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Pelvic bone:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>260. Pelvic    bone: (0) not bifurcate anteriorly; (1) bifurcate with conspicuous notch. (UJ26,    BU62i, MO69m, ZV139i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the pelvic bone has an overall cylindrical longitudinal axis and a variably    developed medial lamella (state 0). Vari (1979) proposed the anterior bifurcation    of the pelvic bone (state 1; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f29">fig. 29</a>)    as a synapomorphy of the Citharinidae plus Distichodontidae. According to Fink    &amp; Fink (1981) these families form the sister group of the remaining characiforms    and this shape of pelvic bone is a synapomorphy of the Otophysi and consequently    plesiomorphic for the Characiformes. Buckup (1998) observed the anterior bifurcation    of the pelvic bone in <i>Crenuchus spilurus</i>, <i>Distichodus maculatus</i>,    and <i>Xenocharax spilurus</i>, coding it as absent in <i>Citharinus gibbosus</i>,    among others, indicating some variability within the Citharinidae. Zanata &amp;    Vari (2005) mentioned a similar bifurcation in the examined 
species of <i>Bryconaethiops.</i></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>261. Articulation    between pelvic bones: (0) through ligaments; (1) with bony interdigitations    between ischiatic processes.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the pelvic bones are loosely joined by ligaments (state 0). This situation    is particularly pronounced in <i>Acestrocephalus sardina</i>, <i>Cynopotamus    argenteus</i>, and <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i>, in which the pelvic bones are    relatively broadly separated from each other; such variation, however, is not    considered in this paper. In a relatively small group of species, the pelvic    bones articulate each other by way of bony interdigitations of their ischiatic    processes (state 1). The articulation of the pelvic bones was reported by Uj    (1990) for <i>Agoniates anchovia</i> and by Winterbottom (1980) for the anostomid    <i>Pseudanos trimaculatus</i> (Kner). Castro (1984) mentioned this condition    also in <i>Clupeacharax anchoveoides</i> and <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i>;    proposing it as a putative synapomorphy of a clade composed of these two taxa.    Castro considered 
the state of these genera as different to that of <i>Agoniates,</i>    in which such processes are articulated by way of a cartilage. The condition    in <i>Agoniates</i>, <i>Clupeacharax</i>, and <i>Engraulisoma</i> are herein    all coded as state 1.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>262. Anterior    extension of pelvic-bone along main axis: (0) not projecting anterior of lateral    and medial lamellae; (1) projecting anterior of lateral and medial lamellae    of pelvic bone. (CM26, ZV140, PZ86i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The medial margin    of the pelvic bone is formed by a cylindrical process, whose anterior tip terminates    in a small cartilage in almost all the examined species. The anterior portion    of the pelvic bone along its primary axis is situated near the anterior confluence    of the lateral and medial pelvic bony lamellae. In these cases the primary axis    of the pelvic bone does not extend anteriorly (state 0). Malabarba (1998b) considered    the anterior projection of the primary axis of the pelvic bone beyond the lateral    and medial lamellae (state 1; Malabarba, 1998b: <a href="#f12">fig. 12</a>)    as a synapomorphy for a clade composed of <i>Lignobrycon</i> and <i>Triportheus</i>.    In <i>Jupiaba</i> spp., the anterior portion of the pelvic bone is modified    as an acute point, and this character is coded as inapplicable. This character    is also coded as inapplicable for the species in which the pelvic bone is 
anteriorly    bifurcate.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>263. Anterior    tip of pelvic bone: (0) rounded and capped by a small cartilage; (1) pointed,    lacking associated cartilage and frequently projecting outside body wall.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anterior end    of the pelvic-bone primary axis is rounded and capped by a small cartilage in    most species in the Characiformes (state 0). In the species of <i>Jupiaba</i>    this bone is very acute anteriorly and lacks this cartilage (Zanata, 1997) (state    1; Zanata, 1997: <a href="#f4">fig. 4A</a>). In some species of this genus,    the anterior tip of the pelvic bone pierces the body wall and projects outside    as an externally visible spine. State 1 was observed only in the examined species    of <i>Jupiaba.</i></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>264. Dorsal    longitudinal ridge on medial lamella of pelvic bone: (0) present; (1) absent.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The principal axis    of the pelvic bone is bordered medially by a variably developed lamella. This    lamella is usually uniformly thin (state 1; <a href="#f103">Fig. 103</a>), whereas    in some species the medial lamella has instead a dorsal longitudinal ridge that    forms a secondary axis which diverges anteriorly from the primary axis (state    0; <a href="#f104">Fig. 104</a>); this character is coded as inapplicable to    species with an anteriorly bifurcate pelvic bone.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Epineurals,    supraneurals, and dorsal fin skeleton</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Dorsal fin:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>265. Relative    position of dorsal-fin anterior insertion: (0) anterior to or at vertical through    pelvic-fin origin; (1) posterior to vertical through pelvic-fin origin. (CM29m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    characids, the dorsal fin is situated posterior to the vertical through the    pelvic-fin origin (state 0). In some species, mostly in the outgroup, the dorsal-fin    origin is situated at the vertical through the pelvic-fin insertion or slightly    anterior of that line (state 1). This character varies among the examined specimens    of <i>Bryconops affinis</i> and the <i>A</i>. <i>eugeniae</i> is coded as polymorphic.    The cyprinids <i>Opsariichthys</i> spp., <i>Puntius tetrazona</i>, and <i>Zacco</i>    spp. and, usually, the siluriforms have also the state 0. The root of this analysis    was consequently coded as this state, although many species in the Cypriniformes    have state 1 (Pflieger, 1997).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>266. Dorsal-fin    rays articulating with first dorsal pterygiophore: (0) two; (1) three or four.    (LU98i, SE75, ZV124i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The unbranched    dorsal-fin rays articulate with the first proximal dorsal-fin pterygiophore    with the number of rays articulating with that pterygiophore variable among    the examined species. Lucena (1993) coded his functional outgroup and several    species as having three or more rays articulating with this pterygiophore (state    1). Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) mentioned the presence of only two rays associated    with the first dorsal pterygiophore (state 0) in the members of the Alestidae    and considered the possession of three rays as a common condition among the    Neotropical characiforms. The presence of only two unbranched and eight branched    dorsal-fin rays (ii+8) was considered by Malabarba &amp; Weitzman (2003) as    a diagnostic character of their clade A. This character is variable among the    examined specimens of <i>Aphyodite grammica</i>, <i>Astyanax paris</i>, <i>Brycon    pesu</i>, <i>Carlana 
eigenmanni</i>, <i>Hollandichthys multifasciatus</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon    herbertaxelrodi</i>, <i>Inpaichthys kerri</i>, <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i>,    <i>Moenkhausia</i> cf. <i>intermedia</i>, <i>Oligosarcus</i> cf. <i>jenynsii</i>,    <i>Parecbasis cyclolepis</i>, and <i>Roeboides descalvadensis</i>, which are    coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>267. Anteriorly    oriented spine formed by first dorsal-fin ray: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Among the species    having three unbranched dorsal-fin rays, the first ray is usually similar to    the posterior ones, but smaller (state 0). The Stethaprioninae was diagnosed    by G&eacute;ry (1964a) as having the first dorsal-fin ray oriented anteriorly    to form a spine (state 1; <a href="#f105">Fig. 105</a>); Reis (1989) considered    this state to be a synapomorphy of this subfamily. G&eacute;ry (1977: 367) illustrated    an anterior projection of the first dorsal-fin ray of <i>Prochilodus</i>; however,    as noted by this author, this projection have paired anterior processes, rather    than a medial spine as in the Stethaprioninae of Reis (1989) and the situation    in <i>Prochilodus</i> is considered non-homologous to that described in the    state 1.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>268. Anterior    rays of dorsal fin of adult males: (0) not elongate; (1) elongate and reaching    posteriorly to position close to adipose fin. (VB36, CA28).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dorsal fin    in most examined species is not sexually dimorphic, or when elongate it does    not demonstrate the overall shape in males described for state 1. Cardoso (2003b)    reported the posterior elongation of the first dorsal-fin rays (state 1) in    adult males of <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i>, <i>Nematocharax venustus</i>, <i>Parastremma    pulchrum</i> Dahl, <i>Pseudochalceus</i> spp., <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i>,    and <i>Rhoadsia</i> spp. In this condition, the last unbranched and first branched    dorsal-fin rays reach posteriorly almost to the adipose fin. In <i>Odontostilbe</i>    spp. only the last unbranched dorsal-fin ray is extended as a filament. This    situation is herein considered as non-homologous to state 1 but rather treated    in the following character.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>269. Last unbranched    dorsal-fin ray of adult males: (0) approximately as long as first branched ray;    (1) distinctly longer than first branched ray and in the form of filament. (MA11,    B&Uuml;102).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the last unbranched and the first branched dorsal-fin rays are the    longest rays with the dorsal-fin rays gradually decreasing in length posteriorly    (state 0). Malabarba (1998a) noted that the posteriormost unbranched dorsal-fin    ray is much longer than the remaining rays and extended as a filament (state    1; B&uuml;hrnheim &amp; Malabarba, 2007: <a href="#f23">fig. 23</a>) in adult    males of <i>Odontostilbe fugitiva</i> and <i>Holoshesthes</i> (=<i>Odontostilbe</i>)    <i>pequira</i> . According to Malabarba (1998a), the elongation of this ray    is a synapomorphy for the species of <i>Odontostilbe.</i></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>270. Number    of branched-rays on dorsal-fin: (0) eight or fewer; (1) nine or more. (AM2m,    VB38m, BE64m, QU38m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The number of branched    dorsal-fin rays is rather uniform across the Characiformes with most examined    species having nine rays (state 1). Malabarba &amp; Weitzman (2003) partially    diagnosed their clade A by the shared possession of only eight branched dorsal-fin    rays (state 0) in almost all the members of that clade, with this state also    present is <i>Clupeacharax</i> and <i>Engraulisoma</i> and variably in <i>Paracheirodon</i>,    <i>Piabucus</i>, <i>Serrabrycon</i> Vari, and <i>Tyttobrycon</i> G&eacute;ry.    Malabarba &amp; Weitzman (2003) mentioned the presence of nine branched dorsal-fin    rays in an examined paratype of <i>Aulixidens eugeniae</i>; however the four    examined specimens of this species have only eight rays and the species is coded    here as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>271. Relative    length of anterior dorsal-fin rays: (0) not reaching tip of posterior rays when    adpressed; (1) reaching tip of posterior rays when adpressed.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i>,    as usual in the Cypriniformes, the length of the posterior dorsal-fin rays is    similar to that of the anterior rays, consequently reaching more posteriorly    in the adpressed fin (state 1). In most characid species, the anterior rays    are proportionally longer and extend posteriorly to the tip of posterior rays,    when the fin is adpressed (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>272. Number    of dorsal-fin rays on last pterygiophore: (0) one; (1) two, adnate. (BU64i,    LU100i, MO78i, ZV126i).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined characids    have only one ray in the last dorsal-fin pterygiophore (state 0), while the    last two dorsal-fin rays articulate with the last dorsal-fin pterygiophore (state    1) in several species of the outgroup. According to the phylogenetic hypothesis    of Buckup (1998), the presence of only one ray articulating with the last pterygiophore    is a synapomorphy of a clade composed of the Acestrorhynchidae, Characidae,    Ctenoluciidae, Erythrinidae, Hepsetidae, and Lebiasinidae. Under the phylogeny    of Lucena (1993), the presence of two rays on the last dorsal-fin pterygiophore    is a synapomorphy of the Cynodontidae, that independently occurs in a clade    composed of <i>Alestes</i>, <i>Brycon</i>, <i>Chalceus</i>, <i>Rhabdalestes</i>,    <i>Hydrocynus</i>, and <i>Serrasalmus</i> Lac&eacute;p&egrave;de, with a reversal    in <i>Brycon</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Intermuscular    bones:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>273. Dorsal    myorhabdoi: (0) absent; (1) present. (TP67).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dorsal myorhabdoi    are slender intermuscular bones situated dorsal to the epineurals (Chapman,    1944; Weitzman, 1954). These bones are present (state 1; Weitzman, 1954: <a href="#f2">fig.    2</a>) in the Gasteropelecidae (Weitzman, 1954), the species of <i>Citharinus</i>    Cuvier, and <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i> (Toledo-Piza, 2000), but absent (state    0) in most members of the Characiformes.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>274. Position    of anteriormost epineurals: (0) lateral to fourth or fifth vertebrae; (1) reaching    to cranium. (LM38, MO85m, ZV123m, PZ74).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the anteriormost epineurals are situated posterior to the fourth or    fifth vertebrae (state 0). In some taxa including species of <i>Carnegiella</i>    Eigenmann, <i>Thoracocharax</i> Fowler (Weitzman, 1954), <i>Clupeacharax</i>    (Castro, 1984), <i>Acestrorhynchus</i>, <i>Agoniates</i>, <i>Chalceus</i>, <i>Cynodon</i>,    <i>Gilbertolus</i>, <i>Lignobrycon</i>, <i>Rhaphiodon</i>, <i>Triportheus</i>    (Lucena &amp; Menezes, 1998), <i>Brycinus</i>, <i>Hydrocynus</i>, and <i>Micralestes</i>    Boulenger (Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005), the anterior epineurals are situated along    the posterior margin of the cranium, and in some of these species they originate    in the posttemporal fossa (state 1; <a href="#f5">Fig. 5</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Dorsal pterygiophores:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>275. Predorsal    spine formed by first dorsal pterygiophore: (0) absent; (1) present. (AM21).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    a predorsal spine formed by the first dorsal-fin pterygiophore was proposed    by Machado-Allison (1983) as a synapomorphy of the Serrasalmidae (state 1).    This spine is absent (state 0) in some Serrasalmidae and all non-serrasalmid    Characiformes.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>276. Number    of dorsal pterygiophores: (0) nine; (1) 10 or more. (LU97m, VB38m, ZV125m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>277. Number    of dorsal pterygiophores: (0) 10 or less; (1) 11 or more. (LU97m, VB38m, ZV125m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>278. Number    of dorsal pterygiophores: (0) 11 or less; (1) 12 or more. (LU97m, VB38m, ZV125m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have 10 dorsal-fin pterygiophores and nine branched dorsal-fin rays (character    276, state 1). Lucena (1993) mentioned the presence of 11 or more dorsal pterygiophores    (character 277, state 1) in <i>Chalceus</i> sp., <i>Cynodon gibbus</i>, <i>Hoplias    malabaricus</i>, <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>, and <i>Serrasalmus</i> (=<i>Pristobrycon</i>)    <i>striolatus</i> (Steindachner). Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) mentioned the presence    of 18 pterygiophores in <i>Crenuchus</i> G&uuml;nther, 13 in <i>Hoplias</i>,    14 in <i>Piaractus</i> Eigenmann, 16 in <i>Serrasalmus</i>, and 18 in <i>Xenocharax</i>    (character 278, state 1). Variations between 10 and 11 pterygiophores were herein    observed in <i>Hyphessobrycon herbertaxelrodi</i> and <i>Inpaichthys kerri</i>,    which are coded as polymorphic for character 277.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Supraneurals:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>279. Supraneural    anterior to neural spine of fourth vertebra: (0) absent or small; (1) present    and vertically elongate. (BU47, LU96, MO74, SE98i, BE63i, ZV122, LI45, QU90,    PZ76).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The supraneurals    are situated between the neural spines anterior to the dorsal-fin pterygiophores.    In most examined species the anteriormost supraneural is situated between the    neural spines of the fourth and fifth vertebrae (state 1), whereas in some species    there is a supraneural situated more anteriorly, anterior to the neural spine    of the fourth vertebra (state 0; <a href="#f7">Fig. 7</a>). According to Buckup    (1998) the loss of this supraneural would be a synapomorphy of a clade composed    of the genera <i>Oligosarcus</i>, <i>Tetragonopterus</i>, <i>Phenacogaster</i>,    <i>Charax</i>, and <i>Cynopotamus</i>. Under the phylogenetic hypothesis of    Lucena (1993) this supraneural was independently lost in four clades and a synapomorphy    for a clade including most of the Characidae except for <i>Agoniates</i>, <i>Brycon</i>,    <i>Bryconops</i>, <i>Hemibrycon</i>, <i>Roeboexodon</i>, and 
<i>Triportheus</i>.    Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) observed that in the Alestidae the absence of this    supraneural is rather correlated with events of miniaturization. This supraneural    is present in the examined specimen of <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i>, contrary    to the observations of Lucena (1993). This species is coded as polymorphic in    light of possible intraspecific variability. In <i>Apareiodon affinis</i>, <i>Parodon    nasus</i>, and <i>Prochilodus lineatus</i>, there is a large supraneural bounding    anteriorly, dorsally, and posteriorly the neural spine of the fourth vertebra.    Since the homology of this supraneural with the one treated here is uncertain,    this character is coded as inapplicable for these species. In the examined specimens    of <i>Hasemania nana</i>, there is an additional supraneural situated just posterior    to the neural spine of the fourth vertebra. Given that the homology of this    additional supraneural is unclear, this character is 
also coded as inapplicable    for <i>H</i>. <i>nana</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>280. Number    of supraneurals: (0) four or fewer; (1) five or more. (MO76m, SE95m, BE61m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>281. Number    of supraneurals: (0) seven or fewer; (1) eight or more. (MO76m, SE95m, LI46,    QU78m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">This character    is related with the dorsal-fin position and the number of vertebrae; however,    it is included as a separate feature given its potential phylogenetic informativeness    at different levels. This character is coded considering the intraspecific variations    mentioned in the original species descriptions. The examined specimen of <i>Puntius    tetrazona</i> has only four supraneurals, but <i>Barilius</i>, a genus related    with <i>Opsariichthys</i> has 13 (Howes, 1978), covering the entire range of    variation considered for this character between these species. Therefore, the    root of this analysis is coded as polymorphic for both these characters.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>282. Bony lamellae    associated with supraneurals: (0) absent or small; (1) wider than primary axis    of supraneurals. (MO75m, SE96m, BE62, LI44).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The supraneurals    usually have a more or less vertical, cylindrical, body, and variably developed    anterior and posterior bony lamellae, which when present are wider dorsally.    The degree of development of these lamellae is difficult to define as discrete    states. The herein recognized states are lamellae that are absent or are narrower    than the main cylindrical body of the supraneurals (state 0), and that in which    the lamellae are wider than the body (state 1). This character is coded as polymorphic    in the species in which these lamellae are variably present.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>283. Position    of last supraneural: (0) located two or fewer vertebrae in front of first dorsal    pterygiophore; (1) located more than two vertebrae in front of first dorsal    pterygiophore.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The posteriormost    supraneural in most examined species is situated between the neural spines of    the vertebrae immediately anterior to the first dorsal-fin pterygiophore (state    0). In a few species the posteriormost supraneural is distant three or more    neural spines from the first dorsal pterygiophore (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Anal fin and    pterygiophores</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Anal fin:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>284. Anal-fin    position: (0) posterior or almost posterior to vertical through last dorsal-fin    ray. (1) extended anteriorly ventral to dorsal fin. (EI16, MO77).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anal-fin origin,    in most examined species, is situated at or posterior to the vertical through    the base of the posteriormost dorsal-fin ray (state 0), whereas in some species    the anal fin extends anteriorly below the middle of the dorsal fin (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>285. Number    of unbranched anal-fin rays: (0) three or fewer; (1) four or more (ZV142m, LI51m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have four to six unbranched anal-fin rays (state 1), with a high intraspecific    variation within this range. Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) mentioned that most alestids    have only three unbranched anal-fin rays (state 0), sharing this state with    <i>Crenuchus spilurus</i>, <i>Hepsetus odoe</i>, and <i>Hoplias microlepis</i>,    among the species examined by them, with most characids having four or five    of such rays (state 1; <a href="#f106">Fig. 106</a>). This character is herein    coded as polymorphic in <i>Aphyocharacidium bolivianum</i>, in which a variation    between three or four rays was observed.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>286. Number    of branched anal-fin rays: (0) 10 or less; (1) 11 or more. (UJ76m, BU65m, LU103m,    SE92m, BE78m, LI52m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>287. Number    of branched anal-fin rays: (0) 17 or less; (1) 18 or more. (LU103m, WM35i, MO80m,    SE92m, BE78m, LI52m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>288. Number    of branched anal-fin rays: (0) 24 or less; (1) 25 or more. (CM30m, MO80m, SE92m,    BE78m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>289. Number    of branched anal-fin rays: (0) 34 or less; (1) 35 or more. (BU66m, LU104m, CM30m,    MO80m, SE92m, BE78m, QU61m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The number of anal-fin    rays is used in species-level systematic studies of many genera of the Characidae.    However, this number is highly variable within some evidently monophyletic clades    and its phylogenetic utility may be mostly restricted to the resolution of rather    small clades. Notably, however, supposedly basal Cypriniformes and Siluriformes    and most non-characid Characiformes have a relatively low number of branched    anal-fin rays (character 286, state 0), while most species of the Characidae    have usually more than 15 rays (character 286, state 1). Buckup (1998) proposed    the presence of 19 or more total anal-fin rays as a synapomorphy of a clade    including the Alestidae, Characidae, Acestrorhynchidae, Erythrinidae, Lebiasinidae,    Hepsetidae, and Ctenoluciidae, with a reversal in a clade formed by the four    latter families. According to the hypothesis of Lucena (1993) the presence of    
14 or more anal-fin rays is a synapomorphy of a clade composed of the Acestrorhynchidae,    Alestidae, Characidae, Cynodontidae, and Serrasalmidae. This character involves    only the branched anal-fin rays, instead of total rays, as in Lucena (1993)    and Buckup (1998). This coding system has advantages in terms of homology assessment,    avoiding the coding of dissimilar arrangements as the same character state (<i>e</i>.    <i>g</i>. ii+15 rays <i>vs</i>. v+12 rays). Coding of these four characters    includes ranges of intraspecific variation taken from the original descriptions    and systematic and faunistic revisions (Eigenmann, 1912, 1915, 1917, 1918, 1921,    1927; Eigenmann &amp; Myers, 1929; G&eacute;ry, 1977; Ringuelet <i>et al</i>.,    1967; Reis, 1989; Vari &amp; Harold, 2001; Zanata &amp; Toledo-Piza, 2004).    Most examined species have 18 to 35 branched anal-fin rays. The species having    ranges of variation comprising more than one state were coded as 
polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>290. Form and    length of anterior anal-fin rays: (0) similar to posterior rays; (1) longer    and more compressed laterally than posterior rays. (B&Uuml;109m, B&Uuml;112m,    B&Uuml;113m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the anterior anal-fin rays are rather similar in form to the posterior    rays (state 0). B&uuml;hrnheim (2006) mentioned that the adult males of <i>Axelrodia    lindeae</i>, the species of <i>Heterocheirodon</i> Malabarba, the species of    <i>Serrapinnus</i> Malabarba, and two species of <i>Spintherobolus</i> have    a series of modifications in the anterior anal-fin rays of males. These involve    the presence of a lobe formed by rays bearing bony hooks, with the rays much    compressed laterally and whose proximal portions are joined by strong ligaments    (state 1; <a href="#f106">Fig. 106</a>). These three characters are here considered    a single feature, because they are functionally correlated, and given that the    presence or absence of a lobe and the degree of development of the ligaments    between the anal-fin rays are difficult to define as discrete states. In 
<i>Acestrorhynchus    pantaneiro</i> the anterior anal-fin rays are much elongated relative to the    posterior rays, forming a pronounced lobe. This state is not, however, exclusive    to the males and it is not considered homologous with state 1 of this character.    An intermediate condition between the defined states was observed in <i>Aphyocharacidium    bolivianum</i>, which is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>291. Number    of rays on last anal pterygiophore: (0) two; (1) one.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have two rays articulating with the posteriormost anal-fin pterygiophore (state    0; <a href="#f106">Fig. 106</a>). The examined specimens of <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>    and <i>Hasemania nana</i> instead have only one ray articulating with that pterygiophore    (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Anal-fin pterygiophores:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>292. Anterior    notch on first anal pterygiophore: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The cylindrical    main body of the anteriormost anal pterygiophore, among the examined species,    is limited anteriorly by a variably developed bony lamella. The anterior margin    of this lamella lacks notches in most taxa (state 0). The examined members of    the Parodontidae and <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i> instead have a marked notch    (state 1) along the dorsal margin of the lamella.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>293. Number    of anal pterygiophores anterior to first haemal spine: (0) three or fewer; (1)    four or more. (LU101, LC41).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most species    the dorsal portion of the first proximal anal-fin pterygiophore is situated    between the anteriormost haemal spines (state 0). Lucena (1998) proposed that    the anterior displacement of the anal fin relative to the haemal spines, with    at least four anal pterygiophores anterior to the first haemal spine (state    1) is a synapomorphy of a clade composed of <i>Charax</i> and <i>Roeboides</i>.    Lucena coded <i>Cynopotamus</i> spp. as state 0, but the specimen of <i>C</i>.    <i>argenteus</i> herein examined has seven pterygiophores anterior to the first    haemal spine, and is coded as state 1.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>294. Proximal    and medial radials of anal fins: (0) fused on anterior five pterygiophores;    (1) fused in most pterygiophores; (2) medial radials absent or completely fused    with proximal ones. (BE82m, ZV190m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anal pterygiophores    are composed of three radials of which the proximal is the longest, extending    dorsally between the haemal spines of caudal vertebrae. The medial and distal    radials are much smaller and participate in the articulation of the pterygiophore    with the corresponding anal-fin ray. In most characids the four or five anterior    proximal anal pterygiophores are fused with the corresponding medial ones, while    in the remaining pterygiophores the three radials are independent ossifications    (state 0). In some species most pterygiophores, instead, have the proximal and    medial pterygiophores fused and only a few posteriormost pterygiophores have    three independent radials (state 1). In the examined specimens of <i>Carnegiella    strigata</i>, <i>Characidium</i> spp., <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>,    <i>Metynnis maculatus</i>, <i>Piaractus mesopotamicus</i>, <i>Pyrrhulina 
australis</i>,    <i>Serrasalmus maculatus</i>, and <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i> the medial    radials are completely absent or fused with the proximal radials in all the    pterygiophores (state 2). Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) mentioned that in the Ctenoluciidae    and Erythrinidae (as also herein observed in <i>Characidium</i> and <i>Pyrrhulina</i>)    the form of the proximal radials suggests their fusion with the medial radials,    while in the Serrasalmidae (as also herein observed in <i>Carnegiella</i> and    <i>Thoracocharax</i>) the medial radials appear to be primarily absent. Both    conditions are coded with the state 2, pending further studies.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>295. Lateral    lamellae on anterior anal pterygiophores: (0) absent; (1) present. (ZV144m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species, the anal pterygiophores have two associated bony lamellae positioned    anteriorly and posteriorly to their main body (state 0). Some species of the    outgroup have, in addition, two lateral lamellae giving the pterygiophores a    cross-shaped transverse section (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Caudal skeleton</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Epurals:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>296. Number    of epurals: (0) one; (1) two or three. (BU68, LU106i, VH55, MO88m, BE85i, PZ90m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>297. Number    of epurals: (0) one or two; (1) three. (BU69, LU107, CM33, MO88m, ZV148, PZ90m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The number of epurals    in the Characiformes varies from one to three, but most species have two epurals    (character 296, state 1, character 297, state 0; <a href="#f107">Fig. 107</a>).    The presence of only one epural (character 296, state 0; <a href="#f108">Fig.    108</a>) was mentioned for several species in the Characiformes (Lucena, 1993;    Buckup, 1998; Moreira, 2002, Benine, 2004; Lima, 2006). Two epurals were observed    herein in <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i>, <i>Gymnocorymbus ternetzi</i> (Boulenger),    <i>Hemigrammus unilineatus</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon eques</i>, <i>Parecbasis cyclolepis</i>,    and <i>Piabina argentea</i>, differing with observations of Lucena (1993), Moreira    (2002), Benine (2004), and Lima (2006). These species are coded as polymorphic    for character 296, in light of possible intraspecific variability. Variation    between one and two epurals was observed in <i>Pristella 
maxillaris</i> which    is coded as polymorphic for this character. The presence of three epurals (character    297, state 1; <a href="#f109">Fig. 109</a>) was mentioned for several mostly    non-characid Characiformes (Buckup, 1998; Moreira, 2002; Zanata &amp; Vari,    2005; Lima, 2006).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Hypurals:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>298. Fusion    of hypural 2 to compound centrum: (0) absent; (1) present. (UJ28m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The fusion of the    hypural 2 with the compound centrum (state 1; <a href="#f108">Fig. 108</a>)    was proposed by Fink &amp; Fink (1981, 1996) as a synapomorphy of the Otophysi.    Zanata &amp; Vari (2005: 122) mentioned that this fusion is present in most    Characiformes, being secondarily absent (state 0; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f30">fig.    30</a>) in a few taxa which usually have the hypurals 1 and 2 fused to each    other. According to Roberts (1969: <a href="#f56">figs. 56-58</a> and <a href="#f60">60</a>),    the hypural 2 is not fused to the compound centrum in <i>Ctenolucius</i>, <i>Hepsetus</i>,    <i>Hoplias</i>, and <i>Hydrocynus</i>. Roberts (1974: <a href="#f18">figs. 18</a>,    <a href="#f38">38</a>, and <a href="#f39">39</a>) illustrated such a condition    also in the hemiodontids <i>Argonectes</i>, <i>Bivibranchia</i> Eigenmann, and    <i>Hemiodus</i> M&uuml;ller. Miquelarena (1982) 
mentioned that in <i>Rhaphiodon</i>    the hypurals 2 and 3 are fused and articulated, but not fused, with the compound    centrum. Zanata &amp; Vari (2005), in the discussion on the phylogenetic position    of <sup>&#8224;</sup><i>Mahengecharax carrolli</i> Murray, indicated that the    hypural 2 is fused with the compound centrum in the Alestidae with the exception    of the miniature species <i>Lepidarchus adonis</i>. In this species both hypurals    are fused each other but separated from the compound centrum; however they (Zanata    &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f30">fig. 30</a>) illustrated an autogenous hypural    2 in <i>Brycinus macrolepidotus</i>, and Murray (2004: <a href="#f13">fig. 13</a>)    illustrated six autogenous hypurals in <i>Alestes stuhlmannii</i> (Pfeffer).    The absence of fusion between the hypural 2 and the compound centrum is usually    correlated with the fusion of the hypurals 1 and 2 (Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005);    however, some exceptions were herein 
observed, and these characters are coded    as separate in this paper. Intraspecific variability was observed in <i>Heterocharax    macrolepis</i>, which is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>299. Fusion    between hypurals 1 and 2: (0) absent; (1) present. (UJ28m, BU71, LU109).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">As mentioned above,    the fusion between the hypurals 1 and 2 (state 1) is often correlated with the    lack of fusion between the hypural 2 and the compound centrum, but as this correlation    is not perfect, these characters are coded as separate.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>300. Posterior    margin of hypural 3: (0) equal to or narrower than posterior margin of hypural    4; (1) deeper than posterior margin of hypural 4.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In the Characiformes    and especially in the Characidae the posterior margin of the hypural 3 is usually    deeper than that of the hypural 4 (state 1; <a href="#f107">Fig. 107</a>), while    in a group of species of the outgroup the posterior margin of the hypural 3    is equal or more slender than the hypural 4 (state 0; <a href="#f109">Fig. 109</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Procurrent rays:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>301. Ventral    procurrent caudal-fin rays of adult males: (0) slender; (1) laminar. (MA45m,    B&Uuml;127m, B&Uuml;135).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In the generalized    condition described by Weitzman (1962) for <i>Brycon meeki</i>, the lepidotrichia    that form each procurrent ray are autogenous or are fused only at their ventral    portion. In these cases the procurrent rays are similar to the principal caudal-fin    rays but shorter or, if corresponding lepidotrichia are fused each other, they    are as slender as the principal caudal-fin rays (state 0; <a href="#f107">Fig.    107</a>). Malabarba (1998a) proposed the fusion and anteroventral expansion    of the corresponding lepidotrichia of all the procurrent rays along their entire    length, forming laminar structures (state 1; <a href="#f110">Fig. 110</a>),    as a synapomorphy of the tribe Cheirodontini.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>302. Number    of ventral procurrent caudal-fin rays: (0) 11 or fewer; (1) 12 or more. (MA42m,    VB74m, B&Uuml;124m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The number of ventral    procurrent rays is 11 or fewer in most examined species (state 0). Malabarba    (1998a) considered the presence of more than 11 ventral procurrent rays (state    1) as a synapomorphy of the Cheirodontini (see previous character). Miquelarena    (1982) mentioned a higher number of rays in <i>Roeboides bonariensis</i> (Steindachner)    (=<i>R</i>. <i>microlepis</i>), <i>Acestrorhynchus altus</i> Menezes (=<i>A</i>.    <i>pantaneiro</i>), <i>Moenkhausia dichroura</i>, and <i>Tetragonopterus argenteus</i>.    Up to 11 ventral procurrent rays were observed in <i>Roeboides microlepis</i>    (11 in 1 ex.), <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i> (11 in 1 ex.), <i>Moenkhausia    dichroura</i> (11 in 2 ex.), and <i>Tetragonopterus argenteus</i> (8-9 in 2    ex.) and these species are thus coded as polymorphic for this character, in    light of possible intraspecific variability. Variation between the defined 
states    was observed in <i>Acestrocephalus sardina</i>, <i>Aphyocharacidium bolivianum</i>,    <i>Axelrodia lindeae</i>, <i>Bryconamericus thomasi</i>, and <i>Gymnocharacinus    bergii</i>, which are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>303. Ventral    procurrent caudal-fin rays of adult males: (0) not projecting through musculature    and skin of peduncle; (1) projecting ventrally through peduncle musculature    and skin. (MA47, B&Uuml;129).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have their anteriormost ventral procurrent rays contained completely within    the skin and musculature of the caudal peduncle and not projecting ventrally    as a keel (state 0). Malabarba (1998a) proposed as a synapomorphy of the Cheirodontini    the ventral projection of such procurrent rays through the musculature and skin    forming an externally visible keel (state 1; <a href="#f110">Fig. 110</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>304. Caudal-fin    bony stays: (0) absent; (1) present. (VA82, BU67, LU105, ZV150).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    caudal stays (sensu Roberts, 1969) was mentioned several times in some studies    treating the Ctenoluciidae (Vari, 1995) and Alestidae (Murray &amp; Stewart,    2002; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005), in which they are particularly developed (state    1; Zanata &amp; Vari, 2005: <a href="#f30">fig. 30</a>). Bony stays are absent    in the examined characids (state 0). Stays are longitudinal median bones situated    at the base of the procurrent rays. whose homology with the procurrent rays    is uncertain. Therefore, the presence or absence of stays is herein treated    as different from the following character.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>305. Anterior    ventral procurrent caudal-fin rays: (0) paired, only distally fused; (1) fused    in laminar medial bones.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Zanata &amp; Vari    (2005) mentioned that in the Characidae there are medial bones, similar to stays,    but much anteriorly situated. These procurrent rays are situated in parallel;    the posteriormost procurrent rays have separated lepidotrichia, which are progressively    fused in the anterior ones. In this condition the anterior ventral procurrent    rays are medial plates without remnants of separated lepidotrichia, articulated    or situated between haemal spines of two or more vertebrae anterior to the compound    centrum (state 1; <a href="#f49">Fig. 49</a>). These plates have a different    position than the caudal stays, which are longitudinal, perpendicular to the    procurrent rays. In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> and most representatives of the    outgroup, the lepidotrichia of the anterior ventral procurrent rays are not    fused to each other and do not reach the haemal spines (state 0).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Uroneurals:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>306. Uroneurals:    (0) absent or just one pair; (1) two pairs. (UJ54, BU70, LU108, MO89, ZV149,    LI50).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The uroneurals    are small paired bones aligned along the urostyle. Most examined taxa have only    one pair of uroneurals (state 0), whereas the presence of two pairs of uroneurals    (state 1; Weitzman, 1962: <a href="#f15">fig. 15</a>) was observed in several    mostly non-characid Characiformes. Among the examined species, the size of the    second pair of uroneurals is variable when present, and in some cases they are    much reduced. Nonetheless, all the species with a second pair of uroneurals    present, regardless it size, are coded as state 1. In the examined specimens    of <i>Acestrocephalus sardina</i>, <i>Bryconamericus exodon</i>, <i>Carlana    eigenmanni</i>, <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>, <i>Moenkhausia</i> cf. <i>intermedia</i>,    <i>M</i>. <i>sanctaefilomenae</i>, <i>Odontostoechus lethostigmus</i>, and <i>Roeboides    descalvadensis</i>, the second pair of uroneurals has a variable occurrence    and 
these species are coded as polymorphic for this character. The complete    lack of uroneurals was observed in <i>Characidium rachovii</i>, and this character    is coded as inapplicable for that species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Bony hooks</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Distribution:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>307. Bony hooks    on fin rays: (0) absent; (1) present in adult males. (CM35m, CM36m, VB58, SE91i,    LI60).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    bony hooks on the fin rays (usually on the anal and pelvic fins) is a secondary    sexual structure of males, that is broadly distributed in the Characidae and    also present in the Gasteropelecidae and Serrasalmidae (Malabarba &amp; Weitzman,    2003) (state 1; <a href="#f103">Figs. 103</a> and <a href="#f104">104</a>).    Malabarba &amp; Weitzman (2003) proposed the presence of bony hooks in adult    males as a synapomorphy of a clade including the Gasteropelecidae, Serrasalmidae,    and Characidae, excepting <i>Agoniates</i>, <i>Clupeacharax</i>, and <i>Engraulisoma</i>.    Most species examined for this paper have bony hooks; however, the absence of    bony hooks can not be assumed to be typical for a species based on the observation    of a limited number of specimens of such species. Rather it should be coded    only for species for which a good sample of individuals and/or undoubtedly adult    
males were examined. Serra (2003) coded <i>Salminus</i> as lacking bony hooks;    although in the examined material no hooks were observed for this genus, <i>S</i>.    <i>brasiliensis</i> is coded with the state 1 following Morais Filho &amp; Schubart    (1955). Weitzman &amp; Malabarba (2003) mentioned the presence of bony hooks    in <i>Microschemobrycon</i> Eigenmann citing B&ouml;hlke (1953a) and G&eacute;ry    (1973); however, G&eacute;ry (1973) explicitly mentioned the absence of hooks    in <i>M</i>. <i>casiquiare</i> and this character is coded as missing for this    species. Additionally to personal observations, the absence of bony hooks is    coded for <i>Rhoadsia altipinna</i> (Cardoso, 2002), <i>Nematobrycon palmeri</i>,    <i>Pseudochalceus kyburzi</i> (Bertaco, 2003), <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>,    <i>Hasemania nana</i> (Serra, 2003), <i>Paragoniates alburnus</i>, <i>Xenagoniates    bondi</i> (Quevedo, 2006) and their presence for <i>Creagrutus anary</i>, 
<i>C</i>.    cf. <i>taphorni</i>, <i>Piabina argentea</i> (Vari &amp; Harold, 2001), <i>Roeboides    microlepis</i> (Lucena, 2003), <i>Bryconexodon juruenae</i> (Lima, 2006), <i>Roeboides    descalvadensis</i> (Lucena, 2007), <i>Hemibrycon dariensis</i> and <i>H</i>.    <i>surinamensis</i> (Bertaco, 2008) following literature.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>308. Anal-fin    bony hooks in adult males of species bearing hooks on fins: (0) absent; (1)    present. (CM35m, CM36m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Bony hooks, when    present, are usually restricted to the anal and/or pelvic fins. A small group    of species has bony hooks also on the other fins and this variation is considered    below. Usually, there is an association between the presence of bony hooks in    the pelvic and anal fins but this correlation is not perfect, and their presence    in each of these fins is analyzed as separate characters. In most species whose    mature males bear bony hooks, they are present in the anal fin (state 1), whereas    in <i>Characidium borellii</i> and <i>Nantis indefessus</i>, among the examined    species, these bony hooks are absent (state 0). This character is coded as inapplicable    to species lacking bony hooks.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>309. Pelvic-fin    bony hooks in adult males of species bearing hooks on fins: (0) absent; (1)    present. (CM35m, CM36m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Pelvic-fin bony    hooks are present (state 1) in most species having secondary sexual bony hooks.    These hooks are absent, however, (state 0) in several species in which the anal-fin    hooks are present. The absence of pelvic-fin bony hooks is somewhat related    with the compressed body of some species, which is in turn usually associated    with a small size of the pelvic fin.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>310. Pectoral-fin    bony hooks in adult males of species bearing hooks on fins: (0) absent; (1)    present. (MA39m, MA41m, B&Uuml;138m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Bony hooks are    usually absent in the pectoral (state 0), dorsal, and caudal fins. As the presence    or absence of hooks on these fins is somewhat independent from each other, this    character and the following two are coded as separate. Among the species bearing    secondary sexual bony hooks, these structures are present in the pectoral fin    in some species (state 1). All the examined species having pectoral-fin bony    hooks have also hooks on the dorsal fin, excepting <i>Phenacogaster tegatus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>311. Dorsal-fin    bony hooks in adult males of species bearing hooks on fins: (0) absent; (1)    present. (MA39m, MA41m, VB37, B&Uuml;138m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    dorsal-fin bony hooks (state 1) is usually associated with the presence of hooks    on the pectoral fin, as herein observed. However, the presence of bony hooks    on the dorsal fin but their absence on the pectoral fin was herein observed    in <i>Bryconamericus thomasi</i> and <i>Hemigrammus erythrozonus</i>. This character    is coded as state 1 in <i>Nematocharax venustus</i> following Bertaco (2003).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>312. Caudal-fin    bony hooks in adult males of species bearing hooks on fins: (0) absent; (1)    present.(MA39m, MA41m, B&Uuml;138m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    caudal-fin bony hooks (state 1) is usually associated with the presence of these    structures on the pectoral and dorsal fins. However, several species with bony    hooks on those fins lack bony hooks on the caudal fin (state 0). The presence    of caudal-fin bony hooks but their absence on pectoral and dorsal fins was observed    herein only in <i>Acrobrycon tarijae</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>313. Bony hooks    on base of pelvic-fin rays of adult males: (0) absent, or in small number compared    to on segmented portion of rays; (1) as numerous as on segmented portion of    rays.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Pelvic-fin bony    hooks are usually more abundant on the branched region of the rays and are absent    or much less concentrated in the basal portions of the rays (state 0). In some    species the bony hooks are more densely concentrated along the basal portions    of the pelvic-fin rays (state 1). Intermediate conditions were observed in <i>Bryconamericus    alpha</i>, <i>Hemigrammus erythrozonus</i>, <i>Knodus breviceps</i>, <i>Oligosarcus</i>    cf. <i>jenynsii</i>, and <i>Prodontocharax melanotus</i>, which are coded as    polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>314. Bony hooks    on last pelvic-fin ray of adult males: (0) absent or reduced in number; (1)    as numerous as in other rays.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Bony hooks are    usually absent or much less concentrated in the last pelvic-fin ray than on    the remaining rays (state 0). In some species, bony hooks are also present and    relatively abundant on the last pelvic-fin ray (state 1; <a href="#f103">Fig.    103</a>). An intermediate situation was observed in <i>Odontostoechus lethostigmus</i>,    which is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>315. Bony hooks    on first pelvic-fin ray of adult males: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The unbranched    first pelvic-fin ray usually lacks bony hooks, even in species in which the    hooks are abundant on other rays (state 0). The first pelvic-fin ray in a few    species have, instead, relatively abundant bony hooks (state 1). This character    is variable in <i>Odontostoechus lethostigmus</i> which is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>316. Position    of anal-fin bony hooks of adult males: (0) paired and ordered laterally or posterolaterally;    (1) medially positioned and oriented posteriorly; (2) asymmetrically disposed    and irregularly arranged. (MA25m, B&Uuml;145).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The anal-fin bony    hooks are usually paired and oriented laterally or posterolaterally (state 0).    Malabarba (1998a) proposed the presence of medial, posteriorly-oriented bony    hooks, as a synapomorphy of a clade of the Cheirodontinae (state 1; Malabarba,    1998a: <a href="#f17">fig. 17</a>). The presence of irregularly arranged and    asymmetrically placed anal-fin bony hooks was proposed as a synapomorphy of    the Stethaprioninae of Reis (1989) (state 2; Reis, 1989: <a href="#f13">fig.    13</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Scales</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Morphology:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>317. Scales:    (0) cycloid; (1) ctenoid; (2) spinoid; (3) crenate. (EI10, LU119m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most characiforms    have cycloid scales, without projections on their posterior field (state 0;    <a href="#f111">Fig. 111</a>). Vari (1979) reported the presence of ctenii along    the posterior margin of the scales in the Distichodontidae and <i>Citharidium</i>    Boulenger, and Lucena (1993) in <i>Acestrocephalus sardina</i>, <i>Ctenobrycon    hauxwellianus</i> (Cope), <i>Cynopotamus kincaidi</i> (Schultz), and <i>Galeocharax    knerii</i> (Steindachner). Following the classification of Roberts (1993), the    scales of the Citharinidae and Distichodontidae are ctenoid (state 1), while    those of <i>Acestrocephalus</i>, <i>Cynopotamus</i> and <i>Galeocharax</i> are    spinoid (state 2; <a href="#f112">Fig. 112</a>). The scales of <i>Ctenobrycon</i>    (not analyzed here) and <i>Psellogrammus</i> are referred to as ctenoid in the    literature; Roberts (1993) did not find ctenii in <i>Ctenobrycon</i>, differing    with 
Lucena (1993), and did not examine specimens of <i>Psellogrammus</i>; thus,    the type of squamation of that genera remained undiscussed by Lucena. The scales    of the belly of <i>Psellogrammus kennedyi</i> have simple flattened serrations    restricted to the margin of the scales similar to that of crenate scales in    the classification of Roberts (1993) (state 3: <i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. Roberts,    1998: <a href="#f4">fig. 4G</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>318. Anterior    margin of scales: (0) uniformly curved or slightly undulated; (1) with conspicuous    undulations. (LU121m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The shape of the    anterior margin of the scales is variable among the examined species. In many    species this margin is almost straight, somewhat rounded, or slightly expanded    along its central portion (state 0; <a href="#f112">Fig. 112</a>). As the shape    of the anterior margin of the scales is variable even in different regions of    the same specimen, it is only considered here the case in which the undulations    are much evident and regularly present on scales of different regions of the    body (state 1; <a href="#f111">Fig. 111</a>). Eigenmann (1917) mentioned the    presence of crenate scales in <i>Entomolepis</i> (=<i>Bario</i>) <i>steindachneri</i>,    while G&eacute;ry (1977) indicated that the scales of <i>B</i>. <i>steindachneri</i>    become undulated when specimens reach 55 mm SL. In the specimen examined for    this paper (62 mm SL), the scales are only slightly undulated anteriorly; given    this 
variation during the growth of this species, <i>Bario steindachneri</i>    is coded as polymorphic for this character.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>319. <i>Circulii</i>    on posterior field of scales: (0) present; (1) absent. (BU80, LU118, ZV171m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The <i>circulii</i>    are concentric striae from the focus to the margins of the scales. In most characids    the <i>circulii</i> are absent on the posterior field of the scales (state 1;    <a href="#f111">Fig. 111</a>), whereas most species of the outgroup and some    characids have complete <i>circulii</i> reaching the posterior field of scales    (state 0). The root of this analysis is coded as polymorphic because the <i>circulii</i>    are absent in <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> but are present in other members of the    Cypriniformes (Pflieger, 1997).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>320. <i>Radii</i>    on scales: (0) absent or reduced in number; (1) present and numerous on most    scales.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The <i>radii</i>    are radially disposed grooves on the surface of scales extending from the focus    to the margins. In most species the <i>radii</i> are uniformly present in all    regions of the body, at least in the posterior field of scales (state 1; <a href="#f113">Fig.    113</a>). In some species such <i>radii</i> are either absent, much reduced    in number, or variably present in different regions of body (state 0; <a href="#f111">Fig.    111</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>321. <i>Radii</i>    oriented towards anterior field of scales: (0) present; (1) only as longitudinal    groove without defined margins; (2) absent. (ZV172m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the <i>radii</i> are only present on the posterior field of the scales    (state 2), and do not converge towards the focus of the scales. Uj (1990) illustrated    scales with <i>radii</i> oriented anteriorly (state 0) in some members of the    Alestidae, Anostomidae, Ctenoluciidae, Erythrinidae, Hepsetidae, and Parodontidae.    Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) mentioned that in most alestids, along with the genera    <i>Hepsetus</i>, <i>Hoplias</i>, and <i>Triportheus</i>, the <i>radii</i> are    oriented from the focus in all directions, even to the anterior field. A much    wider anteriorly-oriented groove without defined margins, (state 1, <a href="#f113">Fig.    113</a>) was observed in <i>Bario steindachneri</i> and <i>Moenkhausia sanctaefilomenae</i>.    This character is coded as inapplicable for species in which the <i>radii</i>    are absent.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>322. <i>Radii</i>    of scales: (0) not converging at focus; (1) converging at focus.</b></font></p>
