<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Although the <i>radii</i>    are oriented towards the focus, in most species they do not converge centrally,    being independent each other (state 0). In some species the <i>radii</i> are    in contact at the focus of the scales (state 1; <a href="#f113">Fig. 113</a>).    In <i>Astyanax</i> cf. <i>abramis</i>, <i>A</i>. <i>asuncionensis</i>, and <i>A</i>.    cf. <i>asuncionensis</i>, this character is variable in different regions of    the body of the same specimen, and this character is coded as polymorphic. This    character is coded as inapplicable for species in which the <i>radii</i> are    absent or reduced in number.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>323. Semicircular    grooves on posterior field of scales: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">As mentioned above,    the posterior field of the scales usually has <i>radii</i> and/or <i>circulii</i>    (state 0). Uj (1990) illustrated a few grooves similar to <i>radii</i> but semicircular    in shape, situated on the posterior field on the scales of <i>Stethaprion erythrops</i>    Cope (state 1). The presence of these grooves was corroborated in this paper.    Although this character is autapomorphic for <i>S</i>. <i>erythrops</i> in this    analysis, this character is included as potentially informative in the future.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Scale distribution:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>324. Scales    covering supraoccipital spine: (0) absent; (1) present and completely covering    supraoccipital spine. (VA74, BU18, LU24, ZV168, LI61m, PZ102).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the dorsal scales extend anteriorly to the posterior margin of the parietals    and supraoccipital but do not cover the supraoccipital spine, which projects    posteriorly between rows of scales (state 0). Vari (1995) mentioned that the    anteriormost dorsal scales extend anteriorly dorsal to the supraoccipital spine    and cover it completely from dorsal view (state 1) in the Ctenoluciidae, Erythrinidae,    Hepsetidae, and Lebiasinidae; this state was considered by him as a synapomorphy    for a clade composed of these four families. Vari (1995) mentioned a similar    coverage of the supraoccipital spine in the Alestidae and Parodontidae, although    he considered these cases as not comparable given the lack of a supraoccipital    crest in the latter two families. This character is considered inapplicable    to species lacking median predorsal scales.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>325. Median    predorsal scales: (0) covering entire predorsal region; (1) leaving naked area    anterior to dorsal fin.(EI7, AM13, BE92).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The region between    the posterior tip of the supraoccipital spine and the origin of the dorsal-fin    origin is typically covered by scales (state 0) in most examined species. The    absence of scales in the predorsal area (state 1) constitutes one of the "generic    character" of Eigenmann (1917), and was used by that author to diagnose <i>Gymnocorymbus</i>    Eigenmann. The absence of predorsal scales was also mentioned by Machado-Allison    (1983) as a synapomorphy of the Serrasalminae (=Serrasalmidae). This author    proposed a correlation between the absence of predorsal scales and the great    development of the supraoccipital spine. The examined specimens of <i>Gymnocharacinus    bergii</i> lack scales. Miquelarena &amp; Ar&aacute;mburu (1983) described the    squamation of this species, indicating that the scales are progressively reabsorbed    in specimens of 42 mm SL or greater. According to those authors, the 
squamation    is regular in smaller specimens, except along the middorsal line and the end    of the caudal peduncle. <i>Gymnocharacinus bergii</i> is, thus, coded as state    1 following the literature.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>326. Ventral    serrae: (0) absent; (1) present. (AM1).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    modified and aligned scales forming a ventral serrae (state 1) is diagnostic    for the Serrasalminae (=Serrasalmidae) (Machado-Allison, 1983). These serrae    are absent (state 0) in all remaining species in the Characiformes.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>327. Scales    covering anal-fin base: (0) one or two rows of scales covering anal-fin base;    (1) several rows covering basal third of anal fin. (EI11, SE93m, BE93m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have one or two rows of scales partially covering the anal-fin base (state 0).    In some species there are, instead, several rows of smaller scales covering    more than one-third the length of the anal-fin rays (state 1). This character    is coded as polymorphic for <i>Poptella paraguayensis</i> which has an intermediate    state.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>328. Scales    covering caudal-fin lobes: (0) covering only their base; (1) covering one-third    of their length. (EI1, CM34, SE89m, BE94).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The scales in most    characids reach only the caudal-fin base (state 0), with the presence of scales    over the caudal-fin lobes (state 1) used as a "generic character" by Eigenmann    (1917). This character state is still used to diagnose several highly diverse    genera in the Characidae. Cases in which the scales cover the medial caudal-fin    rays, but not the lobes, as in the Serrasalmidae, <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i>,    and <i>Roeboides descalvadensis</i>, are coded as state 0. <i>Microschemobrycon    casiquiare</i> is coded as polymorphic given the observations of G&eacute;ry    (1977) about the intraspecific variability of this character. In the examined    specimens of <i>Bryconamericus alpha</i> the scales cover part of the ventral    caudal-fin lobe, but the dorsal lobe is completely naked. This character is    coded as polymorphic for this species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Muscles and    ligaments</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Cranial musculature:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>329. Ventral    division of tendon from <i>adductor mandibulae</i> inserted on dentary: (0)    absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The A2 and A3 sections    of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> form a strong tendon whose anterior region    is usually divided in two smaller portions, one attached to the coronomeckelian    bone and the second to the medial surface of the dentary just ventral to the    Meckelian cartilage (state 1; <a href="#f114">Fig. 114</a>). The ventral division    of this tendon varies in degree of development and attachment site, which is    considered below. In some species, such a division is completely absent, and    the tendon from the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> attaches only in the coronomeckelian    bone (state 0). This condition was observed in <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> and    some representatives of the outgroup.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>330. Longitudinal    position of insertion of <i>adductor mandibulae</i> tendon on dentary: (0) on    vertical through posterior half of Meckelian cartilage; (1) on vertical through    middle or anterior half of Meckelian cartilage. (ZV92m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The tendon from    the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> usually attaches on the dentary on a vertical    through some point of the posterior half of the Meckelian cartilage (state 0).    In some species this tendon is comparatively stronger and inserts more anteriorly    on the dentary (state 1). This anterior displacement of the attachment site    is usually correlated with a shortening of the lower jaw, however this correlation    is not perfect and these features have certain independence from each other.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>331. Insertion    of <i>adductor mandibulae</i> tendon on dentary: (0) ventral to Meckelian cartilage;    (1) anterior to Meckelian cartilage; (2) on a medial process of the dentary.    (ZV92m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the ventral division of the tendon from the <i>adductor mandibulae</i>    inserts ventral to the Meckelian cartilage (state 0). In some species the insertion    of this tendon is anteriorly displaced to the posterior wall of the dentary    fossa for the replacement teeth (state 1; <a href="#f114">Fig. 114</a>); this    state was described by Zanata &amp; Vari (2005) as synapomorphic for a clade    including <i>Alestes</i>, <i>Brycinus</i>, and <i>Bryconaethiops</i>. The ventral    division of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> tendon in the Iguanodectinae is attached    to an ascendant lobe of the inner surface of the dentary, immediately medial    to Meckelian cartilage (Moreira, 2002) (state 2; <a href="#f62">Fig. 62</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>332. Posterior    attachment of A1 section of <i>adductor mandibulae</i>: (0) principally to vertical    arm of preopercle; (1) restricted or almost restricted to horizontal arm of    preopercle. (UJ65, LU111).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The A1 section    is the most lateral division of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> muscle. The posterior    portion of this section broadly attaches to the horizontal and vertical arms    of the preopercle (state 0). In several characids this section is relatively    reduced and inserted almost exclusively on the horizontal arm of the preopercle    (state 1; <a href="#f115">Fig. 115</a>). Lucena (1993) coded <i>Acestrorhynchus    pantaneiro</i> as state 0, while the state 1 was observed in the specimens herein    examined, and this species is coded as polymorphic considering possible intraspecific    variability. The root of this analysis is also coded as polymorphic due to variations    in the attachment area within the Cypriniformes (Howes, 1978).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>333. Attachment    of medial tendon of A1 section of <i>adductor mandibulae</i>: (0) on quadrate    near its articulation with preopercle; (1) on preopercle posterior to quadrate.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The ventral portion    of the A1 section of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> broadly attaches to the    horizontal arm of the preopercle and the quadrate, with its dorsal surface bordered    by the A2 section, which is situated more medially. The medial margin of the    A1 section is limited dorsally by an oblique tendon which attaches anteriorly    to other tendons from the A2 and A3 sections to form the large tendon described    in the characters 329 to 331. This tendon usually inserts on the dorsal margin    of the quadrate, near the articulation between that bone and the preopercle    (state 0; <a href="#f75">Figs. 75</a> and <a href="#f77">77</a>). In some species    this tendon, instead, attaches more posteriorly and dorsally on the preopercle    posterior to the margin of the quadrate (state 1; <a href="#f74">Fig. 74</a>).    In several species the tendon in question could not be observed, and although    apparently 
absent, this issue needs confirmation.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>334. Anterior    insertion of A1 section of <i>adductor mandibulae</i>: (0) on maxilla; (1) on    coronoid process of dentary.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The A1 section    of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> attaches anteriorly to the maxilla (state    0) in the Cypriniformes and Citharinoidei (Howes, 1978; Vari, 1979). This condition    was observed in <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> and <i>Distichodus maculatus</i>. In    the remaining species this section rather attaches to the variably developed    coronoid process of the lower jaw (state 1).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>335. Contact    between dorsal margin of <i>adductor mandibulae</i> and ventral margin of <i>dilator    operculi</i>: (0) absent; (1) present. (LU113m, LU115m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The dorsal margin    of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> is posterodorsally oblique and attaches to    the dorsal region of the preopercle, while the <i>dilator operculi</i> is posteroventrally    oriented from the neurocranium to the preopercle. In most species there is a    triangular gap between these muscles immediately posterior to the orbit making    the <i>levator arcus palatini</i>, which is medial to both muscles, visible    from a lateral view. The ventral margin of the <i>dilator operculi</i> usually    overlaps part of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> dorsal margin reducing the laterally    visible portion of the <i>levator arcus palatini</i> and covering the insertion    of this muscle on the preopercle (state 1; <a href="#f115">Fig. 115</a>). In    some species, instead, the <i>dilator operculi</i>, does not cover the <i>adductor    mandibulae</i> and the <i>levator arcus palatini</i> is visible to its 
insertion    in the preopercle (state 0; <a href="#f116">Fig. 116</a>). Lucena (1993) considered    both the presence and degree of overlap of the <i>dilator operculi</i> over    the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> as two separate characters. The degree of overlap    of these muscles is apparently related to the degree of development of the musculature    of jaws and its condition varies within some apparently monophyletic groups.    In <i>Aphyocharax dentatus</i>, for example, these muscles broadly overlap,    while in <i>A</i>. <i>anisitsi</i>, with a much weaker jaw musculature, they    only slightly overlap. Thus, it is preferable herein to consider only the presence    or absence of overlapping between the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> and the <i>dilator    operculi</i>. Intraspecific variability in those features was observed in <i>Aphyocharacidium    bolivianum</i>, <i>Axelrodia lindeae</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon luetkenii</i>, <i>Lonchogenys    ilisha</i>, and <i>Piabina argentea</i> 
which are coded as polymorphic for this    character.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>336. Anterior    extension of <i>adductor arcus palatini</i>: (0) covering most of dorsal surface    of mesopterygoid; (1) covering only half of dorsal surface of mesopterygoid.    (LU114).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The <i>adductor    arcus palatini</i> inserts anteriorly on the dorsal surface of the mesopterygoid.    In most examined species, this muscle thinly covers only the posterior half    of the mesopterygoid (state 1; <a href="#f117">Fig. 117</a>). In some species    both of the ingroup and the outgroup the <i>adductor arcus palatini</i> covers    most of the dorsal surface of the mesopterygoid (state 0; <a href="#f118">Fig.    118</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>337. Posterior    region of <i>levator arcus palatini</i>: (0) limited laterally by <i>adductor    mandibulae</i> and medially by <i>adductor arcus palatini</i>; (1) limited lateral    and medially by A2 and A3 sections of <i>adductor mandibulae</i>. (LU110m, LU112m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the posterior portion of the <i>levator arcus palatini</i> is situated    between the medial margin of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> and the lateral    surface of the <i>adductor arcus palatini</i> (state 0). In some species the    A3 section of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> (the most medial section) is instead    conspicuously developed, and its dorsal margin extends between the <i>levator    arcus palatini</i> and the <i>adductor palatini.</i> In these cases the <i>levator    arcus palatini</i> is thus bordered medially and laterally by different sections    of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> (A2 and A3 sections) (state 1). Lucena (1993)    treated the development of the A3 section of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i>    and the relative position of the <i>levator operculi</i> as different characters.    Both characters are herein combined as one because it was impossible to estimate    the 
development of the A3 section independent of its relationship with the <i>levator    arcus palatini</i> and the <i>adductor arcus palatini</i> muscles. A different    situation was observed in <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> in which the A3 section of    the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> is relatively more developed, although its dorsal    margin is bordered laterally by fibers of the <i>adductor arcus palatini</i>;    thus, the ventral margin of the <i>levator operculi</i> is margined laterally    by both the <i>adductor arcus palatini</i> and the <i>adductor mandibulae</i>.    The root of this analysis is thus coded as polymorphic for this character. Only    a small portion of the <i>levator arcus palatini</i> is bordered medially by    the A3 section of the <i>adductor mandibulae</i> in <i>Aphyocharax dentatus</i>.    This is considered an intermediate condition and this species is coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>338. Origin    of <i>dilator operculi</i>: (0) anterior to vertical through posterior margin    of eye; (1) completely posterior to vertical through posterior margin of eye.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the <i>dilator operculi</i> inserts anteriorly in a fossa formed by    the frontal and the sphenotic or on the ventral surface of the frontal. In both    conditions it inserts just dorsal to the posterodorsal margin of the orbit (state    0). In <i>Characidium</i> spp., among the examined species, the anterior border    of the <i>dilator operculi</i> is displaced to a point posterior to the vertical    through the posterior margin of the orbit (state 1). In the Erythrinidae and    plesiomorphically in the Lebiasinidae, the <i>dilator operculi</i> extends anteriorly    through the sphenotic to the orbit (Vari, 1995). This condition is different    to the states herein defined, and this character is coded as inapplicable to    <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i> and <i>Pyrrhulina australis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Postcranium:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>339. Pseudotympanum    limited by first pleural rib, <i>lateralis superficialis</i>, second pleural    rib, <i>obliquus inferioris</i> and <i>obliquus superioris</i>: (0) absent;    (1) present. (AM26m, MA1, ZV199m, B&Uuml;163m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species the musculature laterally covering the gas bladder is present, or if    slightly reduced does not form a gap between the muscle layers (state 0). According    to the phylogenetic hypothesis of Malabarba (1998a), the presence of a pseudotympanum    limited anteriorly by the first rib, dorsally by the <i>lateralis superficialis</i>,    posteriorly by the second rib, and ventrally by the <i>obliquus inferioris</i>    and <i>obliquus superioris</i> (state 1; Malabarba, 1998a: <a href="#f3">fig.    3</a>), constitutes a synapomorphy of the Cheirodontinae. This author mentioned    that other characids have reductions in the musculature lateral to the anterior    chamber of the gas bladder, but that the homology of such reductions with the    pseudotympanum is doubtful. Malabarba (1998a) described different types of pseudotympani    in <i>Microschemobrycon</i> sp., <i>Rhoadsia altipinna</i>, and 
<i>Tetragonopterus    chalceus</i> Spix &amp; Agassiz. This author mentioned the presence of a pseudotympanum    similar to that of the Cheirodontinae also in <i>Aphyocharacidium</i> G&eacute;ry,    <i>Charax</i>, <i>Leptagoniates</i> Boulenger, <i>Phenacogaster</i>, <i>Roeboides</i>,    and variably within the rosy tetra clade of Weitzman &amp; Palmer (1997). Different    types of such openings were herein observed in <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i>,    <i>Hyphessobrycon elachys</i>, <i>Metynnis maculatus</i>, <i>Paracheirodon axelrodi</i>,    <i>Psellogrammus kennedyi</i>, and <i>Rhoadsia altipinna</i>. This character    is coded as inapplicable to these species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>340. Insertion    of pterotic aponeurosis: (0) on pterotic spine or lateral surface of horizontal    semicircular canal; (1) on a lobe situated dorsal to horizontal semicircular    canal; (2) on pterotic or sphenotic, distinctly dorsal to horizontal semicircular    canal</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most Characiformes    the pterotic aponeurosis (<i>sensu</i> Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1983), which attaches    part of the epaxial musculature to the cranium, inserts on the pterotic spine    or onto the lateral margin of the pterotic tube of the semicircular canal (state    0; Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1983: <a href="#f9">figs. 9-11</a>). In a small group    of species this aponeurosis inserts immediately dorsal to the pterotic tube    for the horizontal semicircular canal, on an ascending lobe situated in the    angle formed by this canal and the pterotic laterosensory canal (state 1; Weitzman    &amp; Fink, 1983: <a href="#f12">figs. 12</a> and <a href="#f14">14</a>). As    described by Weitzman &amp; Fink (1983) for <i>Paracheirodon</i>, in some species    the aponeurosis attaches to the pterotic or sphenotic approximately at the middle    of the depth of the posttemporal fossa (state 2; Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1983:    <a 
href="#f6">figs. 6-8</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Coloration and    miscellaneous characters</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Coloration:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>341. Humeral    spot: (0) absent or vertically-elongate; (1) horizontally-ovate. (VH53m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most species    the humeral spot is vertically elongate, with diffuse margins (state 0). Malabarba    (1998a) proposed the total absence of a humeral spot as a synapomorphy of the    Cheirodontinae; however, this state is not analyzed herein given that in some    species the spot is extremely reduced, making the discrimination of that condition    from the absence of spot difficult. Instead, in a group of species the humeral    spot is ovate and horizontally elongated, with definite margins and surrounded    anteriorly and posteriorly by somewhat clearer areas (state 1). The humeral    spot of <i>Astyanax correntinus</i> is ovate, but much reduced in size and without    definite margins, and this character is coded as polymorphic for the species.    In <i>Hemigrammus ulreyi</i> (Boulenger) the humeral spot is extended posteriorly    by a narrow lateral band. Since this condition differs from both states, this    
character is coded as inapplicable for this species.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>342. Second    humeral spot: (0) absent or diffuse; (1) present as a conspicuous vertical bar.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most examined species    have a variably developed anterior humeral spot and, occasionally, a very faint    second one (state 0). In a small group of species both humeral spots are distinctly    conspicuous vertical bars (state 1). This character is coded as polymorphic    for <i>Poptella paraguayensis</i>, in which a second humeral spot is present    but it is slightly more diffuse than the anterior bar.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>343. Dark conspicuous    spot on dorsal fin: (0) absent; (1) present. (MA65m, MA66m, MA67m, BE100, B&Uuml;159).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most species    the dorsal fin is hyaline or have some yellowish to reddish coloration, lacking    a distinct dark spot (state 0). G&eacute;ry (1977) listed a group of <i>Hyphessobrycon</i>    species &#91;his <i>H</i>. <i>callistus</i> (Boulenger) group&#93; as having    a conspicuous dark spot in the dorsal fin (state 1); this group includes <i>H</i>.    <i>callistus</i> (=<i>H</i>. <i>eques</i>) and <i>H</i>. <i>pulchripinnis</i>,    among the species analyzed here. The constitution of this group of species is    rather similar to that of the rosy tetra clade of Weitzman &amp; Palmer (1997),    which additionally includes <i>H</i>. <i>socolofi</i> and <i>H</i>. <i>compressus</i>,    the type species of <i>Hyphessobrycon</i>, and probably also <i>Hemigrammus    unilineatus</i>, the type species of <i>Hemigrammus</i> (Meek). This character    is coded as polymorphic in <i>Hemigrammus ulreyi</i> in which this spot is 
usually    present but fainter.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>344. Horizontal    line of chromatophores just dorsal to anal-fin base: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most species    the region just dorsal to the anal-fin base has a rather uniform coloration    (state 0). In a small group of species there is instead a well defined longitudinal    line of chromatophores just dorsal to the anal-fin base (state 1). A similar    line of chromatophores was mentioned by Malabarba (1998b) for <i>Lignobrycon    myersi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>345. Color of    caudal-fin lobes: (0) symmetrically hyaline, yellowish, reddish, or violaceous;    (1) ventral lobe orange or reddish and dorsal lobe hyaline; (2) ventral lobe    dark brown or black and dorsal lobe hyaline; (3) both lobes dark brown or black.    (BE103m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most examined    species both lobes of the caudal fin have a similar coloration, being hyaline,    yellowish, reddish, or violaceous (state 0). These colorations are usually variable    intraspecifically, and are treated herein as the same state, although some discrimination    between these situations could be done as a result of the study of specific    clades. In most species of <i>Aphyocharax</i> the ventral lobe is orange to    intense red and the dorsal lobe is hyaline (state 1). In <i>Thayeria</i> Eigenmann    and <i>Hemiodus</i>, among the examined taxa, the ventral lobe is black and    the dorsal lobe hyaline (state 2), whereas in a small group of species both    lobes are black, usually with white tips (state 3).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>346. Diffuse    spots on flanks: (0) absent; (1) present, especially in young specimens.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most characiforms    have a rather uniform coloration except for the variable presence of humeral    and peduncular spots and a lateral band (state 0). Usually the coloration of    young specimens is similar to that of the mature adults. Machado-Allison (1983)    proposed as a synapomorphy of the Serrasalminae (=Serrasalmidae) the presence    of rounded blotches or diffuse spots on flanks (state 1). These blotches gradually    disappear during the growth.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>347. Little    spot on each scale of flanks: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most species    the distribution of melanophores is somewhat related with the size and distribution    of the scales, being usually more concentrated along their margins and producing    various reticulated patterns (state 0). Some species of <i>Astyanax</i> have    highly concentrated chromatophores on the medial or distal surface of each scale,    especially on those of the dorsolateral surface of the body, thereby producing    a dotted appearance (state 1). This state was described and used in systematic    studies by Eigenmann (1917), and subsequently used in the literature by several    authors (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. Ringuelet <i>et al</i>., 1967; G&eacute;ry, 1977)    for the discrimination of a group of species including <i>A</i>. <i>abramis</i>    and <i>A</i>. <i>asuncionensis</i> among those herein analyzed.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>348. Dark spot    covering entire depth of caudal peduncle: (0) absent; (1) present. (BE102m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Many species have    a more or less developed lateral band which is usually continuous with a spot    on the caudal peduncle and extends to middle caudal-fin rays (state 0). A dorsally    expanded dark caudal-peduncle spot (state 1) is present in <i>Moenkhausia sanctaefilomenae</i>    among the examined species and, according to Benine (2004), in <i>Bario steindachneri</i>,    <i>Moenkhausia cotinho</i> Eigenmann, <i>M</i>. <i>oligolepis</i> (G&uuml;nther),    and <i>M</i>. <i>pyrophthalma</i> Costa. This spot is barely visible in the    examined specimens of <i>B</i>. <i>steindachneri</i>, and this species is coded    as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Miscellaneous:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>349. Ventral    union of gill membranes: (0) joined anteriorly, but not covering the isthmus;    (1) joined along length of isthmus but not attached to isthmus; (2) joined to    each other and with isthmus. (MO91m).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The gill membranes,    in most examined species, converge just anterior to the urohyal, leaving the    entire isthmus visible from a ventral view (state 0). In some species the gill    membranes are joined at the posterior end of the isthmus which is consequently    covered ventrally by the membranes (state 1). In both cases, the gill membranes    are free from the isthmus. In <i>Puntius tetrazona</i> and the Anostomoidea    the gill membranes are instead joined each other, and are firmly attached to    the isthmus (state 2).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>350. Sclerotic    bones: (0) single anteroventrally open bone; (1) two bones separated by cartilages.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The sclerotic bones    are developed from a complete cartilaginous ring bordering the eye. In the condition    typical for the Teleostei this cartilage forms two independent ossifications    along the anterior and posterior margins of the eye that are separated by the    remnants of the original cartilaginous ring (state 1; <a href="#f119">Fig. 119</a>)    (Franz-Odendaal &amp; Hall, 2006). This condition was observed in most outgroup    species and some members of the Characidae. In other characids these sclerotic    bones apparently are fused dorsally, and only the anteroventral margin of the    eye is limited by cartilage (state 0; <a href="#f120">Fig. 120</a>). In <i>Coptobrycon    bilineatus</i> there is a single bone completely encircling the eye, even anteroventrally.    Given that this is considered to be an extreme case of ossification of the original    cartilaginous ring, this species is coded with the state 0. 
The conservativeness    or lack thereof of this character during the growth was not studied in detail,    and this coding should be evaluated by more focused future studies. This character    is variable among the examined specimens of <i>Astyanax troya</i>, <i>Bryconamericus    thomasi</i>, <i>Gymnocorymbus ternetzi</i>, <i>Nantis indefessus</i>, <i>Odontostilbe    paraguayensis</i>, and <i>Serrapinnus calliurus</i>, which are coded as polymorphic.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>351. Nostrils:    (0) rounded and divided only by skin fold; (1) nostrils distinctly separate.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In most characiforms    the nostrils of each side of the snout are close each other, being only separated    by a fold skin (state 0; <a href="#f121">Fig. 121</a>). In <i>Coptobrycon bilineatus</i>    and <i>Grundulus cochae</i>, among the ingroup species, there are instead two    widely separated nostrils on each side of the snout (state 1; <a href="#f122">Fig.    122</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>352. Gill-derived    gland on males: (0) absent; (1) present.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Bushmann <i>et    al</i>. (2002) described a gland formed by the anteriormost gill filaments (state    1) in adult males of some species of their Glandulocaudinae (Stevardiinae, in    part). This gland was subsequently observed in <i>Aphyocharacidium bolivianum</i>,    <i>Aphyocharax anisitsi</i>, <i>Hemibrycon</i> sp., <i>Phenacogaster franciscoensis</i>    Eigenmann, and the Cheirodontinae (B&uuml;hrnheim, 2006). As this gland is present    only in males and is not easily visible in some species, the coding of this    character is mostly based on literature. Personal observations of alcohol specimens    were used only to code species in which this gland is undoubtedly present or    absent in adult males. Although no seasonal variation in presence or absence    of this gland was reported in the literature, this issue should be further evaluated.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>353. Glandular    tissue of granular appearance on caudal fin of mature males: (0) absent; (1)    present (MW2).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">According to Menezes    &amp; Weitzman (2009), the presence of glandular tissue in the caudal organ    (state 1; <i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. Menezes &amp; Weitzman, 2009: <a href="#f5">fig.    5</a>) is unique to their Glandulocaudinae and Stevardiinae. They coded all    remaining members of their clade A (=Stevardiinae, as treated here) as lacking    the glandular tissue herein considered (state 0) even if they lack a caudal    organ as such. The used definition of states is the same to that by Menezes    &amp; Weitzman (2009). A tissue similar to that described by Menezes &amp; Weitzman    (2009) was found in males of <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>; although the glandular    nature of this tissue was not confirmed, this species is also coded as state    1, pending further confirmation. This character is only coded in the species    in which the presence of this glandular tissue was mentioned by Menezes &amp;    Weitzman (2009) or 
its presence or absence was observed in adult males. The    remaining species are coded with missing entries. This character was not analyzed    by Mirande (2009).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>354. Hypertrophied    ventral caudal-peduncle squamation: (0) absent; (1) present. (MW6)</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    a glandular fold on the ventral lobe of the caudal fin (state 1; Weitzman &amp;    Menezes, 1998: <a href="#f10">figs. 10-16</a>) was considered as diagnostic    for the Glandulocaudinae (G&eacute;ry, 1977; Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1985; Weitzman    &amp; Menezes, 1998). The monophyly of this subfamily was later questioned and    the Stevardiinae was proposed to include most species of the former glandulocaudins    (Weitzman <i>et al</i>., 2005). Weitzman &amp; Menezes (2009) analyzed the glandular    fold in two different characters, considering the origin of the scales involved    in such fold. They considered the hypertrophy of the scales of the dorsal lobe    of the caudal fin and that of the ventral lobe as different characters and proposed    the first character to be diagnostic of their Glandulocaudinae and the second    character to be synapomorphic for their Stevardiinae. The presence (state 1;    
<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. Weitzman &amp; Menezes, 1998: <a href="#f14">fig. 14</a>)    or absence of hypertrophy of scales of the caudal-fin ventral lobe is herein    coded. This character was not included as such by Mirande (2009), who instead    coded the presence or absence of a caudal fold of scales, without considering    if the scales forming this fold were from the dorsal or ventral caudal-fin lobe.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>355. Caudal    gland cells consisting of modified mucous cells: (0) absent; (1) present. (MW5).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    caudal gland cells formed by modified mucous cells (state 1) was proposed by    Menezes &amp; Weitzman (2009) as a synapomorphy of their Stevardiinae. No histological    examination were made for this paper and the coding of this character is exclusively    based on Menezes &amp; Weitzman (2009). The presence or absence (state 0) of    modified mucous cells was coded only at generic or suprageneric levels by Menezes    &amp; Weitzman (2009) and their presence or absence should be corroborated in    each species. This character was not included by Mirande (2009).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>356. Adipose    fin: (0) present; (1) absent. (EI15, VA81, MA12, VB39, SE90m, QU41).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    an adipose fin (state 0) was considered as a plesiomorphy of the Ostariophysi    (Fink &amp; Fink, 1981) that was independently lost in the Gonorynchiformes,    Cypriniformes, and Gymnotiformes. However, according to the phylogenetic hypothesis    of Fink &amp; Fink (1981), the correct optimization of this character is ambiguous,    and their interpretation of character-state evolution is equally parsimonious    to the absence of the adipose fin in the ancestor of the Ostariophysi and its    acquisition in the common ancestor of the Characiformes, Gymnotiformes, and    Siluriformes. This character, thus, is coded as polymorphic to the root of this    analysis. In most members of the Characiformes the adipose fin is present, while    it is absent (state 1) in the Erythrinidae, Lebiasinidae, and some characids.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>357. Papillae    on tongue: (0) not aligned; (1) forming longitudinal rows anteriorly.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The epithelial    papillae situated in the dorsal surface of the primary tongue are irregularly    arranged in most examined species (state 0; <a href="#f123">Fig. 123</a>). In    some species these papillae are instead aligned, forming four to six conspicuous    longitudinal rows on the anterior region of dorsal surface of the primary tongue    (state 1; <a href="#f124">Fig. 124</a>).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>358. Insemination:    (0) absent; (1) present. (MA70, WM2, B&Uuml;168, QU92, MW1).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Although a detailed    study of the reproductive biology of the species included in this analysis is    beyond the scope of this paper, the available data about insemination is herein    analyzed in a familial phylogenetic context. Although the list of characid inseminating    species is surely far from complete, the published list of species in which    insemination is known to be absent is even more incomplete. Thus, this and the    following character, which is also related with reproductive biology, have a    relatively high proportion of missing entries. Most characids have external    fertilization (state 0), while the presence of insemination (state 1) was reported    for several genera of the Cheirodontinae and Stevardiinae and the genus <i>Hollandichthys</i>    (Bertaco, 2003; Burns <i>et al</i>., 1995, 1997, 1998; Burns &amp; Weitzman,    2005; Castro <i>et al</i>., 2003; Menezes <i>et al</i>., 2003; Weitzman et 
al.,    2005). This character is coded exclusively from literature.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>359. Type of    spermatozoa: (0) aquasperm; (1) introsperm. (MA71, WM47m, B&Uuml;169, QU91).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The spermatozoa    in externally fertilizing species are usually of the aquasperm type, with a    rounded nucleus (state 0), while in the inseminating species they are usually    of the introsperm type, with an elongated nucleus (state 1) (Burns &amp; Weitzman,    2005). Although there is a correlation between the presence of insemination    and introsperms, there are exceptions to such relationships (Burns &amp; Weitzman,    2005). This character was coded only from literature, and many species are coded    as missing entries.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>360. Sperm storage    area on testes: (0) absent or small; (1) present, as broad as spermatogenic    area. (QU93).</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The presence of    a developed aspermatogenic region in the testicle, which serves as storage area    (state 1) was proposed by Weitzman &amp; Menezes (1998) as a synapomorphy of    their Glandulocaudinae. A similar storage area was observed by Bertaco (2003)    in the species of <i>Hollandichthys</i>. This storage area is absent or extremely    reduced in most of the Characidae (state 0). This character was coded exclusively    from literature.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>361. Number    of 2n chromosomes: (0) 36 to 40; (1) 46 or more.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>362. Number    of 2n chromosomes: (0) 48 or less; (1) 50 or more.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>363. Number    of 2n chromosomes: (0) 50 or less; (1) 52 or more.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>364. Number    of 2n chromosomes: (0) 52 or less; (1) 54 or more</b>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>365. Number    of 2n chromosomes: (0) 56 or less; (1) 58 or more.</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Although several    species analyzed herein have published information as to their chromosome number,    this information was not previously included in phylogenetic analyses. The root    of this analysis is coded as polymorphic for the characters 363, 364, and 365    because the number of chromosomes in the Cypriniformes usually ranges between    48 and 52. This character was coded from the literature (Arefjev, 1990a, b;    Artoni &amp; Bertollo, 2002; Bellafronte <i>et al</i>., 2005; Bertollo <i>et    al</i>., 1986; Carvalho <i>et al</i>., 2002; Centofante <i>et al</i>., 2003;    Cestari &amp; Galetti, 1992; Falc&atilde;o &amp; Bertollo, 1985; Foresti <i>et    al</i>., 1989; Galetti Jr. <i>et al</i>., 1981; ; Hinegardner &amp; Rosen, 1972    ; Kirby <i>et al</i>., 1977; Paintner-Marques <i>et al</i>., 2002; Pauls &amp;    Bertollo, 1984; Portela <i>et al</i>., 1988; Porto <i>et al</i>., 1992; Silva    &amp; Maistro, 
2006). Different numbers of chromosomes were reported for several    species, which might indicate identification problems. These usually occurs    in non-systematic papers; thus, several species are coded as polymorphic denoting    some uncertainty as to identifications rather than polymorphisms <i>per se</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Phylogenetic    Results</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The final hypothesis    is the strict consensus between the most parsimonious trees obtained in a range    of K-values under implied weighting (Goloboff, 1993). Details about the analysis    itself, including the criteria by which this final hypothesis was constructed    were already published (Mirande, 2009). The final hypothesis is presented in    the <a href="/img/revistas/ni/v8n3/html/01f125a129.htm">Figs. 125-129</a>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Diagnosis of    the obtained clades</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The common synapomorphies    of the individual trees are listed for each node of the final hypothesis. Those    synapomorphic changes that are present only in some of the original trees are    listed under "some trees". The node numbers correspond to those obtained from    the TNT software and presented in the <a href="/img/revistas/ni/v8n3/html/01f125a129.htm">Figs.    125-129</a>. GC values and relative frequencies as measures of stability, and    GC values and relative Bremer support as measures of support are expressed between    parentheses in each node (see Material and Methods, and Mirande, 2009).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>OUTGROUP</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Node 172: Characoidea    (100 / 100 / 76 / 24)</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Families Alestidae,    Characidae, Gasteropelecidae, and Serrasalmidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The superfamily    Characoidea was proposed by Buckup (1998) to include the Characidae (containing    the Serrasalmidae) and Gasteropelecidae. That author did not include the Gasteropelecidae    in his analysis, but classified that family with the Characidae based mainly    on G&eacute;ry (1977), who stated that the gasteropelecids have most characters    in common with certain characids. The Characoidea is redefined in this paper    to include, in addition, the former families Acestrorhynchidae and Cynodontidae    (herein considered as subfamilies of the Characidae) and the Alestidae. In the    publication by Buckup (1998) both the Acestrorhynchidae and Cynodontidae are    included in the superfamily Cynodontoidea, while the Alestidae was classified    in its own superfamily, the Alestoidea. Although no serrasalmids were included    in the phylogeny of Buckup (1998), that author preferred to maintain this group    as a 
subfamily of the Characidae in light of the lack of phylogenetic information    refuting a close relationship of these families. In the molecular hypothesis    of Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>. (2005) the Serrasalmidae, however, forms a clade    separate from the Characidae. The hypothesis herein proposed also supports a    familial level status for serrasalmids.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Synapomorphies:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Relative    position of anterior margin of antorbital and first infraorbital (57): (1 &gt;    0) anterior margin of antorbital either aligned with or anterior to first infraorbital.    Reversed in node 184 and in <i>Galeocharax humeralis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Form    of lateral line (89): (0 &gt; 1) curved ventrally in abdominal region. Paralleled    in <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i>. Reversed in <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Relative    number of precaudal vertebrae (226): (0 &gt; 1) equal or less numerous than    caudal vertebrae. Reversed in <i>Brycinus carolinae</i>, <i>Chalceus macrolepidotus</i>,    and <i>Gymnocharacinus bergii</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>4.</b> Dorsal    longitudinal ridge on medial lamella of pelvic bone (264): (0 &gt; 1) absent.    Reversed in the node 184.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>5.</b> Number    of branched anal-fin rays (286): (0 &gt; 1) 11 or more. Reversed in <i>Chalceus    macrolepidotus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>6.</b> Number    of branched anal-fin rays (287): (0 &gt; 1) 18 or more. Reversed in the Alestidae,    in nodes 280 and 290, and in <i>Attonitus ephimeros</i> and <i>Prodontocharax    melanotus</i>. Some trees: Reversed in <i>Hasemania nana</i>. Paralleled in    node 182.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>7.</b> Lateral    lamellae on anterior anal pterygiophores (295): (1 &gt; 0) absent. Reversed    in the Alestidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Node 171: Gasteropelecidae    (100 / 100 / 100 / 89)</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Genera <i>Carnegiella</i>,    <i>Engraulisoma</i>, <i>Gasteropelecus</i> Scopoli, and <i>Thoracocharax</i>;    genus <i>Clupeacharax</i>?</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Although the monophyly    of the Gasteropelecidae, as traditionally defined, has long been obvious (Weitzman,    1954, 1960; Buckup, 1998), the relationships of this family with the remaining    Characiformes had not been adequately tested. The great morphological divergence    of the gasteropelecids probably complicated their inclusion in previous morphological    phylogenies; however, no members of this family were included also in the molecular    phylogeny of Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>. (2005). As herein proposed this family    includes all genera traditionally considered in the Gasteropelecidae plus <i>Engraulisoma</i>    (and tentatively also <i>Clupeacharax</i>). Castro (1984) proposed a close relationship    between <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i> and <i>Clupeacharax anchoveoides</i>,    the only member of the characid subfamily Clupeacharacinae (G&eacute;ry, 1977;    Lima, 2003a), based on seven putative 
synapomorphies: the possession of a foramen    in the ventral surface of the pterotic, the short supraorbital, the fusion of    the third and fourth infraorbitals (*), the antorbital with unique form and    size within Characidae (*), the third branchiostegal ray articulated in the    suture between the anterior and posterior ceratohyals, the absence of the second    and third postcleithra (*), and the presence of interdigitations between the    ischiatic processes of the pelvic bones. Synapomorphies marked with (*) are    comparable to those defining the Gasteropelecidae in this analysis. The fusion    of the posttemporal and supracleithrum, and the possession of only one epural,    mentioned as autapomorphies of <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i> by Castro (1984),    are shared with all the former Gasteropelecidae and with <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i>,    respectively. Similarly, the posteriorly situated dorsal fin is shared between    <i>Clupeacharax</i> and the Gasteropelecidae sensu 
Weitzman (1954). Thus, although    <i>Clupeacharax anchoveoides</i> was not included in this analysis, it can be    tentatively included as <i>incertae sedis</i> within this clade, given the observations    of Castro (1984). With conservativeness as a criterion, the genera <i>Clupeacharax</i>    and <i>Engraulisoma</i> should be included in the Gasteropelecidae whether if    the former genus is actually the sister group of <i>Engraulisoma</i>, as proposed    by Castro (1984), or if <i>Clupeacharax</i> is basal to <i>Engraulisoma</i>    and the remaining Gasteropelecidae. Under all possible scenarios <i>Engraulisoma    taeniatum</i> and probably also <i>Clupeacharax anchoveoides</i> are removed    from the Characidae and included in the Gasteropelecidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Synapomorphies:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Position    of antorbital relative to lateral ethmoid in lateral view (56): (0 &gt; 1) antorbital    overlapping lateral ethmoid. Paralleled in node 302.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Fourth    infraorbital (66): (0 &gt; 1) absent or much reduced and bordered posteriorly    by third and fifth infraorbitals. Paralleled in the Aphyocharacinae, in node    186, and in <i>Aphyodite grammica</i>, <i>Hasemania nana</i>, <i>Hemigrammus    erythrozonus</i>, <i>Hoplocharax goethei</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon pulchripinnis</i>,    and <i>Nematobrycon palmeri</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Laterosensory    canal of first infraorbital (73): (1 &gt; 0) projects dorsally from main body    of first infraorbital. Paralleled in the Heterocharacinae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>4.</b> Alignment    of ascending process of premaxilla (105): (0 &gt; 1) medially shifted and separated    from nasal. Paralleled in node 193.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>5.</b> Position    of coronomeckelian (110): (1 &gt; 0) situated mainly lateral to Meckelian cartilage.    Paralleled in nodes 176 and 206, and in <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>    and <i>Prochilodus lineatus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>6.</b> Inner    row of dentary teeth (143): (0 &gt; 1) absent. Paralleled in nodes 166, 168,    and 189, and in <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i> and <i>Serrasalmus maculatus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>7.</b> Teeth    on third pharyngobranchial (206): (0 &gt; 1) absent. Paralleled in <i>Piaractus    mesopotamicus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>8.</b> Second    postcleithrum (248): (0 &gt; 1) absent. Paralleled in node 302 and in <i>Pseudocorynopoma    doriae</i> and <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>9.</b> Third    postcleithrum (249): (0 &gt; 1) absent. Paralleled in node 302, and in <i>Piabucus    melanostomus</i>, <i>Pyrrhulina australis</i>, <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>, and    <i>Xenagoniates bondi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>10.</b> Fusion    between posttemporal and supracleithrum (255): (0 &gt; 1) present.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>11.</b> Anterior    extension of pelvic-bone along main axis (262): (0 &gt; 1) projecting anterior    of lateral and medial lamellae of pelvic bone. Paralleled in node 302 and in    <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>, <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>, <i>Rhaphiodon    vulpinus</i>, and <i>Stethaprion erythrops</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>12</b>. <i>Circulii</i>    on posterior field of scales (319): (0 &gt; 1) absent. Paralleled in nodes 168    and 206, and in <i>Agoniates anchovia</i>. Some trees: Paralleled in node 302.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Autapomorphies    of <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i>:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Extent    of expansion of first infraorbital lateral to maxilla (59): (0 &gt; 1) covering    most of maxilla. Paralleled in node 277 and in <i>Heterocharax macrolepis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Shape    of ectopterygoid (156): (0 &gt; 2) approximately square.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Contact    between ectopterygoid and anterodorsal region of quadrate (162): (0 &gt; 1)    absent. Paralleled in nodes 184 and 242, and in <i>Aphyocharax dentatus</i>,    <i>Prionobrama paraguayensis</i>, and <i>Stichonodon insignis</i>. Some trees:    Paralleled in the Cheirodontinae and in <i>Microschemobrycon casiquiare</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>4.</b> Interhyal    (210): (0 &gt; 1) absent. Paralleled in <i>Aulixidens eugeniae</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>5.</b> Number    of branchiostegal rays (212): (1 &gt; 0) three. Paralleled in <i>Apareiodon    affinis</i>, <i>Leporinus striatus</i>, and <i>Pyrrhulina australis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>6.</b> Development    of transverse process of neural arch of third vertebra (219): (0 &gt; 1) well    developed and extending beyond anterior margin of tripus. Paralleled in node    302, and in <i>Agoniates anchovia</i>, <i>Cyanocharax alburnus</i>, <i>Deuterodon    langei</i>, <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i>, <i>Roeboexodon geryi</i>, and    <i>Thayeria obliqua</i>. Some trees: Paralleled in <i>Microschemobrycon casiquiare</i>    and <i>Parecbasis cyclolepis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>7.</b> Transitional    vertebrae with haemal canal (229): (0 &gt; 1) absent. Paralleled in nodes 195    and 212, and in <i>Aulixidens eugeniae</i>, <i>Metynnis maculatus</i>, and <i>Piabina    argentea</i>. Some trees: Paralleled in node 247 and in <i>Bryconamericus alpha</i>    and <i>Paracheirodon axelrodi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>8.</b> Base    of second pectoral ray (231): (0 &gt; 1) similar in form and size to base of    posterior rays. Paralleled in node 175. Some trees: Paralleled in node 302.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>9.</b> Bony    ridge of coracoid between base of mesocoracoid and ventral margin of interosseous    space (239): (1 &gt; 0) absent. Paralleled in node 204.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>10.</b> Articulation    between pelvic bones (261): (0 &gt; 1) with bony interdigitations between ischiatic    processes. Paralleled in node 302 and in <i>Agoniates anchovia</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>11.</b> Relative    length of anterior dorsal-fin rays (271): (0 &gt; 1) reaching tip of posterior    rays when adpressed. Paralleled in nodes 163 and 179 and in <i>Pyrrhulina australis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>12.</b> Position    of last supraneural (283): (0 &gt; 1) located more than two vertebrae in front    of first dorsal pterygiophore. Paralleled in nodes 174 and 244 and in <i>Gymnocharacinus    bergii</i> and <i>Xenagoniates bondi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>13.</b> Proximal    and medial radials of anal fins (294): (2 &gt; 0) fused on anterior five pterygiophores.    Paralleled in node 179.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>14.</b> Posterior    margin of hypural 3 (300): (1 &gt; 0) equal to or narrower than posterior margin    of hypural 4. Paralleled in node 181 and in the Alestidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>15.</b> Longitudinal    position of insertion of <i>adductor mandibulae</i> tendon on dentary (330):    (0 &gt; 1) on vertical through middle or anterior half of Meckelian cartilage.    Paralleled in the Iguanodectinae, in nodes 184, 186, 209, 241, 261, and 270,    and in <i>Gymnocharacinus bergii</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Node 170: (100    / 100 / 100 / 65)</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Genera <i>Carnegiella</i>,    <i>Gasteropelecus</i>, and <i>Thoracocharax</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">This node includes    the Gasteropelecidae as defined by Weitzman (1954), and recognized in subsequent    papers (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. G&eacute;ry, 1977). As <i>Gasteropelecus</i> was    not analyzed, it is possible that some synapomorphies of this node actually    correspond to a more restricted clade. Although the monophyly of a clade composed    of <i>Carnegiella</i>, <i>Gasteropelecus</i>, and <i>Thoracocharax</i> was never    tested in a phylogenetic context, it never was questioned, given the high resemblance    of these genera and their morphological divergence from the remaining Characiformes    (Weitzman, 1954; Weitzman &amp; Palmer, 2003). The phylogenetic position of    this clade, however, was unknown, because no previous higher-level phylogenies    included species of the Gasteropelecidae. According to G&eacute;ry (1977: 243),    the members of this node "have most (characters) in common with the Characidae,    
chiefly with certain tetras"; however, this author maintained the Gasteropelecidae    as a family, separated from the Characidae. Malabarba &amp; Weitzman (2003)    proposed a clade supported by the presence of bony hooks on the fin rays, which    included the Characidae, Gasteropelecidae, and Serrasalmidae with the exception    of the genera <i>Agoniates</i>, <i>Clupeacharax</i>, and <i>Engraulisoma</i>.    According to their hypothesis both the Serrasalmidae and Gasteropelecidae should    be included in the Characidae. However, such hypothesis was rather speculative,    and not based on any published phylogenetic analysis.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Synapomorphies:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Ventral    longitudinal lamellae of basioccipital (2): (1 &gt; 0) falling short of posterior    border of basioccipital. Paralleled in node 205 and in <i>Serrasalmus maculatus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Ventral    projection of lagenar capsule (3): (0 &gt; 1) extending ventrally to articulation    between basioccipital and parasphenoid. Paralleled in the Serrasalmidae, in    nodes 205, and 302, and in <i>Cyphocharax spilotus</i> and <i>Micralestes stormsi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Articulation    between medial region of lateral ethmoid and frontal or mesethmoid (17): (0    &gt; 1) extensive articulation of entire lateral ethmoid dorsal margin. Paralleled    in node 193.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>4.</b> Form    of orbitosphenoid (37): (1 &gt; 0) slender, relatively small and separate from    parasphenoid. Paralleled in the Characidae, in node 168, and in <i>Hemiodus</i>    cf. <i>thayeria</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>5.</b> Parietal    fontanel (41): (0 &gt; 1) absent in adults. Paralleled in nodes 162 and 181    and in <i>Brycinus carolinae</i> and <i>Brycon pesu</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>6.</b> Supraorbital    (70): (0 &gt; 1) absent. Paralleled in nodes 185 and 205 and in <i>Micralestes    stormsi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>7.</b> Lateral    surface of vertical canal of preopercle (81): (1 &gt; 0) canal uncovered and    situated posteriorly to musculature and infraorbitals. Paralleled in nodes 175    and 204 and in <i>Chalceus macrolepidotus</i> and <i>Metynnis maculatus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>8.</b> Number    of teeth in inner premaxillary row (130): (0 &gt; 1) eight or more. Paralleled    in the Aphyoditeinae and in <i>Brycon orbignyanus</i>, <i>Grundulus cochae</i>,    <i>Phenacogaster tegatus</i>, <i>Prionobrama paraguayensis</i>, and <i>Salminus    brasiliensis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>9.</b> Form    of quadrate (150): (0 &gt; 1) with anterodorsal portion equal or longer than    ventral region. Paralleled in the <i>Pseudochalceus</i> clade, in nodes 176,    211, and 299, and in <i>Exodon paradoxus</i> and <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>10.</b> Form    of anterior portion of ectopterygoid (157): (0 &gt; 1) slender and articulating    only to lateral margin of palatine, and lacking ligaments to neurocranium. Paralleled    in the Alestidae and in <i>Agoniates anchovia</i> and <i>Attonitus ephimeros</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>11.</b> Bony    lamella dorsal to fourth basibranchial (185): (1 &gt; 0) present. Paralleled    in nodes 168, 203, and 302 and in <i>Phenacogaster tegatus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>12.</b> Anterior    development of basihyal (190): (1 &gt; 0) broadly extending beyond anterior    margin of hypohyals. Paralleled in node 302.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>13.</b> Rows    of gill rakers on first ceratobranchial (192): (1 &gt; 0) one. Paralleled in    node 179.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>14.</b> Development    of medial lamella of coracoid (238): (0 &gt; 1) expanded as a keel. Paralleled    in node 302 and in <i>Paragoniates alburnus</i>, <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>,    <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i>, and <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>15.</b> First    postcleithrum (247): (0 &gt; 1) absent. Paralleled in node 236.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>16.</b> Dorsal    myorhabdoi (273): (0 &gt; 1) present. Paralleled in <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>17.</b> Position    of anteriormost epineurals (274): (0 &gt; 1) reaching to cranium. Paralleled    in nodes 175 and 302 and in <i>Distichodus maculatus</i> and <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>18.</b> Number    of supraneurals (281): (0 &gt; 1) eight or more. Paralleled in node 207 and    in <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i> and <i>Pyrrhulina australis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>19.</b> Anal-fin    position (284): (0 &gt; 1) extended anteriorly ventral to dorsal fin. Paralleled    in nodes 208, 212, and 236 and in <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Autapomorphies    of <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i>:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Opening    between orbitosphenoid and pterosphenoid (39): (1 &gt; 0) present, rounded or    ovate, usually margined by frontal dorsally. Paralleled in nodes 205 and 302.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Ventral    extent of third infraorbital (64): (0 &gt; 1) not reaching horizontal arm of    preopercle, at least anteriorly. Paralleled in nodes 168 and 180.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Number    of maxillary teeth (135): (0 &gt; 1) two or more.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>4.</b> Articulation    between ventral margin of metapterygoid and posterodorsal margin of quadrate    (155): (0 &gt; 1) present. Paralleled in nodes 176 and 299 and in <i>Deuterodon    langei</i>, <i>Heterocharax macrolepis</i>, <i>Pristella maxillaris</i>, and    <i>Roeboides descalvadensis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>5.</b> First    basibranchial (182): (1 &gt; 0) absent or much reduced, not articulating anteriorly    with basihyal. Paralleled in node 163.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>6.</b> Number    of branchiostegal rays (213): (0 &gt; 1) five. Paralleled in <i>Characidium    borellii</i>, <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>, <i>Piaractus mesopotamicus</i>,    and <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>7.</b> Number    of dorsal pterygiophores (278): (0 &gt; 1) 12 or more. Paralleled in the Serrasalmidae    and in <i>Characidium rachovii</i>, <i>Distichodus maculatus</i>, and <i>Hoplias</i>    cf. <i>malabaricus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>8.</b> Number    of branched anal-fin rays (289): (0 &gt; 1) 35 or more. Paralleled in nodes    207 and 212 and in <i>Gymnocorymbus ternetzi</i>, <i>Metynnis maculatus</i>,    <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>, <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i>, <i>Rhaphiodon    vulpinus</i>, and <i>Stethaprion erythrops</i>. Some trees: Paralleled in node    261 and in <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>9.</b> Scales    covering anal-fin base (327): (0 &gt; 1) several rows covering basal third of    anal fin. Paralleled in the Serrasalmidae, in nodes 210 and 221, and in <i>Bario    steindachneri</i>, <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i>, <i>Paragoniates alburnus</i>,    <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>, and <i>Roeboides microlepis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>10.</b> Ventral    union of gill membranes (349): (0 &gt; 1) joined along length of isthmus but    not attached to isthmus. Paralleled in the Iguanodectinae and in node 162.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Autapomorphies    of <i>Carnegiella strigata</i>:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Number    of rows of premaxillary teeth (122): (1 &gt; 0) one. Paralleled in node 195    and in <i>Aulixidens eugeniae</i>, <i>Carlana eigenmanni</i>, <i>Grundulus cochae</i>,    <i>Odontostoechus lethostigmus</i>, <i>Paracheirodon axelrodi</i>, <i>Piabucus    melanostomus</i>, and <i>Probolodus heterostomus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Edentulous    basihyal lamella (189): (0 &gt; 1) present. Paralleled in the Alestidae and    Heterocharacinae, in nodes 175 and 302, and in <i>Bryconops affinis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Adipose    fin (356): (0 &gt; 1) absent. Paralleled in the Gymnocharacinae, in node 181,    and in <i>Phenagoniates macrolepis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Node 180: (100    / 100 / - / 12)</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Families Alestidae,    Characidae, and Serrasalmidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The monophyly of    a clade equivalent to this grouping was not proposed in previous phylogenies.    Uj (1990) proposed the monophyly of an African clade composed of the Alestidae,    Citharinidae, and Distichodontidae, which was repeatedly contradicted in all    subsequent phylogenies. The hypothesis of Buckup (1998) included the Erythrinoidea    in a node similar to this one, making his results incompatible with those obtained    in this study. In the hypothesis of Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>. (2005) the Alestidae    are more related to the Crenuchidae and Erythrinoidea than to the Characidae.    The families forming this node formed a trichotomy in the final hypothesis proposed    by Mirande (2009), whereas the Serrasalmidae are herein proposed to be the sister    group of the Alestidae and Characidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Synapomorphies:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Length    of sphenotic spine (10): (0 &gt; 1) extending ventrally to articulation between    sphenotic and hyomandibula. Paralleled in <i>Prochilodus lineatus</i>. Reversed    in the Characinae and in nodes 176 and 197.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Ventral    diverging lamellae of mesethmoid (30): (0 &gt; 1) present. Reversed in node    184.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Ventral    extent of third infraorbital (64): (0 &gt; 1) not reaching horizontal arm of    preopercle, at least anteriorly. Paralleled in node 168 and in <i>Thoracocharax    stellatus</i>. Reversed in the Heterocharacinae and Iguanodectinae, in nodes    184, 198, 225, and 302, and in <i>Agoniates anchovia</i>, <i>Brycon pesu</i>,    <i>Hasemania nana</i>, <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i>, <i>Moenkhausia sanctaefilomenae</i>,    <i>Pseudochalceus kyburzi</i>, <i>Roeboexodon geryi</i>, and <i>Stichonodon    insignis</i>. Some trees: Reversed in node 292.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>4.</b> Tubules    for passage of blood vessels on lamellar portion of maxilla (98): (0 &gt; 2)    anastomosed tubules.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>5.</b> Horizontal    process of anguloarticular (108): (0 &gt; 1) broadly covered by dentary which    reaches posterior border of Meckelian cartilage. Reversed in nodes 176 and 206.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>6.</b> Ascending    process of neural pedicle of third vertebra (220): (0 &gt; 1) present. Paralleled    in <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i>. Reversed in <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>7.</b> Supraneural    anterior to neural spine of fourth vertebra (279): (0 &gt; 1) present and vertically    elongate. Reversed in the Iguanodectinae, in node 204, and in <i>Micralestes    stormsi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>8.</b> Uroneurals    (306): (0 &gt; 1) two pairs. Paralleled in node 163. Reversed in node 205.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Node 187: Serrasalmidae    (100 / 100 / 100 / 59)</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Genera <i>Acnodon</i>    Eigenmann, <i>Catoprion</i> M&uuml;ller &amp; Troschel, <i>Colossoma</i> Eigenmann    &amp; Kennedy, <sup>&#8224;</sup><i>Megapiranha</i> Cione, Dahdul, Lundberg    &amp; Machado-Allison, <i>Metynnis</i> Cope, <i>Mylesinus</i> Valenciennes,    <i>Myleus</i> M&uuml;ller &amp; Troschel, <i>Mylossoma</i> Eigenmann &amp; Kennedy,    <i>Ossubtus</i> J&eacute;gu, <i>Piaractus</i>, <i>Pristobrycon</i> Eigenmann,    <i>Pygocentrus</i> M&uuml;ller &amp; Troschel, <i>Pygopristis</i> M&uuml;ller    &amp; Troschel, <i>Serrasalmus</i>, <i>Tometes</i> Valenciennes, and <i>Utiaritichthys</i>    Miranda Ribeiro.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The monophyly of    this clade was proposed by Machado-Allison (1983, 1986), supported by 27 synapomorphies,    and subsequently corroborated by the molecular phylogenies by Ort&iacute; <i>et    al</i>. (1996) and Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>. (2005). The taxonomic level of    this group has been longly debated. G&eacute;ry (1977) treated it as a family,    while Machado-Allison (1982, 1983, 1985, 1986) and J&eacute;gu (2003) considered    this clade as a subfamily of the Characidae. According to the phylogenetic hypothesis    of Calcagnotto <i>et al</i>. (2005), this clade should be classified as a family,    as herein proposed. As only a small sample of the serrasalmids are herein analyzed,    some synapomorphies could correspond to more inclusive clades.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Synapomorphies:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Ventral    projection of lagenar capsule (3): (0 &gt; 1) extending ventrally to articulation    between basioccipital and parasphenoid. Paralleled in nodes 170, 205, and 302    and in <i>Cyphocharax spilotus</i> and <i>Micralestes stormsi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Length    of supraoccipital spine (53): (1 &gt; 0) extends posteriorly to, at least, middle    length of neural complex of Weberian apparatus. Paralleled in nodes 182 and    205 and in <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i> and <i>Prochilodus lineatus</i>. Some    trees: Paralleled in <i>Brycon meeki</i> and <i>B</i>. <i>orbignyanus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Teeth    on inner premaxillary row (126): (1 &gt; 0) molariform.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>4.</b> Polymorphism    of teeth on inner premaxillary row (131): (0 &gt; 1) present, with two medial    teeth somewhat larger and usually separated from remaining ones by a gap. Paralleled    in the Bryconinae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>5.</b> Posterior    directed radial striae from articular region of opercle (169): (0 &gt; 1) present.    Paralleled in <i>Prochilodus lineatus</i>.</font></p>
