<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>8.</b> Posterior    margin of cleithrum (235): (0 &gt; 1) with markedly concave margin, almost forming    straight angle. Paralleled in nodes 162 and 247 and in <i>Agoniates anchovia</i>,    <i>Attonitus ephimeros</i>, <i>Characidium borellii</i>, <i>Iguanodectes geisleri</i>,    <i>Moenkhausia</i> cf. <i>intermedia</i>, <i>Prionobrama paraguayensis</i>,    and <i>Xenagoniates bondi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>9.</b> Insertion    of <i>adductor mandibulae</i> tendon on dentary (331): (0 &gt; 1) anterior to    Meckelian cartilage. Paralleled in nodes 183 and 186 and in <i>Xenagoniates    bondi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Autapomorphies    of <i>Piabina argentea</i>:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Position    of sphenotic spine relative to hyomandibula (11): (0 &gt; 1) displaced anteriorly    relative to anterior margin of hyomandibula. Paralleled in nodes 162 and 211    and in <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i>, <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i>, and    <i>Serrasalmus maculatus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Relative    length of palatine (172): (1 &gt; 0) approximately one-half length of ectopterygoid,    or less. Reversal of synapomorphy 4 of node 197. Paralleled in node 255 and    in <i>Acrobrycon tarijae</i>, <i>Aphyocharax nattereri</i>, <i>Gymnocharacinus    bergii</i>, and <i>Parecbasis cyclolepis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Contact    between lamella on anterior portion of first basibranchial with lamella on posterior    portion of second basibranchial (183): (0 &gt; 1) present. Paralleled in the    <i>Bryconops</i> clade, in nodes 168, 177, and 216, and in <i>Chalceus macrolepidotus</i>,    <i>Distichodus maculatus</i>, <i>Hemiodus</i> cf. <i>thayeria</i>, and <i>Hoplias</i>    cf. <i>malabaricus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>4.</b> Transitional    vertebrae with haemal canal (229): (0 &gt; 1) absent. Paralleled in nodes 195    and 212, and in <i>Aulixidens eugeniae</i>, <i>Engraulisoma taeniatum</i>, and    <i>Metynnis maculatus</i>. Some trees: Paralleled in node 247 and in <i>Bryconamericus    alpha</i> and <i>Paracheirodon axelrodi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>5.</b> Posterior    region of <i>levator arcus palatini</i> (337): (0 &gt; 1) limited lateral and    medially by A2 and A3 sections of <i>adductor mandibulae</i>. Paralleled in    <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Node 252: (100    / 100 / 89 / 70)</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Genus <i>Creagrutus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">As mentioned in    the preceding node, a test for the monophyly of <i>Creagrutus</i> is beyond    the objectives of this paper and this issue was studied in detail by Vari &amp;    Harold (2001), who diagnosed this genera supported by 11 synapomorphies. The    two species herein analyzed were included in a large polytomy of 41 species    of the genus in the hypothesis of Vari &amp; Harold (2001).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Synapomorphies:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Longitudinal    ridge in quadrate bordering <i>adductor mandibulae</i> muscle ventrally and,    to some degree, laterally (152): (0 &gt; 1) present. Paralleled in the Iguanodectinae    and in node 209.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Shape    of dentigerous plate of fifth ceratobranchial (204): (1 &gt; 0) rounded, with    posterior notch. Paralleled in the Iguanodectinae and in <i>Axelrodia lindeae</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Articulation    between ventral process of mesocoracoid and dorsal margin of scapula (245):    (0 &gt; 1) present and broad. Paralleled in <i>Gymnocharacinus bergii</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>4.</b> Number    of unbranched anal-fin rays (285): (1 &gt; 0) three or fewer. Paralleled in    <i>Iguanodectes geisleri</i> and <i>Paracheirodon axelrodi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>5.</b> Number    of ventral procurrent caudal-fin rays (302): (0 &gt; 1) 12 or more. Paralleled    in the <i>Bryconops</i> clade, in node 229, and in <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Autapomorphies    of <i>Creagrutus</i> cf. <i>taphorni</i>:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Ventral    extent of third infraorbital (64): (0 &gt; 1) not reaching horizontal arm of    preopercle, at least anteriorly. Reversal of synapomorphy 2 of node 198. Paralleled    in nodes 280 and 298 and in <i>Aphyodite grammica</i>, <i>Axelrodia lindeae</i>,    and <i>Bryconamericus rubropictus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Length    of medial bony ridge of opercle (170): (1 &gt; 0) 60% or greater than opercular    length. Paralleled in the Serrasalmidae, in node 210, and in <i>Astyanax abramis</i>,    <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>, and <i>Roeboides microlepis</i>. Some    trees: Paralleled in <i>Acestrorhynchus pantaneiro</i> and <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Process    of scapula forming anterior border of scapular foramen (244): (0 &gt; 1) absent.    Paralleled in node 193 and in <i>Aphyodite grammica</i>, <i>Deuterodon langei</i>,    <i>Hoplias</i> cf. <i>malabaricus</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon herbertaxelrodi</i>,    <i>Leporinus striatus</i>, <i>Odontostilbe paraguayensis</i>, and <i>Thayeria    obliqua</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Autapomorphies    of <i>Creagrutus anary</i>:</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>1.</b> Length    of sphenotic spine (10): (0 &gt; 1) extending ventrally to articulation between    sphenotic and hyomandibula. Reversal of synapomorphy 1 of node 197. Paralleled    in <i>Inpaichthys kerri</i>. Some trees: Paralleled in <i>Aphyodite grammica</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>2.</b> Position    of ventral margin of posttemporal (252): (1 &gt; 0) anterior to lateral margin    of epioccipital. Paralleled in nodes 162, 285, and 301 and in <i>Aulixidens    eugeniae</i>, <i>Diapoma speculiferum</i>, <i>Moenkhausia</i> cf. <i>intermedia</i>,    and <i>Pyrrhulina australis</i>. Some trees: Paralleled in node 247 and in <i>Knodus    breviceps</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>3.</b> Relative    position of dorsal-fin anterior insertion (265): (1 &gt; 0) anterior to or at    vertical through pelvic-fin origin. Paralleled in node 282 and in <i>Exodon    paradoxus</i>, <i>Moenkhausia xinguensis</i>, and <i>Parecbasis cyclolepis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>4.</b> Pelvic-fin    bony hooks in adult males of species bearing hooks on fins (309): (1 &gt; 0)    absent. Paralleled in <i>Hyphessobrycon eques</i>, <i>H</i>. <i>luetkenii</i>,    <i>Phenacogaster tegatus</i>, <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i>, and <i>Stethaprion    erythrops</i>. Some trees: Paralleled in <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i> and <i>Psellogrammus    kennedyi</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>5.</b> Contact    between dorsal margin of <i>adductor mandibulae</i> and ventral margin of <i>dilator    operculi</i> (335): (1 &gt; 0) absent. Paralleled in <i>Inpaichthys kerri</i>,    <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>, <i>Prionobrama paraguayensis</i>, <i>Pristella    maxillaris</i>, <i>Prodontocharax melanotus</i>, and <i>Pyrrhulina australis</i>.    Some trees: Paralleled in <i>Hyphessobrycon elachys</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>6.</b> Anterior    extension of <i>adductor arcus palatini</i> (336): (1 &gt; 0) covering most    of dorsal surface of mesopterygoid. Paralleled in node 166 and in <i>Markiana    nigripinnis</i> and <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i>. Some trees: Paralleled in    <i>Brycon orbignyanus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Some trees:</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>7.</b> Anterior    convergence of ventral diverging lamellae with nasal septum of mesethmoid (31):    (0 &gt; 1) confluent at posterior end of nasal septum. (some trees under k9-14).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Incertae    sedis</i> genera</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">In strict sense,    all the genera listed with question marks can be considered as <i>incertae sedis</i>    within the Characidae; however, there are differences in the situation of that    genera and those listed below. The genera listed with question marks have some    evidence relating them to various clades obtained in this paper, and were listed    in such a manner only because a corroboration from a phylogenetic study is lacking.    Thus, these genera could be considered to be included, at least provisionally,    in a clade defined here. The genera listed below, in contrast lack published    evidence relating them to any clade herein recognized. Most of these genera    were defined by autapomorphies, and their descriptions and published information    does not include presumably apomorphic features shared with some clade of the    present hypothesis. The available information of these genera is listed below    in 
relation to the present analysis.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Astyanacinus</i>    Eigenmann, 1907</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><i>Astyanacinus</i>    was considered closely related to <i>Astyanax</i>, differing from that genus    only by the form of the mouth. In <i>Astyanacinus</i> the maxilla is long and    does not form an angle with the premaxilla (Eigenmann, 1921). This character    state is present in other genera of the Characidae, as <i>Dectobrycon</i>, <i>Hollandichthys</i>,    <i>Oligosarcus</i>, and <i>Pseudochalceus</i>. Among the presumably apomorphic    features of <i>Astyanacinus</i>, the rounded humeral spot and the presence of    <i>circulii</i> on the posterior field of scales &#91;(pers. obs. in <i>A</i>.    <i>moorii</i> (Boulenger)&#93; and the presence of chromatophores densely concentrated    in the focus of scales (pers. obs. in <i>A</i>. <i>multidens</i> Pearson), would    relate this genus with the <i>Astyanax bimaculatus</i>-group, while the presence    of chevron-shaped marks on the flanks is shared with <i>Astyanax 
superbus</i>    Myers and <i>Hyphessobrycon bifasciatus</i>, among other species. These alternatives    could relate <i>Astyanacinus</i> both with the <i>Astyanax</i> clade or with    the <i>Hyphessobrycon luetkenii</i> clade and it is preferable to leave this    genus as <i>incertae sedis</i> pending its inclusion in a phylogeny of the family.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Atopomesus</i>    Myers, 1927</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">G&eacute;ry (1977)    mentioned that this genus has seven aligned and strong premaxillary teeth; that    author included this genus in his Aphyoditeina, without any phylogenetic analysis.    Although the relatively high number of premaxillary teeth is rather similar    to one of the synapomorphies of the Aphyoditeinae (eight or more premaxillary    teeth), the teeth in members of this subfamily are slender and small. Therefore,    it is preferable to leave <i>Atopomesus</i> as <i>incertae sedis</i> within    the Characidae pending further analysis.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Bryconella</i>    G&eacute;ry, 1965b</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">According to G&eacute;ry    (1977) this genus is a <i>Hemigrammus</i> - like tetra, with differences in    the infraorbitals and the dentition. That author mentioned that the inner premaxillary    tooth row of <i>Bryconella</i> has only two or three teeth, which are much close    to the anterior row, and that in some individuals both rows merge in an irregular    row of teeth. Among the species herein examined, a comparable situation was    observed only in <i>Inpaichthys kerri</i> (Aphyocharacinae), but this feature    could be a parallelism.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Brittanichthys</i>    G&eacute;ry, 1965a</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The phylogenetic    position of this genus is uncertain. G&eacute;ry (1965a, 1973, 1977) classified    it among the Aphyoditeina, based principally on a numerical taxonomy analysis    (G&eacute;ry, 1965a). It shares the presence of one row of premaxillary teeth,    among other features, with some members of Aphyoditeinae. The analysis of G&eacute;ry    (1965a) grouped <i>Brittanichthys</i> with <i>Leptobrycon</i> and these two    species were grouped with <i>Aphyodite</i> and <i>Parecbasis</i>. G&eacute;ry    (1965a) mentioned also that <i>Brittanichthys</i> has ectopterygoid and mesopterygoid    teeth and lacks a tongue; these conditions are unique or much unusual among    characids. Moreira (2002), in his coding of this species, reported the frontal    fontanel as margined anteriorly by the mesethmoid, thereby differing from the    examined species of the Aphyoditeinae, in which the frontal fontanel is limited    
anteriorly by the frontals. This genus is inseminating (Malabarba, 1998a) and    modifications of the medial caudal-fin rays (G&eacute;ry, 1965a, 1977) resemble    those of some Stevardiinae. The relationships of this genus, thus, should be    tested in a phylogenetic framework.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Dectobrycon</i>    Zarske &amp; G&eacute;ry, 2006</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><i>Dectobrycon    armeniacus</i> Zarske &amp; G&eacute;ry shares some dentition features and the    presence of an interrupted lateral line with <i>Hollandichthys</i> and <i>Pseudochalceus</i>    (<i>Pseudochalceus</i> clade) and the presence of scales covering most of the    length of the anal-fin with <i>Markiana</i> (<i>Astyanax</i> clade) (Zarske    &amp; G&eacute;ry, 2006). The available data would indicate a higher affinity    of this genus with <i>Hollandichthys</i> and <i>Pseudochalceus</i>, but it is    preferable herein to leave this genus provisionally as <i>incertae sedis</i>    within the Characidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Genycharax</i>    Eigenmann, 1912</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The only species    described for this genus, <i>Genycharax tarpon</i> Eigenmann, has a general    appearance of an <i>Astyanax</i>, but with a clupeoid mouth and elongated and    curved teeth. This genus was related with <i>Astyanax</i> and some Characinae    by G&eacute;ry (1977). According to the illustrations of G&eacute;ry (1977)    this species lacks a supraorbital bone, and it would not be included either    in the subfamilies Acestrorhynchinae, Agoniatinae, Bryconinae, Cynodontinae,    Iguanodectinae or Salmininae, nor in the <i>Bryconops</i> clade. Although this    species shares some details of general appearance and the presence of unicuspidate    teeth with the Characinae, such a proposed relationship would be speculative    and it is maintained herein as <i>incertae sedis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Gymnotichthys</i>    Fern&aacute;ndez-Y&eacute;pez, 1950</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The unique known    species of this genus, <i>Gymnotichthys hildae</i> Fern&aacute;ndez-Y&eacute;pez    has a naked predorsal line as occurs in <i>Gymnocorymbus</i> and the overall    body shape and coloration are similar to some <i>Moenkhausia</i> of the <i>lepidura</i>-group    (G&eacute;ry, 1977). If this species is related with some of these genera, it    should be included in the Tetragonopterinae. Indeed, if the <i>Moenkhausia lepidura</i>    - group of G&eacute;ry (1977) is monophyletic and includes <i>G</i>. <i>hildae</i>,    all its species should be transferred to <i>Gymnotichthys</i>, according to    the hypothesis herein proposed. However, all these conjectures are speculative    in the current state of knowledge and further studies are necessary to assess    the relationships of this genus.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Mixobrycon</i>    Eigenmann, 1915</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><i>Mixobrycon ribeiroi</i>    (Eigenmann) was originally described as a species of <i>Cheirodon</i> (Eigenmann    &amp; Ogle, 1907) and it was considered as part of the Cheirodontinae by G&eacute;ry    (1977) in having only one row of premaxillary teeth. Malabarba (1998a) mentioned    that the holotype of this species, although much damaged, resembles some <i>Hyphessobrycon</i>    species and that the unique feature relating this species with the Cheirodontinae    is the dentition.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Oligobrycon</i>    Eigenmann, 1915</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><i>Oligobrycon</i>    was included in the Aphyoditeina by G&eacute;ry (1977) by sharing some characters    that are actually broadly distributed in Characidae (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. compressed    body, adipose fin present, dorsal fin without dark markings). G&eacute;ry stated    in the identification key of the Aphyoditeina that <i>O</i>. <i>microstomus</i>    Eigenmann has strong but not compressed teeth and only four teeth in the premaxilla.    One of the synapomorphies of the Aphyoditeinae is the presence of eight or more    slender premaxillary teeth in a single row; thus, this species is maintained    as <i>incertae sedis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Parapristella</i>    G&eacute;ry, 1964b</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">This genus, with    two recognized species, is distinguishable from <i>Pristella</i> mainly in having    two rows of premaxillary teeth, resembling a <i>Hemigrammus</i> species with    a higher number of maxillary teeth (G&eacute;ry, 1977). Although both <i>Hemigrammus</i>    and <i>Pristella</i> are herein included in the Tetragonopterinae, <i>Parapristella</i>    does not share presumably apomorphic character-states with any of the genera    included in this clade and it is maintained herein as <i>incertae sedis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Schultzites</i>    G&eacute;ry, 1964b</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><i>Schultzites    axelrodi</i> G&eacute;ry, the unique species of this genus, is differentiated    from <i>Moenkhausia</i> by having seven to ten maxillary teeth distributed along    2/3 of its length. The remaining characters of this genus resemble <i>Moenkhausia    dichroura</i> or <i>M</i>. <i>intermedia</i> (Tetragonopterinae) (G&eacute;ry,    1977). As in <i>Parapristella</i>, the limited available information for this    genus would suggest its inclusion in the Tetragonopterinae, but given the lack    of apomorphic characters supporting this relationship, it is maintained herein    as <i>incertae sedis</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Scissor</i>    G&uuml;nther, 1864</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">This monotypic    genus was described from a single specimen of uncertain origin, although it    is supposed that it is from Suriname (Lima <i>et al</i>., 2003). According to    Eigenmann (1917) this specimen has short gill-rakers, 29 anal-fin rays, conical    teeth distributed along one half of the maxillary length, and premaxillary and    dentary teeth similar to those of <i>Tetragonopterus</i>. G&eacute;ry (1977)    included <i>Scissor macrocephalus</i> G&uuml;nther in his tribe Bramocharacini.    The available information, as evident, is not sufficient to propose the inclusion    of this genus in any of the clades herein proposed.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Serrabrycon</i>    Vari, 1986</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><i>Serrabrycon    magoi</i> Vari, the only species of this genus, shares the presence of teeth    oriented outside the mouth and the lepidophagous habit with <i>Probolodus</i>    (Tetragonopterinae), <i>Bryconexodon</i>, <i>Exodon</i>, <i>Roeboexodon</i>,    and <i>Roeboides</i> (Characinae) (Vari, 1986). According to its description,    this species could be related with the genera <i>Hemigrammus</i> and <i>Pristella</i>    (Tetragonopterinae), or with some of the mentioned lepidophagous genera.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Stygichthys</i>    Brittan &amp; B&ouml;hlke, 1965</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The position of    this genus within Characidae is completely enigmatic; even its assignment to    the Characidae can not be considered to be well justified. The single species    of this genus, <i>Stygichthys typhlops</i> Brittan &amp; B&ouml;hlke, has hypogean    habits and some unique or much unusual features among the Characidae (G&eacute;ry,    1977). The presence in this species of a very short anal fin with only eight    rays is unique within the Characidae. No information relevant to a hypothesis    about the relationships of this genus is available and <i>Stygichthys</i> is    maintained as <i>incertae sedis</i> within the Characidae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Thrissobrycon</i>    B&ouml;hlke, 1953b</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">This genus, composed    only of <i>Thrissobrycon pectinifer</i> B&ouml;hlke, was included in the Aphyoditeina    by G&eacute;ry (1973). This author mentioned that the clupeoid mouth of this    genus resembles that of <i>Leptobrycon</i> and <i>Oxybrycon.</i> This feature    differentiates these three genera from the genera herein included in the Aphyoditeinae.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b><i>Tucanoichthys</i>    G&eacute;ry &amp; R&ouml;mer, 1997</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">The relationships    of the miniature genus <i>Tucanoichthys</i> are unknown. <i>Tucanoichthys tucano</i>    G&eacute;ry &amp; R&ouml;mer, its single species, has one row of eight conical    premaxillary teeth, resembling some members of the Aphyoditeinae or Characinae.    The maxilla is completely toothed as in the Characinae, whereas the predorsal    line is naked as in <i>Gymnocorymbus</i> (Tetragonopterinae). Its coloration    resembles that of <i>Hyphessobrycon herbertaxelrodi</i>, with a broad black    lateral band dorsally delineated by a clear margin (G&eacute;ry &amp; R&ouml;mer,    1997). The resemblance of this species to the Aphyoditeinae and the miniature    genus <i>Priocharax</i> was mentioned in its description (G&eacute;ry &amp;    R&ouml;mer, 1997).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Discussion of    characters of Eigenmann (1917)</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Most of the current    systematics of the Characidae was delineated by the classification of Eigenmann    (1917). This classification was proposed as provisional by that author, who    highlighted that some of the genera were probably polyphyletic and noted the    necessity of a classification that reflected the divergent phylogenetic history    of the group. In a first attempt to use an evolutionary approach, he proposed    alternative states for 17 characters which presence or absence, in different    combinations, defined most genera of the Characidae. Eigenmann (1917) "optimized"    these character-states in a radial scheme, recognizing the impossibility of    producing a divergent scheme with his data. Eigenmann traced evolutionary lines    for each character in his radial scheme, taking as primitive their most frequent    states. In this manner, he considered <i>Astyanax</i> as the most primitive    genus in having 
the most frequent states of all the characters he utilized.    Eigenmann's classification was later followed by G&eacute;ry (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>.    1977) and others, but its shortcomings were subsequently noted in phylogenetically-oriented    papers that questioned the value of the characters of Eigenmann (1917) (<i>e</i>.    <i>g</i>. Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1983). Most of these characters are analyzed    here in a familial context, and their phylogenetic informativeness can be evaluated    for first time based on a thorough phylogenetic analysis.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 64: Ventral    coverage of third infraorbital</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Defined as "cheeks    partly naked" <i>vs</i>. "cheeks entirely covered by the third suborbital" by    Eigenmann (1917). This character was not "optimized" in the hypothesis of Eigenmann    (1917: <a href="#f1">fig. 1</a>), although the absence of contact between the    third infraorbital (second suborbital according to Eigenmann) was used to distinguish    <i>Knodus</i> from <i>Moenkhausia</i>, and to characterize <i>Astyanacinus</i>,    <i>Astyanax</i>, <i>Ctenobrycon</i>, <i>Deuterodon</i>, <i>Hasemania</i>, <i>Hollandichthys</i>,    <i>Hyphessobrycon</i>, <i>Landonia</i>, <i>Pseudochalceus</i>, <i>Pristella</i>,    and <i>Psellogrammus</i>, in his generic key. In the present analysis this character    is highly homoplastic (28 steps). Considering only unambiguous transformations,    this character is a synapomorphy for nine clades of this analysis and an autapomorphy    for 14 species. The reduction of infraorbitals 
was proposed to be related with    miniaturization events (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. B&uuml;hrnheim <i>et al</i>., 2008).    Although it is true that most miniature species usually have reduced infraorbitals    (in number and/or development), a slight reduction producing a separation between    the infraorbitals and the preopercle is also present in some non-miniature species.    Indeed, only nine of the transformations proposed for this character are optimized    as separation of the third infraorbital and the preopercle, while the remaining    14 are optimized as expansion of that infraorbital to reach the preopercle.    This suggests that although highly homoplastic, this character has phylogenetic    information which is independent from miniaturization events and it should be    analyzed in phylogenies, especially in those considering the homoplasy degree    as useful information (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. under implied weighting or self-weighted    optimization; Goloboff, 1993, 
1997).</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 91: Lateral    line</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Defined as "lateral    line complete" <i>vs</i>. "lateral line incomplete" by Eigenmann (1917). This    character delineated much of the Eigenmann's characid scheme of relationships    (Eigenmann, 1917: <a href="#f1">fig. 1</a>), as an outer line separating the    genera with an interrupted lateral line. An interrupted lateral line defined,    according to Eigenmann (1917), <i>Brycochandus</i> (=<i>Bryconops</i> in part),    <i>Hasemania</i>, <i>Hemigrammus</i>, <i>Hollandichthys</i>, <i>Hyphessobrycon</i>,    <i>Nematobrycon</i>, <i>Pristella</i>, <i>Psellogrammus</i>, <i>Pseudochalceus</i>,    and <i>Thayeria</i>. In that scheme the Cheirodontinae, Glandulocaudinae (=Stevardiinae    in part, as herein recognized), and Rhoadsiinae lie over that line, showing    variability within each of these subfamilies. It is noticeable, however, that    these groups are not closely related each other, according to the figure of    
Eigenmann, but originated from different lines of evolution (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>.    <i>Hemigrammus</i>, <i>Pristella</i>, and <i>Thayeria</i> are related with <i>Moenkhausia</i>,    whereas <i>Psellogrammus</i> is related to <i>Ctenobrycon</i>). Thus, Eigenmann    (1917) was implicitly proposing several parallel reductions of the lateral line    within the Characidae. This is in agreement with most subsequent discussions    about that issue, especially regarding miniaturization (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>.    Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1983). However, the high homoplasy and the parallel reduction    (not regaining) of the lateral line was not previously tested in a phylogeny    of the family. In the hypothesis herein proposed, the lateral line is optimized    as having 11 reductions and only one reacquisition, in <i>Xenagoniates bondi</i>.    The reductions are synapomorphies of five clades and six autapomorphies. Thus,    the results of this paper agree with Eigenmann (1917) and subsequent 
authors    in that the loss of a complete lateral line is more usual than reacquisition    of a complete one. Miniaturization can not, however, be considered to be the    only event producing a reduction of the lateral line, as some medium-sized genera    (<i>i</i>. <i>e</i>. <i>Hollandichthys</i>) have reduced lateral lines.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 123: Number    of rows of premaxillary teeth</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Defined as "premaxillary    teeth in two series" <i>vs</i>. "premaxillary teeth in three series" by Eigenmann    (1917). The presence of three series of premaxillary teeth was reported by Eigenmann    (1917) for <i>Creagrutus</i> and <i>Piabina</i>. As mentioned in the description    of the character 123, <i>Piabina argentea</i> is coded as polymorphic. This    character is herein optimized as synapomorphic for the Bryconinae and <i>Creagrutus</i>    (or <i>Piabina</i> plus <i>Creagrutus</i>, given its polymorphism in <i>Piabina</i>)    and autapomorphic for <i>Bryconaethiops macrops</i> and <i>Chalceus macrolepidotus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 137: Extent    of dentition along maxilla</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Defined as "maxillary    with few teeth or none" <i>vs</i>. "maxillary with teeth along its entire edge"    by Eigenmann (1917). Eigenmann (1917: <a href="#f1">fig. 1</a>) implicitly proposed    the parallel acquisition of teeth along the entire maxillary margin in <i>Hemibrycon</i>,    (<i>Hollandichthys</i> + <i>Pseudochalceus</i>), <i>Knodus</i>, <i>Nematobrycon</i>,    <i>Phenacogaster</i>, and <i>Pristella</i>. In this analysis this character    has a moderate degree of homoplasy, with eight unambiguous acquisitions, and    is a synapomorphy for three clades and autapomorphy for five species, along    with two losses of teeth along the entire maxillary margin.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 148: Heterogeneity    of dentary teeth</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Defined as "teeth    of the sides of the dentary abruptly smaller" <i>vs</i>. "teeth of the sides    of the dentary graduated" by Eigenmann (1917). This character was not considered    in the scheme of relationships of Eigenmann (1917: <a href="#f1">fig. 1</a>),    but was used in his generic key to distinguish <i>Astyanacinus</i>, <i>Astyanax</i>,    <i>Ctenobrycon</i>, and <i>Psellogrammus</i>, with abruptly minute dentary teeth    from <i>Deuterodon</i> and <i>Landonia</i>, with graduated teeth. Several intermediate    states were, however, observed in this paper, and only the extreme cases are    coded as having abruptly minute dentary teeth. Thus, the original character    of Eigenmann and those herein used are not directly comparable. As coded here,    this character is moderately homoplastic, with six parallel acquisitions of    abruptly minute dentary teeth and only one reversion to graduate teeth.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 284: Anal-fin    position</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Defined as "origin    of anal behind origin of dorsal" <i>vs</i>. "origin of anal under or in front    of origin of dorsal" by Eigenmann (1917). This character was not considered    in the scheme of relationships of Eigenmann (1917: <a href="#f1">fig. 1</a>).    In the present analysis, this character has five unambiguous transformations    to a posteriorly situated dorsal-fin. Four of them are synapomorphies for specific    clades, while the remaining one is an autapomorphy of <i>Piabucus melanostomus</i>.    However, the posterior position of the dorsal-fin, above the anal fin, is shared    by most of the Iguanodectinae, except <i>Iguanodectes geisleri</i>, among others    (Moreira, 2002). Thus, although relatively homoplastic, this character has important    phylogenetic information at some level.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 317: Ctenii    or spines on scales</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 318: Anterior    margin of scales</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Defined as "scales    entire" <i>vs</i>. "scales ctenoid" and "scales crenate" by Eigenmann (1917).    This character was considered as two separate characters in the present analysis.    The presence of spinoid scales is a synapomorphy of a clade composed of <i>Acestrocephalus</i>,    <i>Cynopotamus</i>, and <i>Galeocharax</i>, but both this state and these species    were not studied by Eigenmann (1917). The presence of ctenoid scales was mentioned    in the generic key of Eigenmann (1917) as present in <i>Ctenobrycon</i> and    <i>Psellogrammus</i>; in the present hypothesis this state is an autapomorphy    of <i>Psellogrammus kennedyi</i>, but no species of <i>Ctenobrycon</i> are analyzed    here and this condition could be a synapomorphy of a clade composed of these    two genera. The presence of crenate scales was mentioned in the generic key    of Eigenmann (1917) for <i>Entomolepis</i> Eigenmann (=<i>Bario</i>). 
This character,    however, is coded as polymorphic in this species given that it is variable during    growth and is optimized in the current hypothesis as independent autapomorphies    of <i>Markiana nigripinnis</i> and <i>Tetragonopterus argenteus</i>.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 324: Predorsal    scales</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Defined as "predorsal    line scaled" <i>vs</i>. "predorsal line naked". The acquisition of a naked predorsal    area has three unambiguous steps in the present hypothesis, two of them supporting    the Gasteropelecidae and a clade composed of <i>Gymnocorymbus</i> and <i>Stichonodon</i>,    respectively. The remaining is an autapomorphy of <i>Lonchogenys ilisha</i>.    This character furthermore has ambiguous changes within the Gymnocharacinae    which may support a clade when a greater number of species is analyzed.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 327: Scales    covering anal-fin base</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Defined as "anal    naked except at the base" <i>vs</i>. "anal scaled to near its tip" by Eigenmann    (1917). The presence of several rows of minute scales covering the anal-fin    base has 11 parallel acquisitions in the present hypothesis. Three of these    changes are synapomorphies, while eight of them are autapomorphies. The rather    homoplastic nature of this character, however, is not a valid argument to ignore    it in a phylogenetic analysis, especially when the degree of homoplasy of the    characters is used as relevant information during tree searches.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 328: Scales    covering caudal-fin lobes</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Defined as "caudal    fin naked" <i>vs</i>. "caudal fin scaled" by Eigenmann (1917). This character    was the main feature in which the scheme of relationships of Eigenmann (1917:    <a href="#f1">fig. 1</a>) was based. Thus, this character had no parallelisms    in his scheme and all the incongruence was resolved by proposing parallelisms    in the characters conflicting with this one. However, as is to be expected according    to the current state of knowledge, this character is homoplastic in this analysis,    having eight unambiguous steps supporting one clade and being autapomorphic    for seven species. As with the previous characters, this degree of homoplasy    is not a valid reason to exclude this character from phylogenetic analyses,    but it is clear that the characid classification can not be principally based    in this character.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Ch. 356: Adipose    fin</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Defined as "adipose    fin present" <i>vs</i>. "adipose fin absent" by Eigenmann (1917). The absence    of an adipose fin is infrequent within the Characiformes and usually related    with miniaturization events (B&uuml;hrnheim <i>et al</i>., 2008). In this analysis    the absence of an adipose fin is optimized as having four unambiguous steps,    of which two are autapomorphies and the remaining two supports the clade composed    of <i>Hoplias</i> and <i>Pyrrhulina</i> and the subfamily Gymnocharacinae, respectively.</font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">On average, the    characters of Eigenmann (1917) analyzed for this phylogeny have 8.7 homoplastic    steps, ranging from 1 to 27 (consistency index: 11.5). This degree of homoplasy    is slightly higher than the average for the whole matrix; in average the characters    used for this phylogeny have 4.6 homoplastic steps (consistency index: 17.8).    Also, the average retention index of Eigenmann's characters is slightly lower    than the average for the whole matrix (60.5 <i>vs</i>. 67.1). This relatively    high degree of homoplasy supports the idea that the systematics of the Characidae    cannot be exclusively based on the characters of Eigenmann, as claimed in several    papers (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1983). It is noticeable, however,    that taking into account the degree of homoplasy during the parsimony searches    through differentially weighted schemes (Goloboff, 1993; 1997), as in the 
present    hypothesis, the influence of highly homoplastic characters is reduced proportionally    to their degree of homoplasy. This leaves characters with low homoplasy (more    congruent with each other) as driving most of the topology of trees. Particularly    when using some of these weighting schemes, no degree of homoplasy is a valid    argument to exclude information from any phylogenetic analysis.</font></p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="3"><b>Conclusions</b></font></p>     
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">This phylogeny    is far from conclusive, but it is a starting point for specific studies in different    clades and degrees of inclusiveness. The morphological description and documentation    presented in this paper are intended to be a reference point for future studies    in this group. However, the morphological evidence analyzed in this paper undoubtedly    does not include all the anatomical variation suitable for analysis in a phylogenetic    context and major contributions in this area are still possible and necessary.    As evidenced, the characters classically used in the systematic of the family,    as longly discussed in the literature (<i>e</i>. <i>g</i>. Eigenmann, 1917;    Weitzman &amp; Fink, 1983) are highly homoplastic, and although useful at some    level, are not sufficient to diagnose generic or suprageneric clades. This phylogeny    delineates future lines of research in almost every major clade, and 
may serve    as a null hypothesis for many possible researches.</font></p>     
<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Buckup, P. A. 1998.    Relationships of the Characidiinae and phylogeny of characiform fishes (Teleostei,    Ostariophysi). Pp. 123-143.   CI-FML 3946: 4 ex. 36.3-40.3 mm. Paraguay, Alto Paraguay, Fort&iacute;n Patria,      
  Negro River. Nov 2002. <i>Pseudochalceus kyburzi</i>. USNM 324462: 2 ex. 36.8-45.3      
  mm. Aquarium specimens. <i>Pseudocorynopoma doriae</i>. CI-FML 3893: 1 ex. 57.5      
  mm. Unknown data. <i>Puntius tetrazona</i>. CI-FML 3860: 1 ex. 26.2 mm. Aquarium      
  specimen. <i>Pyrrhulina australis</i>. CI-FML 3873: 1 ex. 26.7 mm. Paraguay,      
  Alto Paraguay, Fort&iacute;n Patria, Negro River. Nov 2002. <i>Rhaphiodon vulpinus</i>.      
  CI-FML 3871: 1 ex. 193.8 mm. Argentina, Corrientes, Guayquirar&oacute;, Corriente      
  River. Apr 2005. <i>Rhoadsia altipinna</i>. MHNG 2173.31: 59.0-73.5 mm. Per&uacute;,      
  El Caucho, Fai River at Zarumilla River. Nov 1978. <i>Roeboexodon geryi</i>.      
  MHNG 2188.14: 1 ex. 37.0-41.0 mm. Suriname, Desiongkondre and Pokigron, Surinam      
  River. Dec 1963. <i>Roeboides descalvadensis</i>. CI-FML 3859: 2 ex. 61.4-63.1      
  mm (23 ex. 57.5-81.1 mm in alcohol). Argentina, Salta, La Uni&oacute;n, Pozo      
  de los Yacar&eacute;s. Aug 2003. <i>Roeboides microlepis</i>. CI-FML 3881: 1      
  ex. 82.9 mm. Argentina, Corrientes, Guayquirar&oacute;, Corriente River. Apr      
  2005. <i>Salminus brasiliensis</i>. CI-FML 3784: 1 ex. 131.4 mm. Argentina,      
  Santiago del Estero, r&iacute;o Sal&iacute; basin, r&iacute;o Hondo dam. Aug      
  2000. <i>Serrapinnus calliurus</i>. CI-FML 3889: 2 ex. 23.1-23.2 mm. Argentina,      
  Salta, La Uni&oacute;n, Puesto de la Viuda, Bermejo River basin. Nov 2001. <i>Serrasalmus      
  maculatus</i>. CI-FML 3873: 1 ex. 69.2 mm. Argentina, Salta, La Uni&oacute;n,      
  Bermejo River basin. Aug 2003. <i>Stethaprion erythrops</i>. MHNG 2187.33: 2      
  ex. 43.0-44.5 mm. Per&uacute;, Yarina Cocha near Pucallpa, Ucayali River. Jul      
  1980. <i>Stichonodon insignis</i>. MHNG 2173.85: 1 ex. 54.5 mm. Brazil, Solim&otilde;es,      
  Muddy Iguarape. Mar 1974. <i>Tetragonopterus argenteus</i>. CI-FML 3883: 1 ex.      
  62.2 mm. Paraguay, Alto Paraguay, Bah&iacute;a Negra, Paraguay River. Nov 2002.      
  CI-FML 3852: 1 ex. 53.0 mm; Argentina, Corrientes, Guayquirar&oacute;, Corriente      
  River. Apr 2005. <i>Thayeria boehlkei</i>. CI-FML 3947: 2 ex. 25.2-26.6 mm.      
  Aquarium specimens. <i>Thayeria obliqua</i>. MHNG 2173.55: 2 ex. 26.5-35.5 mm.      
  Brazil, Ilha do Castanha, Aripuana River. Jul 1976. <i>Thoracocharax stellatus</i>.      
  CI-FML 3869: 2 ex. 43.7-45.2 mm (13 ex. 38.8-44.9 mm in alcohol). Paraguay,      
  Alto Paraguay, Bah&iacute;a Negra, Paraguay River. Nov 2002. <i>Triportheus      
  nematurus</i>. CI-FML 3948: 1 ex. 82.1 mm. Paraguay, Alto Paraguay, Fort&iacute;n      
  Patria, Negro River. Nov 2002. <i>Triportheus pantanensis</i>. CI-FML 3949:

  Apur&eacute; River. Feb 1978.</font></p>
